Je sais, et je vous le repète encore, mon cher Monsieur, que une cruelle indecision d'esprit vous empeche d'agir, d'ecrire, et même de pailer; — je vous vois effrayé du malheur, honteux de votre situation, en cherchant, sans puvoir trouver de remede; — et quoique je pense que avec de l'energie, de l'activité, et de la perseverance vous pourriez repeter à tout, je ne vous reproche pas de ce que vous ne possedez ces qualités au degré necessaire à votre bonheur; — cela depende de une disposition naturelle, que l'age même peut detruire plus ou moins vite, mais ne peut changer. Ainsi tout étant obligé de ouvrir à M.r Reading votre situation et la mienne, que d'ailleur mon silence n'aurait pas suffi a lui cacher, je lui ai toujours repeté ce que je vous ai écrit et que je crois sincerement — «que vous avez l'ame naturellement honête, et malheureusement egarée par des habitudes dont maintenant il vous est difficile de revenir tout d'un coup; — et que je dois chercher un autre traducteur, non par defiance de votre bonne volonté, mais par la crainte que vous ne puissiez avoir jamais toute la force de resolution à executer vos plans pendant longtems». — Adieu de tout mon coeur.
Tout a vous etc.

My Dear Friend — Lady Calantha having accustomed me to be in fault, and to implore her forbearance, I ought in my turn not to complain if after having induced me to hope to see her at the Digamma Cottage she should suddently change her mind, — but should she disappoint me ten times in the same way, she would not punish me in the tenth part of my deserts. Wednesday, however, as I lost the occasion of seeing you, I felt keenly her chastisement — I had, as usual, a great deal of matter to talk about, — which I will do tomorow Saturday when I come into town. In the mean time I send you four copies of an extract containing the substance of the award made by the Arbiters on my affair with the Doctor — as the award is some what long and as I wish to send copies to several friends, it is impossible for me to have it transcribed at length — But I will bring you the original tomorow: meanwhile as I hear from more than one quarter that the sentimental author of the Sketchbook does not confine himself to simple commiseration of the Doctor, but imputes to me a portion of his sufferings — pray, let him remark in the Extract of the Award signed by his own arbitrators, that the Doctor has been remunerated at the enormous, and unheard of, rate of half a guinée a page for a translation which you know I only partially used — and that while my conduct towards him has been judged to have been considerate and perfectly honorable through the transaction; the same arbitrators declared that the amount as well as the manner of his claims were illjudged and unjustifiable. — Do me the favour to give a copy to M.r Hallam, whom I saw yesterday here, with M.r Milman; but as the award was not signed until late last evening I could not give any exact account of its contents. Hallam spoke to me about the intended edition of the Italian poets, chiefly of Dante, and if I have not sooner renewed the subject, ascribe it, I entreate you, only to circumstances against which I was lately obliged to strive, and which I have slowly and with great difficulty overcome especially as they did not depend on myself alone. My Translator wrongly ashamed of his poverty, left his appartements for two weeks; and I could not prevail upon him to return until yesterday! — So far for my plans. — As for the present, I wish to know whether M.r Gifford thinks the paper on the Digamma will sufficiently entertain the readers so as to prevent them from complaining if it will be followed by the History of Homer's Text — But if, on the contrary, M.r Gifford thinks the subject may be tiresome, I will put into a bag all the papers that I have scribled on the matter, and think of something else. — So, fare well till to–morow, — et adieu de tout mon coeur —
Toujours à vous. Etc.

div1.n: 2656. A Samuel e Richard Bentley (3 aprile 1822)
div1.p: My Dear Sir — I send you a sheet to correct which you will have the goodness to return as soon as possible, as I ought and will, and now I can devote all my time and attention without any interruption to the Edition until it be done, which with assiduity may be done in a few days. — I shall be able to send to you by tomorrow the end of the second Essay with the addition for which at last I have found a translator, — so you may be sure of receiving them. In the meanwhile the Translations and the Originals of Petrarchs poetry, which will form an additional Appendix must be printed in the same type of the other Appendixes, — according to the directions on the Manuscript, which will be explained to you by my Friend — The sooner I have the proofs of these translations, the better I shall be able to refer to them in the third Essay — Meanwhile believe me yours very sincerely obliged etc.

Ugo, — L'ò letta finalmente quella tua Ricciarda bella fra le più belle che fossero mai, pella forza dello stile, pell'economia delle situazioni difficili, ben condotte, patetiche, e veramente teatrali. Fra i caratteri alcuni sono nuovi, e terribili, altri d'una natura superiore alla comune (ciò che non è sempre bellezza nelle arti), alcuni finalmente son freddi, indecisi, sforzati. Senza dubbio Guelfo è il primo carattere dell'azione, e quello che maggiormente interessa come causa prima di tutti gli accidenti secondi. L'ideale di Ricciarda è preso fuori della natura come quello di Michel–Angelo che dispiace perchè è troppo grande. Sia pietà, compassione, debolezza, o timore, il carattere morale di Alverado non contrasta abbastanza con quello di Guelfo per cui nonostante l'indole feroce il lettore s'interessa mercechè assediato in sua reggia. Tu lo sforzi a tutte le colpe di cui si lorda. Guido è un irresoluto che non sa nè amare, nè odiare, nè vivere — nè morire e che esiste fra le Tombe come l'indemoniato del Vangelo viveva fra i Sepolcri.
Oltre questi impercettibili difettucci l'inverisimile opuleggia nella tua Tragedia che finisce alla foggia delle Inglesi con macello della scena.
Candidamente. Etc.

div1.n: 2658. A Samuel e Richard Bentley (13 aprile 1822)
div1.p: Dear Sir —— From the non–appearance of the proof of Lady Dacre's Translation, and from a letter which I now receive from the Post–office, I apprehend that our packet lays there. — They write to me that the parcel addressed to me being too heavy to be forwarded according to the act, will be delivered to any person producing the enclosed notice. — As the man who do my errands does not go into the town every day, and I do not know where the Two penny Post office is to be found, have the goodness of sending there some person to recover the parcel. — Perhaps it does not contain the proof; and in this case also the recovering of the parcel, will be an additional favour from you — If you send it at M.r Colbourn's it will soon find its way to Digamma Cottage —
Ever yours etc.
Saturday —

ps.p: P.S. —— I send you the extract of an award on the question between me and a Translator, who receiving the enormous remuneration of 10.s 6.d for each page of bad translation, threatened me with imprisonnement, and wrote abusive letters and challenges in order to be paid at receive a guinea for every page. — As it is very likely that you have heard of this dispute, and the gentleman in question still continues exposing my name with a profusion of calumnies and complaints, I wish you be acquainted with the decision of the arbitrators, — the one was chosen by him, and he is to this day absolutely unknown to me.

div1.n: 2659. A un mediatore nella disputa con Williams Thomas Moore (23 aprile 1822)

opener.salute: A un mediatore nella disputa col WILLIAMS [THOMAS MOORE]

dateline.date: Regent's Park, South Bank Digamma Cottage — 23 Aprile 1822.

div1.p: Mon cher Monsieur, — J'allais repondre à Will. Rose et le prier de vous rendre mes remercimens, lorsque j'ai appris votre retour, et je puis vous remercier directement de l'offre de votre mediation dans ma dispute avec le D.r Williams. Lorsque la lettre de Rose m'arriva, nous avions deja nommé deux Arbitres. M.r Campbell avait ecrit pour moi — «I am authorised by M.r Foscolo to repeat in writting the answer to your message, which he delivered verbally to your friend — namely that before an affair of honour could be spoken of, the business, as a money–business, must be sifted either by legal judges, as you have threatened to take him to law; or by Arbitrators, as you have proffered arbitrators. He said to your messenger, and he authorises me to repeat, that if you can prove before a judge or an arbitrator the slightest injustice or dishonourableness either in act or intention on this part towards you, he will give you the satisfaction of a gentleman. But he believes, the injustice and dishonourableness to be on your part; and untill you shall disprove this to be the case before a Judge or an Arbitrator, he holds it unworthy of himself to have an affair of honour with you» — Ainsi le Docteur après m'avoir intimé qu'il avait delivré mes lettres confidentielles à un homme de loix pour me forcer à lui payer de l'argent — après m'avoir fait menacer en forme par un attorney de me faire arrêter sur le champ — après m'avoir ecrit une lettre pour m'appeller a scoundrel, and a coward, il a du nommer un Arbitre; j'en ai choisi un autre, — et ils ont decidé — “We find that the quantity of translation completed according to the engagement is thirty pages for which there was due to D.r Williams the sum of L. 15. 15 — We find also that the sum of L. 30, upon which the difference arose, was prematurely demanded by D.r Williams in an ill–judged and unjustifiable manner. With respect to M.r Foscolo, we are of opinion that his conduct towards D.r Williams has been throughout their mutual transactions, considerate and perfectly honorable — Signed C. Reading — Edw. Baldwin, Arbiters”.

Mio caro Giovanni! — Dacchè ci lasciaste, di voi non mi sono scordato un momento! Troppo caro, e pregiato mi foste ognora, ed io nella tenuità de' mezzi d'arte, e di cuore tentai di rendervi persuaso della mia affezione. Quanto caro mi fu al tornare di Davide Bertolotti il sentire che voi pure di me vi ricordavate! Io ne cercai al Cielo, alla terra, ed ad ogni reduce dall'Inghilterra. Qualche foglio letterario mi dié conto de' vostri travagli; ma una sola Tragedia di voi, potei leggere da che partiste. Io costi perdei tutte le mie conoscenze. Fu l'ultima il Presidente della Società Reale, il dottissimo Benk's, ed ignoro se il medico Simons, che contavo fra miei amici in Londra viva ancora. Ma il Maestro appartiene ad epoca troppo remota per lusingarsi dell'esistenza de' suoi contemporanei. Da voi due cose sole esigo. Che mi amiate, e che siate felice. Questo vi è dovuto; l'altro invoco dalla cordialità vostra. Il Sig. Mirri, che oggi mi vide potrà di me parlarvi e parlarvi della nostra Contessa Somaglia, cui l'età non tolse spirito e coltura, ed accrebbe le virtù della sperienza. Pelajo l'ex–gesuita, che faceva il pendant nel Regno alle famose galanterie, cessò di vivere ottagenario.
Aggradite il più tenero, e sincero amplesso
Del vostro Amico vero

My dear Sir. — I have delayed thanking you for your very obliging letter, and I received the printed Copy of your Fragment on the Veil of the Graces, which you thought might reach Woburn by the beginning of this week. I have not yet received it, but I will as longue delay returning you my acknowledgments before obliging relations — allow me at the same time to inform you that I shall be in town to–morrow, and you will perhaps have the goodness to forward the paper to S.t James Square, instead to Woburn —
Believe me with sincere estime
Your very faithful Serv.t etc.

Dear Sir — To the alterations of the begining of the I. and VIII. sections and at page 192 I added scraps of paper to facilitate the corrections to the printer; — and these two sheets may be printed off freely under your inspection. — In the last Appendix containing Lady Dacre's Translations, the lines which were sent the last with the title “Stanzas suggested by a canzone of Petrarch”— and beginning — “A way proud boy” ought not to be printed, Lady Dacre having told M.r Murray that she gave those stanza[s] to Miss Joanna Baillie to be inserted in a collection published for a charitable purpose. —
Ever sincerely yours etc.

div1.n: 2663. A Samuel and Richard Bentley (3 maggio 1822?)
div1.p: I thank you for the promptitude — and for the correctness, which (considering the difficulty of Italian Poetry, and the illegibility of my penmanship) I had no right to hope. — There are still a few errors which you will have the goodness to correct; you will see them in one of the copies. — But this is not the whole of the fragment; having by mistake omitted to send the remainder, I found it to–day and sent it by the two penny post; — nevertheless I will tomorrow early send to Wobourn Abbey the other copy “as a specimen” (which indeed is beautiful) “of the press”, — and I will at the same time explain that it is only a proof, and that the fragment corrected and compleated will be forwarded in the beginning of the week. — Yours etc.

Milord — En vous envoyant ce matin la copie des vers sur la quelle l'imprimeur du M.r le Duc doie diriger son impression, je n'ai pas osé vous troubler pour l'affaire du buste; — maintenant les raisons qui m'ont forcé de vous en parler me harcêlent, et surtout ce soir de maniere a m'obliger bongré malgré de vincre ma repugnance, et je prens la liberté de vous en entraitenir de nouveau, mais pour ne point vous donner la peine de m'ecrire, j'irai demain matin avant midi à Arlington Street ou j'espére de avoir l'honneur de vous voir. Je n'ai pas eu occasion de revoir l'homme qui porta le buste à Arlington Street; je crois neammoins qu'il sera arrivé sauf, — et j'aurai aussi l'opportunité de m'en assurer demain. En attendant, Milord, veuillez bien me pardonner, — ou plustôt de plaindre la necessité; et de me croire
votre très devoué et reconnoissant etc.

My dear Sir — Permit me to offer you my best thanks for your so kindly sending me a corrected printed copy of your beautiful Version of Phanocle's Veil of the Graces. D.r Hunt, who you may remember to have met at Woburn, is the bearer of this, and will talk to you on the subject of introducing this Fragment, or a part of it, into the descriptive work I have now in hand, relating to the Marbles I have at Woburn; and in my return to town in a few days I hope to have the pleasure of seeing you again.
Remain with perfect truth your faithful and obedient servant etc.
My dear Sir — Are we right as to Digammi? Is the passage a quotation?

Your language has surprized me: it has all the raciness of a native. I have not much meddled with you, as you will see: two things, however, I have done. I have in consequence of a regulation made many years ago, and to which I was driven by necessity, avoided the allusion to any ulterior Art. This, you will find, is a matter of no kind importance: and I have rescued his Reverence from a little of your flogging — not from any sense of its injustice, for you are right — but because we had him up already, as you know, in a separate Art. He winced a good deal then, and if we bring him forward again, I should like to do it expressly on the foundation of his own work. — In these days of the “Man of Sin”, we must deal demurely with the persons.
Sincerely my dear Sir, I am very faithfully yours etc.

ps.p: P.S. — If you are right respeting the i, you need not give yourself any trouble. If it be an oversight, let me hear from you as soon as possible, as the Art. is now printing.

div1.p: Mon cher Foscolo, — Je vous adresse un discours où j'ai fait de vous la mention que je devais en faire, au sujet de Parga: faites moi connaitre votre jugement sur cette production, je vous compte au nombre des juges dont j'aime et dont j'estime le plus le suffrage.
Je vous embrasse de tout mon coeur etc.

ps.p: P.S. — Veuillez faire passer l'exemplaire ci–joint au Colonel de Bosset.

div1.p: Dear Milman — Hearing from your friend M.r Harness that you set off on Sunday next, I hasten to send the letters which I delayed in the hope of adding to them the Essays on Petrarch. The edition, however, goes on more slowly than I thought, and you shall have them on your return; — when among those who will hail you, none will exceed me who as an exile am in greater need of friends, and I have found in you one, who affords me the double gratification of loving for his kindness towards me and estiming for his talents and character — Addio — Ecc.

Egregio Signor Foscolo, — Spero che le ricordi d'un giovine, che dal 1814. al 15. fu Capo mastro alla Scuola militare d'equitazione in Lodi, quando appunto il di lei fratello Giulio ne era Direttore; e che di più le ricordi quante volte quel giovine abbia avuto il piacere di visitare lei stessa, abitante allora in Milano presso il Monte Napoleone e d'intrattenersi seco le lunghe ore, e sempre con quella interna compiacenza, la quale è il miglior premio di chi cerchi accostarsi ad uomini di chiaro nome e d'intelletto più chiaro. Ora io, che mi prendo la libertà di scriverle, sono quel giovine stesso, e cerco, non debbo negarlo, di chiamarle alla mente le cose passate, onde in qualche maniera giustificarmi dell'incomodo che le reco, mentre per quanto io mi creda di franco e leale animo, stimo atto scortese o d'orgoglio bassissimo lo scrivere a sconosciuta persona.

Quand'Ella si decise passare da Zurigo al Paese nel quale presentemente si trova, io partii di Lodi per Napoli, ove qualcuno della mia famiglia vive tuttora, e scrissi a Giulio in Germania l'ultima volta; ultima difatti perchè non ho più ricevuto alcun cenno da lui. Il solo Visconti, col quale ho avuto regolare corrispondenza, m'ha dato per circa quattro anni che ho abitato in Napoli, notizie d'entrambi; notizie che ho sempre cercate ed accolte con l'ansietà che mi veniva dal candido amore che mi ha legato al buon Giulio, e dalla riverenza che ho per l'alto di lei ingegno. Partito di là onde riabbracciare mia madre in Lombardia, non ho potuto che toccare di volo quella terra a me cara, e sono venuto sin qui, dove, straniero veramente, non son cognito ad alcuno. Ho però visitato Biagioli, uno egli pure fra' tanti commentatori dell'Alighieri, e venendo, non saprei come, a dire di lei che l'ho conosciuta in Milano, m'ha pregato a salutarla da parte sua. Non so veramente se, o come Ella conosca Biagioli, ma quella sua preghiera m'ha posto in pensiero di scriverle: e mi permetto ora una brevissima digressione.

Forse per indole, o forse per educazione fino da' primi anni ho caldamente amato tutto ciò che ridondava a gloria del mio Paese, e quindi gli uomini, che per altezza d'intelletto e di cuore l'onoravano, m'eran carissimi; e quest'amor mio m'ha spinto per conseguenza a coltivare, per quanto il mio stato me l'ha permesso, le lettere, giacchè questa è l'unica strada che non ci venga precisa. Credo di avere attinto a purissime fonti, ma dacchè la fortuna m'ha fatto rompere il proponimento di starmi celato, sarei caduto in disperazione se non mi confortasse quel «maestri miei» che ho sovente incontrato nell'aurea di lei traduzione del Viaggio di Sterne. E scrivo così, perchè Biagioli mi ha fatto conoscere un letterato, e di que' veramente che scrivono pe' morti, il quale danna senza misericordia qualunque parli a' viventi, o, come credo io, che scriva per la posterità. — Biagioli però sente di lei come sent'io, e tutti gli altri che abbiano sortito dal Cielo qualche inclinazion generosa, e ciò mi fa supporlo uomo d'ingenuo costume e di rettissimo cuore.

Ma per venire allo scopo di questa mia lettera, dal quale mi son forse troppo dilungato, le dirò che mi sarebber gratissime le di lei nuove e quelle di Giulio, e che io la prego a darmele: e che, dappoi che forti circostanze m'hanno condotto in questo Paese, nel quale se vorrò sostenermi converrà ch'io profitti di quel poco di ingegno che la natura mi ha dato, e mi riduca finalmente ad insegnare a chi lo vorrà la mia lingua, se le parrà bene può dirigermi fin di costi col consiglio e con l'opera. Certo è che in Inghilterra i di lei talenti debbono avere quella celebrità che meritamente hanno negli altri luoghi, e che perciò ella sarà conosciuta da tutti, ed ella stessa conoscerà molte persone: certo è altresi che vi sono in Francia moltissimi Inglesi, i quali cercano apprendere il nostro idioma, che se fossero conosciuti da lei potrebbero essere diretti più ad un maestro che ad un altro. Frattanto qui havvi un giovine a cui debbo moltissimo, d'ingegno non ordinario e di rarissimo cuore, il quale già da anni insegna italiano (non in Parigi mentre non v'è da maggior tempo di quello che io vi sia) e in fatto di lingua è in modo perito da fare meglio che altri buonissimi allievi. E a questo giovine potrebb'ella indirizzar qualche inglese, ed essere nella certezza di non errar nella scelta, poichè oltre le belle sue cognizioni, ha il vantaggio anche, come quello che è nato e cresciuto in Siena, di possedere la più perfetta e la più dolce pronunzia della Toscana. Nè creda che obbligo solo di gratitudine, o 'l pensiero che qualunque fatto a questo giovine sarebbe diviso con me, mi faccia dire mezza parola più del vero: ho sempre rispettato me stesso, e stimo tanto Ugo Foscolo che non saprei non mostrargli nudissimo il cuore; e se ella si ricorderà di me e di quello che può averlene detto l'ottimo Giulio, non potrà caderle alcun dubbio su la veracità di quanto le scrivo. Eccole intanto l'indirizzo della indicata persona = Didier Martelli, Rue de Grenelle S. Honoré n. 8 — Paris = .

Perdoni, e su tutto non mi neghi sue notizie e di Giulio. Che se mai le sembro in qualche modo importuno, mi scusi col pensiero, che gl'Italiani non possono in tanta difficoltà di tempo volgersi meglio che a qualche verace Italiano.
Sono con tutta quella stima che gli si deve

ps.p: P.S. — Il mio indirizzo è lo stesso che quello del Sig.r Martelli.

dateline.date: Sale, near Manchester Thursday, June the 6.th 1822.

div1.p:
My dear Friend — If Lady Dacre is still in town you will probably hear from her of my expedition, — and unless death condemn me to dwell for ever near this brutal S.t Giles, alias Manchester, I shall in spite of my bad health haste my return, and I hope to be in London towards the middle of this month. — A friend of mine dissatisfied with this neighbourhood, wishes to settle near Wimbledon, and if I remember right, there was last year a house to dispose of — The proprietor was a naval officer, — and the house was the third or the fourth after yours on the same side. I remember also that they then asked an extravagant price particularly on account of the shrubbery in the back ground. As my friend is willing to buy it out and out, or during a very long series of years, it is probable that the proprietor will come down and accept a reasonable price. Have then the kindness of informing me as soon as convenient to you whether that house is still to be disposed of, and whether you know the name of the proprietor, or his agents in London. I recollect that the woman who last year kept the house told us the name of an upholster who was charged with the selling of it. Direct your letter thus
H. Foscolo
Sale
near Manchester
at M.r Hatfield's —
do not omit the name of M.r Hatfield. My compliments to Mrs. Murray to whom I will before winter pay a visit at Wimbledon — Adieu de tout mon coeur —
Tout à vous pour la vie etc. —
Mon cher Foscolo, — Permettez moi de vous recommander M. Jullien de Paris, fondateur et directeur de la Revue Encyclopédique, et de plus auteur de plusieurs ouvrages sur l'education et la morale.

M. Jullien désire trouver en Angleterre des collaborateurs pour un Dictionnaire Encyclopédique des sciences morales et politiques; personne ne peut le servir, à cet égard, mieux que vous qui êtes lié avec les littératures et les hommes d'état les plus celèbres de la Grande Bretagne.
Vous avez du recevoir par Lord Holland une lettre de moi, avec un discours sur le commerce où j'ai eu le plaisir de vous citer comme vous n'aviez du l'être au sujet des Grecs modernes et de Parga.
Adieu, mon cher Foscolo. Conservez–moi votre amitié.
Je vous embrasse de tout mon coeur etc.

Madame — J'etais las de n'être jamais ni tout–à–fait bien, ni tout–à–fait malade; et sans pouvoir m'occuper utilement de rien, je n'avais pas même la satisfaction de m'occuper serieusement de ma santé; —— une occupation que le Ciel donne a ceux qui n'ont rien autre chose à faire. Cependant mes yeux me menaçoient de nouveau, et plus la saison s'embellissoiet de Soleil, et plus ma vue redoutait la lumiere. L'on ma dit que les eaux minerales de Chatsworth m'auroient fait du bien, — et je l'ai cru, ou plustot j'ai voulu le croire d'autant plus que un amis m'offrit de m'y accompagner. J'ai donc vu l'Université de Cambridge, et les savants Epicuriens de l'Université; — j'ai vu les plaines de Cambridgeshire, et l'idée de l'Infini que leur nudité donne. J'ai vu la triste Comtée de Leicester, et la Suisse elegante de Darbishire. En verité Darbishire semble une miniature de la Suisse, et je voudrais y vivre pendant toute ma vie, car je jouirais de la Scenery sans etre obligé de tollerer le villain caractere des habitants, — et en Suisse il est intollerable, car la villainie est habillé d'hypocrisie. J'aurais preferé Matloc parceque j'y ai trouvé plus de solitude et un auberge qui n'est pas chér; mais les bains sont trop froids; ensuite j'aurais aimé de tâcher de guerir à Bakewell ou l'on trouve un beau jardin, des belles dames demi coquettes, demi malades, de passage, et surtout un excellent prêtre, M.r Hodgson, traducteur de une partie de l'Anthologie grecque, — et surtout a very good whig; je l'aime d'autant plus qu'il aime sa femme, une jolie petite jeune Dame qui semble une Demoiselle; et il est malheureux et il sera encore plus malheureux parceque elle est atteinte d'une consumption avancée, et il doit la perdre à jamais. — Les eaux etant plus efficaces à Chatsworth je les ai experimenté pendant huit jours, et je m'en suis trouvé bien — j'ai perdu les continuelles sensations qui m'assiegeoint nuit et jour d'une fievre lente, et mes yeux pourroient soutenir la lumiere de Juin, aussi bien que celle de Novembre. Je n'ai pas vu a Chatsworth a personne, hormis a ma vieille Landlady, et aux enfants que j'ai rencontré dans les rues; malgré cela je voudrais pouvoir y demeurer pendant un mois ou deux, car soit l'air, soit la nouveauté et la tranquillité, soit reellement que les eaux possedent la vertu de faire des miracles, j'ai recouvré ici ma santé, et ce qui plus est, ma bonne humeur et mes Spirits me semblent être tels qu'ils etoient —
«Quando de' miei fiorenti anni fuggiva
La primavera».
Mais il faut que je retourne au Digamma Cottage ou je dois vivre non plus en Amant, mais en Mari avec la Muse, — et un Mari qui pour pouvoir vivre avec sa femme doit bongré malgré travailler nuit et jour. Et puisque j'etais si près, j'ai voulu voir Manchester, d'autant plus que un ami m'a offert de me loger dans son cottage — Le villain, immense, — oh l'admirable et execrable à la fois — le tyrannique a la fois et a la fois le licentieux S.t Giles! En verité ce n'est pas une ville, c'est precisemment la continuation de S.t Giles: —— tandis que de l'autre coté
«La gente nuova, e i subiti guadagni
Orgoglio e dismisura han generata»
et ce que l'on appelle le Massacre de Manchester ne serait jamais arrivé s'il y avait des Whigs; — mais il n'y a pas même de Torries; il n'y a aucun patriciat, aucune Aristocratie intermediaire; il n'y a que la plus horrible des Tyrannies celle des Oligarches maitres des manufactures qui n'ont d'autre idée, d'autre sentiment que celui de faire fortune en exigeant le plus de travail possible, pour le moins de pain possibile. Milord repetera que je suis un Aristocrat a pendre; mais vos enfants, ou au plus tard vos neveux s'appercevront que la revolution veritable sera tacitement operée par la dêtresse de la multitude d'une cotée, et par la richesse des mushrooms de l'autre. — Demain j'irai a Liverpool ou j'espère de trouver plus d'esprit patriotique, de Marchands moins plebeyens, et si je rencontrerai des Messieurs qui regrettent le commerce des Negres, je rencontrerai aussi M.r Roscoe et d'autre qui l'on fait abolir. Maintenant adieu Milady; je vous ecris à fin que vous ne croyais que je me suis jetté dans le canal de Regent's Park; — vous me verrez Madame de nouveau —
«Che Branca d'Oria non è morto unquanco
Ma mangia e beve e dorme e veste panni».
Je serai à Londres avant le 20 du mois, et j'espere que vous n'aurez pas encore quitté this side of the water. Mille choses pour moi a Milord, et mille choses a la Reine, et au Roi, — et donné un baiser pour moi au petit prince de Trebisonde. Votre devoué pour la vie etc.

dateline.date: Waterloo Hotel near the Lyceum Tuesday 3 o'clock. [June 18th 1822].

div1.p: Signor mio, — Arrivo a Liverpool; e se non in tutto per lei certamente in gran parte per lei; e se dovessi vedere la città solamente, mi pentirei d'esservi venuto; e perch'io forestiere non saprei come trovare indizio della sua casa, nè potrei rimanere qui per più di ventiquattrore, le scrivo pregandola di riscrivermi indicandomi a che ora potrei venire da lei stassera o domattina.
Tutto suo etc.

My Dear Sir — I am delighted to find that you are in Liverpool, and would instantly have waited on you had I been able to walk so far. As this is not the case may I intreat the favour of your company to Tea this afternoon in my small dwelling, to which I and my family are just removed. I hope not to disappointed in this request but if you should be otherwise engaged I shall not fail to call on you in the morning and hope you will afford me as much of your society as you possibly can during your stay in Liverpool.
I am my dear Sir most truly yours etc.
div1.closer:
Lodge Lam Toxteth Park
Tuesday 3 o' Clock
Tea at 6. or soon after.

div1.p: Caro Foscolo nostro — Je vous envoie une lettre d'une belle Dame en Italie a ce que m'en dit Lord Lynedoch qui me l'envoie de Paris, et à qui Lord Bradford l'a remis. — Je viens de recevoir votre lettre de — je ne puis dechifrer — ou —, mais qui me fait beaucoup de plaisir, puisqu'elle me montre le pauvre Foscolo tout–a–fait rémis de ses maladies d'esprit et de corps et que j'ose en augurer des ouvrages de genie qui lui seront d'un grand profit d'une côté, et a nous tous tant que sommes d'un autre. — Je desire vous voir dans votre digamma la plume à la main, avant que les spirits que vous avez rattrappé s'echappent, — et je vais vous proposer une petite assistance — pour la nouvelle du moins. — C'est une personne qui traduira le français pour la moitié de ce que vous avez donné jusqu'ici, et qui ne vous trompera ni ne vous tourmentera pas — Mais je ne vous parlerai de cela que lorsque vous aurez lu la lettre de la belle dame — car la mienne est affreuse et mourante de faim, et vous ne pourrez pas lui prêter votre attention dans le moment. — Lorsque je saurai que vous êtes de retour et que avez le loisir de m'ecouter je conterai mon histoire. — J'ai aussi une lettre que vous fera peur de Mons.r Price — Ce sera aussi pour une autre fois. — Adieu — portez vous bien et tout ira bien. — Etc.

Povero Foscolo — Nous sommes à Londres pour un jour seulement. Venez nous voir demain à midi si vous pouvez, ou Samedi matin un peu plutôt, pour nous trouver avant notre depart. Je ne sais ou nous dinerons demain car nous avons laissé tous nos gens à la campagne — c'est pourquoi je parle du matin seulement. — Je vous parlerai de la traductrice, et vous montrerai ce qu'elle sait faire. — Je vous ai envoyé une lettre hier par la poste — Je ne savais pas alors que j'accompagnerais Lord D à Londres aujourd'hui. —
Adieu

Mon cher Monsieur, — Voici la quatrième lettre que je vous ai expedié, sans aucune reponse ou explication sur «le voile des Graces». La premiere était addressée à Digamma Cottage, South Bank, Alpha Cottages, Regents Park London. La seconde etait recommendée aux soins du Maitre de la Poste, Post office Liverpool. La troisieme avait une addresse plus detaillée, que voici:
To / Ugo Foscolo Esqr
Digamma Cottage / South Bank
St John's Wood / Regent's Park
London.
Et toutes les trois furent affranchi par mon ami, M.r C. F. Palmer, Membre du Parlement. Jusqu'à ce jour, je n'ai reçu aucun pacquet par la Diligence, ou Stage Coach, de votre part, et je ne sçais pas, si je puisse me flatter de l'espoir de vous voir sous mon petit toît à Bedford. Dans une des lettres, j'eus la hardiesse de dire «nil mihi rescribas; attamen ipse veni», ainsi je me flattai: que votre silence avait été causé par la resolution que vous aviez prise, de venir me voir ici, au lieu d'ecrire.

Pardonnez les erreurs, causées par mon peu d'habitude de la langue française et soyez persuadé que je serais charmé de vous posseder pour quelque tems ici: mais, s'il me faut abandonner cette esperance, envoyez moi deux mots par la Poste, le même jour que vous m'expediez par la Diligence du George and Blue Boar Holborn, une seconde copie du Voile, avec l'introduction en prose, dont vous parlez dans votre lettre, de Liverpool, du 13e de ce mois.
Je suis très sincèrement,
Votre devoué et obeissant Serviteur etc.

ps.p: P.S. — Il y a grand nombre de Diligences, qui vont tres regulièrement de Londres a Bedford, tous les jours. Celle que je prefererai [....] The old Bedford Coach, qui part du [....] and Blue Boar, Holborn. —

div1.p: My dear Sir —— That fellow Graham has gone off and I am placed in a dilemma in which I fear you will share, no translation, nothing done, and his fate unknown to me. One of his accustomed visits to the gambling houses I suppose has involved him in inextricable trouble; whatever the cause may be, he leaves nothing but his talents at translation to be regretted by either of us — I fear however your disappointment in different things you have in hand will be great — Translators such as you need are difficult to get but I trust you will not be long without one — I will make every enquiry for a substitute sur le champ —
I am My Dear Foscolo Yr very fay etc.

Caro Foscolo — Je vous envoie la lettre de Mr. Price — vous demelerez aisement les gentillesses qui me regardent d'avec les raisonnements qui sont pour vous. — Je crois vraiment qu'il y a du bon, car il m'a fait comprendre un peu de quoi il s'agissait — Renvoyez moi la lettre avec trois mots pour le pauvre vieux homme. Lord Dacre ira a Londre mardi pour 3 jours. — Je resterai ici avec la famille royale de Trebisonde. Qu'avez vous fait de ma pauvre Madlle Ker? — Vous portez–vous toujours bien? — Et travaillez vous comme forçat? — Adieu — Toujours à vous etc.

Egregio Sig.r Foscolo, — Sul ragionevole dubbio che una lettera, scrittale il 1.mo dell'ora scorso, sia andata smarrita, approfitto dell'occasione in cui il Sig.r Gerosa di Milano si reca a Londra, onde farle pervenire con sicurezza la presente. S'io potessi darmi a credere che quella mia lettera fosse arrivata sino a Lei, non seguirei certo a scriverle; ma poichè quel dubbio, se ho riguardo al carattere ch'Ella ha sempre mostrato, deve essere certezza per me, così la prego a scusarmi se le tolgo qualche momento di tempo.

In quella mia io le diceva, per richiamarmele alla memoria, d'essere stato Capo Mastro alla scuola d'Equitazione in Lodi allora che il di lei fratello Giulio n'aveva la direzione; le diceva che un legame intimo d'amicizia m'ha stretto a Giulio medesimo, finchè la partenza di questo per l'Ungheria ci divise; e che più volte, s'ella ben si ricorda, io era venuto a visitar lei stessa in Milano abitante allora presso il monte Napoleone, e d'aver goduto le lunghe ore della sua urbana accoglienza e conversazione. Le parlava di Giuseppe Visconti di Lodi, e concludeva chiedendole sue notizie e pregandola, giacchè la fortuna mi stringe a sostenermi in Parigi col dare lezioni di lingua italiana, a voler dirigermi, se il caso le si presentasse, qualche signore inglese che avesse caro d'apprenderla: preghiera ch'io le rinnovo, e che, spero, non andrà vuota d'effetto, questa lettera venendole immancabilmente alle mani. Che se io le reco qualche disturbo me ne tenga per iscusato, e l'attribuisca alla volontà d'occuparmi, onde non esser tacciato d'indolente e di meritevole della disgrazia. V'ha quel nostro proverbio che fa dire a Dio stesso «ajutati, ed io t'aiuterò» e non le parrà strano per conseguenza ch'io abbia ricorso ad uno de' più celebri nostri Italiani, che per buona ventura ho avuto il ben di conoscere —

La signora Giuditta Pasta prima cantatrice da lei conosciuta costi mi dice di salutarla, ed io lo fo volontieri, nell'atto stesso che, pregandola nuovamente a scusarmi e a darmi qualche suo cenno, mi dico ammiratore verace del di lei ingegno, e pieno di stima e d'affezione per l'altre sue buone qualità.
Umil.mo e devot.mo servit. ecc.

ps.p: P.S. — Il mio indirizzo è questo: Rue de Grenelle S.t Honoré N. 8.

div1.p: Dear Sir, — As I am now building a cottage and I believe that the stoves of the two drawing rooms at the Alfred are set up after the most convenient plan, I take the liberty of requesting you to allow the bearer to look at those stoves, and you will add thus one more reason for the gratitude to which your repeated kindness has bound me to you. Forgive my bad English, and believe me dear Sir —
Your very sincerely obliged etc.

Foscolo nostro — Ma cousine me dit que l'Eveque fait le tour de son Eveché pour confirmer les jeunes gens etc., et ne sera pas de retour chez lui de quelques semaines; ainsi je ne veux pas attendre son consentement, mais je vous envoie le Stance d'«Italia» comme je le trouve mieux moi même. — J'ai fait une petite marque de crayon aux mots que j'ai changé pour attirer votre attention. — La derniere ligne est plus près de l'original sans epithete pour le ciel, et je n'ai deja que trop d'epithetes, à cause de notre langue monosillabique. Dans la ligne antipenultime j'ai mis just, parceque fair n'allait pas bien avec ce fairer qu'on trouve deux lignes plus haut. — Dites moi si vous êtes content, et dites moi en même tems ce que vous savez de la malheureuse protegée de Mr. Young. — Adieu — Portez vous bien —
Votre amie etc.

Caro il mio Gino, quanto fratello — Il S.r Eyre Crowe gentiluomo Inglese viaggia a fare raccolta di documenti e notizie per una opera periodica, e voi potrete ascoltarlo e ajutarlo senza riguardi nè scrupoli da che egli non è scrittore di parte politica, nè gli studi suoi tendono se non se a pura e innocente letteratura. Non potrà stare a lunga dimora nelle diverse città ch'ei deve pur visitare a ogni modo; però quanto più le vostre cure per lui saranno pronte, tanto più le parranno cortesi. E se voi li conoscete, fate ch'egli pure conosca i vostri Editori di opere periodiche, in guisa che possa intendersi, e far cambio di mercanzia; e i vostri vi guadagneranno, e impareranno. Ma più che mai vi prego di procacciare al S.r Crowe alcuna lettera per gli uomini letterati di Roma, e di Napoli, dov'io non saprei a chi raccomandarlo. Or addio. Mille e mille saluti a Niccolini, e più di dieci mille alla cara Quirina ch'io abbraccio con tutto lo spirito, e tutto il cuore —— Addio —

Caro Grassi. — Il S.r Eyre Crowe gentiluomo Inglese viaggierà a raccogliere documenti e notizie per un'opera sua di cui vi parlerà, e voi potrete ascoltarlo da ch'ei non è scrittore di parte, e gli studj suoi non tendono che a pura ed innocente letteratura. E perch'egli non potrà stare a lunga dimora nelle diverse città d'Italia, le vostre cure per lui saranno tanto più cortesi quanto saranno più pronte. Ed egli ed io ve ne saremo gratissimi. Or addio da tutto il cuore —
L'amico vostro ecc.

Ugo mio. — Perchè io ti scriva, nè che cosa abbia a scriverti quasi non lo so, e se non fosse che mi parrebbe villania il lasciar partir di qua M.r Milman Isenza dargli un verso per te, me ne sarei stato in silenzio. Che dove sarebbe necessario un caldo, e lunghissimo sfogo, le poche e aride parole di una lettera fanno peggio, e a me non trovano la via di fuggir dalla siepe de' denti, che prima di poter versare una parte dell'amaro che ho nel cuore avrei bisogno di pigliar forza io stesso, e di sollevarmi fuori di quest'aria impestata che si respira. E tu che puoi non vedere le cose nostre, fai di non udirle neppure, e non aver mai un momento di rammarico per esser lontano da casa. che non è più casa per nessuno: wim 8'poep nóAeµo; yXuxtov (e visaan. Di me saprai da M.r Milman tutto quello che vi è da dirne, per quanto mi abbia veduto due volte sole. Cioè che io son grasso, e rubicondo, e malinconico, e diacciato, e inerte. E tu che conosci i Fiorentini, e li Italiani tutti, e l'indole della tirannia, che ci circonda, e la dolce paternità, che ci pervade tutti qui in Toscana, capirai bene come queste cose stiano insieme, e unite ti faranno sì che io ti serva di esempio di ciò che siamo tutti in questa sentina. Il Velo è come me tale quale, salvo che egli è più contento di me nella sua vita presente, e più lieto di speranze cocciutissime, nelle quali egli è tanto fisso, che schernirebbe anche l'inferno dell'altro mondo con tutta la sua eternità. Figurati quanto abbiamo gridato intorno a ciò: egli è stato qui a passar meco tre mesi l'inverno scorso, ma benchè mi abbia fatto rabbia tal volta col suo far rose di tutto quello ch'ei tocca, pure mi ha fatto del bene, per allora, benchè poi si sia rimasti tali quali amendue. Nè io penso punto a uscir di qua, che già non potrei per la famiglia, e poi ho perduto l'animo, e l'intendimento per cui viaggiava. Nè in Inghilterra potrei tornare per ora, «Noµœr, Tpãog, xx) TP C, e specialmente le belle ragazze inglesi, delle quali non potrei soffrire il sogghigno, o il tacito vitupero annesso ai bruttissimi nomi, che io porterei meco dal paese di dove escirei. Ma non più di queste brutture. Fa' che io sappia di tanto in tanto che cosa tu lavori sicchè io possa leggerlo. Mandami se puoi, e vuoi la visione di Didimo, che mi promettesti fino da Londra. Io ho dato a Milman qualche libruccio. Se me ne soccorrano altri che tu abbia a vedere te li manderò. Qui la letteratura Italiana non è altro che pettegolezzi, o viltà, o ciancie da collegiali. Addio. La Quirina non ha avute da un pezzo tue lettere. Ama il tuo ecc.

My Dear Friend — I have just returned from M.r Wilbraham's villa, and as I find the Mss. Castruccio has been on my table since Monday, I hasten to inform you that I received it, and that I will send it to you — and my opinion with it — on Monday next without further delay — Will you be so good as to get a frank for the enclosed which is directed to a schoolmaster an enthusiast of the Digamma? Addio —
Ever yours etc. —

Dear Foscolo, — My father desires me to give his compliments to you and to say that he is waiting for your Italian verses for his book. It is his opinion that you might give the verse now and it would be printed alone. As for the prose and the requisite translation he hopes you will come to Woburn to meet D.r Hunt, when it can be settled much better than by letter. D.r Hunt is uneasy at its being supposed he had the presumption to think of translating your verse — he only meant the prose.
My father will be at Woburn about the 20.th he leaves this on the 18.th pray send your letter to him or me to S.t James's Square and put in it “to be forwarded”.
Yours truly etc.

Dear Friend — I read the whole of the first volume; the story although slow, sometimes heavy and often tamely told, is yet entertaining as far as I read it; and as novels generally increase in interest towards the middle and the end, I have no doubt but the second and third volumes, of which I only perused several pages at random, will be more interesting, especially to those readers who derive great source of amusement from a number of complicate incidents; — a method of composition which is by no means congenial to my taste — but there are readers of various descriptions; and whilst I cannot go with patience through a long series of events, others cannot like me wander with attention in the labyrinths of the human heart. As I in novels prefer strong passions, others prefer wonderful accidents; still, provided the novels, though of different description, be entertaining, we are all in the right. — The hero of this romance has been also the hero of a very small romantique biography written by Macchiavelli, and intended for political purposes. The readers already preoccupied by the character of the Macchiavellian Castruccio will hardly yield their imagination to this a Volterian one; such readers, however, in all probability are very few, and the less they are acquainted with the ancient manners of Italy, the more they will like the novel; and what for an Italian is a glaring falsehood, appears a very credible fact to an Englishman; — and the book is intended for English readers. Perhaps too even on this account I am an hypercritic as I have a strong avversion to novels founded on characters and facts which having become the property of history are already to be known as not to admit any fiction. Either the reader of the novel is acquainted or unacquainted with the real history; if acquainted, the inventions of the novellist do not carry any illusions with them; — and if unacquainted, the unlearned reader is deceived by fictions on a subject with which he could be more usefully amused with historical truth. But what is a fault in my eyes, has been lately made by the Author of Kenilworth, a very popular merit; and in this respect also my criticism should not be depended upon. In the romance of Castruccio the general out–line of the history of the fourteenth century appears to be correctly drawn; but I do not find the peculiar characteristics of he age so well delineated. The personages act in the scenes that eally passed, or in all probability might had passed at that period; but they think and express themselves as our contemporaries. I suspect that the historical facts have been sought for in Sismondi and other similar historian; the novellist therefore could not avoid seeing through a metaphysical Telescope. Had the author perused the old Italian chronicles only, they would have enabled him to draw his characters with much less anachronism. He would also have avoided some impardonable errors, as when in a note speaking of the Prince of Padua he calls him Signor Messer Francesco. Would it not be ridiculous for an Italian to write Mister Sir Walter Raleigh? — However these and other mistakes may be easily corrected, and if the novel be printed, I will look on the proof sheets to atone for the severity of my criticism. Yet I am writing every word of this letter under the double anxiety of endangering the interest either of the publisher or of the Author; and I am the more perplex in my judgement in as much as many novels of which I could not get through half a volume — as for instance the Corinne of Madame de Stael — have been read — throughout even by M.r Hallam! — and from the few pages in a different handwriting which precede the novel of Castruccio I perceive that it has already deserved great admiration, as an exhibition of passages of fervent imagination, original thinking, and energetic execution. All this may be true for those who are more capable of feeling the beauties of the style and language of which I can be an incompetent judge; — and as it is through the language only that facts and descriptions reach the imagination of the readers, my little acquaintance with the real merits of English composition made me write in the beginning of this letter that the narrative is rather diffuse, without either energy or warmth. So I think still; without however thinking that my opinion is right; but were I to give you my oath I would say that the Author of Castruccio is far from being either a common or an extraordinary one; — and were I to guess and wage I would say that the Author is a she — Author. — Adieu.
Your grateful affectionate friend etc.

Après un aussi long silence vous serez sans doute surpris mon cher M. Foscolo de revoir encore de mon écriture. Mais depuis longtems je desire infiniment savoir ce que vous devenez et quoiqu'il ne me soit pas profitté dans la vie d'hermite que je fais a present d'entretenir des correspondences suivies, je serois très fâchée de perdre de vue mes amis pour toujours. Dans la liste de ceux là vous savez bien que vous avez toujours tenu une place des plus distinguées et que j'ai toujours attachée le prix que je devois à votre amitié. Ce sont là des sentimens sur lesquels le tems ne fait rien.

Ecrivez moi donc et dites moi ce que vous faites, ce que vous pensez, avec qui vous vivez, enfin tout ce que vous interesse. Tout sera du plus grand interêt pour moi et dites moi je vous prie quel est l'etat de mon pauvre ami Lord Glenbervie. Je sais qu'il a été très malade et je ne doute pas que vous ne le voyez souvent. C'est un homme pour qui j'ai un veritable attachement et par conséquent il m'est impossible de n'être pas fort inquiete dans un cas comme celui ci.

Quant à moi je me trouve très bien de ma solitude. Si je pouvois de tems en tems voir un petit nombre des personnes que j'ai quittées, je ne desirerois rien de mieux que ce que je fais aujourd'hui. On me dit que vous cultivez les fleurs. Venez me donner des avis là dessus. Elles sont ma passion et j'en ai beaucoup.
Adieu écrivez moi.

Dear Foscolo, — I do not know whether you will take it as an intrusion that after such an interval without any communication between us, I venture to apply to you in favour of the bearer, an Italian officer, who has been recommended to me by one of my dearest friends in Spain. But though my health has not allowed me the pleasure of much intercourse with you, I know too well the kindness of your heart to fear that you will not decline to do whatever may be in your power in favour of an Italian exile. M.r Sismondi is I understand a great master of his sword and could give lesson of fencing. Perhaps you may be able to recommend him for that purpose among your friends. My Spanish friend give him a high character on every respect. I have already introduced him to Lord Holland.
I was very much pleased with your article on the Digamma. I wish we were nearer knot I might have the pleasure of seeing you; but my health continues too bad for any exertion.
With the most sincere esteem believe me Dear Foscolo
Ever your truly etc.

My Dear Murray — M.r Clowes sent to me on Saturday a bill of L. 166. 7. 6. for 1000 copies of the unpublished, and indeed unfinished work on Parga. Possibly some of the items are overcharged, but whatever they may be, I am in justice and in equity obliged to pay M.r Clowes. — The less I mentioned you this illfated book, the more I felt the necessity, whilst I saw the impossibility, of publishing it. Some persons surmised, and possibly many may still believe it, that I was bribed by the English Government to suppress such a work. On the other hand King Tom asserts through his secretaries to the honest editor of John Bull, that I am here at the head of a Committee in the pay of Russia to excite both the English and Greek radicals against the paternal administration of the Jonian Islands. These calumnies affected me less than your interest and that of the translator, — for, besides my own labour and expenses, the impression and translation are to be paid, and by all laws of justice by me; — but if it were absolutely impossible for me to meet these claims, the loss would fall by the laws of necessity on you. The publication of the work would have defrayed at least these expenses, and at the same time it would have proved that no government minister or kings have any claim of gratitude upon me, and that they excite in my mind no other sentiment than compassion which greatly partakes of contempt. Yet other and stronger considerations arising from circumstances which happened while I was writting the work, opposed themselves to its pubblication. I availed myself of the curiosity and interest excited by the cession of Parga throughout Europe in order to state a series of facts authentic enought to show in full light the nature and consequence of the new international law. The revolution of Naples coming unexpectedly at the very moment I was completing my narrative added new facts to illustrate and strengthen the arguments on the Holy Alliance with which I intended to close the book. I therefore enlarged my plan, but to ascertain the events then going on in Italy it was necessary to wait, — but in a very short period the fall of Naples contributed only to consolidate the Holy Alliance and discouraged me from continuing my work. Not that I was afraid to attack a bad system because its first application had been successful; for I believe still an everlasting peace cannot exist among men; and the contrivance of a confederacy of kings to keep all human institutions, and all political constitutions always stationary, is contrary to the nature of things and the tendencies of mankind; and while such a confederacy does exist, the nations will wage either an open or silent civil war with their kings. But I have supported my arguments upon documents containing names and statements which, if published after the last revolution, would undoubtedly lead to prison several individuals. Before the tragicomedies of Naples and Piedmont, people were rather persecuted, and never without proofs or at least some appearance of proofs; but now such is the policy of terrorism adopted by the Austrian Government, that the most inoffensive persons are on the slightest suspicion and without trial thrown into the jails. To this peril I should have exposed those friends who having formerly acted as public men would be easily and not unjustly suspected of having furnished me with the original pieces; — to this I may add the danger of my brother, who is constantly detained in Hungary, apparently with a military commission, but in reality as an hostage. Those who accuse me of a timid silence, and impute to me the most base and self interested motifs, are certainly ignorant how often I think of the Philosopher Bayle whose writtings in Holland against the despotism of Louis XIV, caused his own brother to die in a prison; but my own philosophy is not so highminded as to make me think that I ought to sacrifice my dearest affections to the very improbable liberty of the Italian slaves. — I have then, as for my book, chosen the expedient of leaving out all that I inserted concerning Italy, and thus I returned to my original plan of speaking only of Parga and Greece. But in this very plan too, to present some unity of interest by engaging the attention of the reader to an extraordinary and celebrated character, I had adopted Ali Pacha as the hero of my narrative, — and the new circumstances in which he found himself soon after his having taken possession of Parga, favored and at the same time delayed my work. The general outcry respecting the sacrifice of the Pargiotes, and the intrigues of some Ambassadors induced the Porte to believe that Ali had the English Government to support his ambition; and this jealousy at last induced the Sultan to come to the resolution of dispossessing Ali of his conquests. Hence Ali resorted to the extremity of calling upon the Greeks to become an indipendent nation, — and this was in fact the most efficient, although the least noticed among the causes which produced the present situation of Greece. The long siege sustained by Ali, — the struggles and repeated attempts of the Pargiotes to recover their City, and in the end the tragic catastrophe of the Hero of the Ottoman Empire, would have increased the interest, and completed the history. But to prevent history from degenerating into romance, it was necessary to be assured of the facts which I heard related in so many different ways that I dare not adopt them without previously collecting such information and documents at to justify my statements of the latter events in Albany. But at such a distance, and with the certainty that all letters are opened by the Police of King Tom, it is now impossible to separate the false from the real circumstances of the end of Ali. I still hope that at some future period the publication of this history will procure me some ounces of reputation and some pounds of profit; and it will be found very interesting, if not for our contemporaries (whose curiosity about Parga and Ali is already exhausted) at least for posterity. The time however is still remote, and the printer after two years credit has every right — and perhaps he is also in the necessity — to insist on the immediate payement of his bill. — I know that I trouble you with too many details; but from a delicacy, which I ought to respect, you declared that you would remain ignorant of the contents of the book until its publication; had you perused what has been already printed, and particularly the documents in the Appendix you would have known my reasons for the delay without been doomed to read my long explanations, — which are now necessary to satisfy you that I have not relinquished my task from caprice or idleness. — Still the delay did arise from me alone, and the loss ought by no means to be yours. But as my circumstances are infinitely too limited for this debt, and even for my subsistence, I must either contrive some means to insure me a year of labour in quiet and indipendence of mind, or to renounce every expectation for the future. I have a plan in contemplation which suggested itself to my mind the moment I received M.r Clowes's bill; and the more I reflect upon it, the more I am convinced of the necessity and the practicability of it. — Now you must repose after such a long reading,— and pour surcroit de malheur in such a bad handwritting; — Then I entreat you to read the second volume of this letter of mine with attention.

First of all I must be at least free from the humiliating cares of my subsistence, and of my debts. During six years (for I landed in England the 12.th Septemb. 1816) I have constantly laboured under difficulties the most distressing; and no one knows them so well as yourself, because no one came to my assistance with so warm a friendship, or with cares so constant and so delicate. My difficulties have become more perplexing since the government both of the Jonian Islands and Italy have precluded even the possibility of my returning to the countries where a slender income would be sufficient, and where I would not be under the necessity of making a degrading use of my faculties. I was born a race–horse: and after near forty years of successful racing, I am now drawing the waggon, — nay to be the teacher of French to my copysts, and the critic of English to my translators! — to write sophistry about criticism, which I always considered a sort of litterary quackery; — and to put together paltry articles for works which I never read. Indeed if I have not undergone the doom of almost all individuals whose situation becomes suddenly opposed to their feelings and habits, and if I am not yet a lunatic, I must thank the mechanical strength of my nerves. My nerves however will not withstand the threatenings of shame which I have always contemplated with terror; Time and Fortune have taught me to meet all other evils with fortitude; but I grow every day more and more a coward at the idea of the approach of a stigma on my character; and as now I must live and die in England, and get the greater part of my subsistence from my labour, I ought to reconcile if not labour with litterary reputation, at least labour and life with a spotless name: I will cease either to be harassed by the fear of infamy, or to suffer life which never had any attrait for me, unless when my faculties and feelings were at liberty to exert themselves. Now not only my faculties, but also my life are mortgaged to my creditors, within the six years I am here, I contracted debts which may be calculated at L. 100 per annum; but in the L. 600 are included the L. 167 due to M.r Clowes and also L. 160 for the loan and interest of a sum advanced by Mess.rs Harries and Farquhar on my security to four Italian refugees who landed in England last year in a state of utter misery, and being unable to exist here, embarked for Spain, leaving in my hands three bills for L. 50 each, to be paid by their families. Now if your reason overpowering the dictates of your heart accuse me, circumstanced as I am, of having acted rashly in becoming responsible for them, I would intreat you to consider that when ones friends are starving in exile, and when they are strangers to every body, they must be some way or other supported — and that their presence here without being less expensive to me, would have made their situation and mine still more irksome. The first bill for L. 50 was duly paid. — But the Austrian government proclaimed it high treason and the banker Ciani having escompted and payed the bill was arrested and is still in a prison. I am not afraid of losing that money; yet the uncertainty whether it shall be paid in time makes me very uneasy, — and I am bound in honour to pay it to Mess.rs H.s and Farq. at the end of October. I have also to pay towards the middle of next month L. 130 which were sent to me unasked and unexpected by M.r Foresti during my long confinement for some months, first by an attack of rheumatism, and soon after by a fall from a horse. I declared him before accepting his kind offer, that while political circumstances obliged me to live in this expensive country, I could not promise him the payment of the loan; — he assured me that he would never consider it as a loan, and would be satisfied by being repaid at my return in the Jonian Islands; I gave him a Memorandum for the sum, which he absolutely declined accepting. He was then, and he is still carried away by the hope which will be always disappointed of being appointed in London Chargé d'Affaires of the Indipendent United States of the Jonian Islands, and in the affair of Parga he took the part of Ministers, and went so far as to threaten the enforcement of the Alien bill against the two defenceless deputies, whom he described to Lord Castlereagh and to several Members of Parliament as two impostors whose credential were forgeries planned in London. My duty to the oppressed overcame my gratitude to M.r Foresti, and I was obliged to prove that he had mislead the government, or an acceptance at any date for the sum of L. 130 — My answer was, “that as I could not pay him immediately, I would sign a bill because the danger to which he thus exposed my character and my personal liberty relieved me from the heavy burden of considering him as a friend”. This bill is becoming due at towards the 10th of next month, — and I should be the most miserable man in existence, were I again forced to be obliged to him for his forbearance.

Thus the money which I owe to M.r Clowes, to Mess.rs Harris and Farquhar, and to M.r Foresti amount to L. 457. — and a remaining ballance of my account with Mess.rs Bentley for the first edition of Petrarch, with L. 20 owed to you, and other small bills make the total sum of L. 600 or thereabouts. I must also remunerate M.r Merivale for his masterly translation of the history of Parga; and I must then have by me the money necessary for my subsistance during at least twelve months. After many different experiments in oeconomy, I find I cannot live on less than L. 400 per ann. — If the sum seems extravagant for a man in my circumstances, it is but moderate for a man of my age, of my former habits, and now obliged to unremitted study and to almost solitary confinement. I can cheerfully undergo other privations; but my dwelling which is always my work–house and often my prison ought not to distress me by appearance of misery, and I confess in this respect I cannot be acquited of the imputation of extravagance. By my purchasing occasionally pieces of furniture, I have perhaps laid out in this way since I am in England the sum of L. 1000. Still they are things, which if not absolutely necessary are very useful to a man of domestic habits, they are enjoyed every moment by myself, my friends, and my servants; and if they were sold, the money expended on them would not be altogether lost; indeed without a good deal of furniture I could never have let my house of Wigmore Street, at L. 5 per week until Michaelmas when I will be rid of the lease. My apartments decently furnished encompass me with an atmosphere of ease and respectability — and I enjoy the illusion of not having fallen into the lowest circumstances. I always declare that I will die like a gentleman, on a decent bed, surrounded by casts, as I cannot buy the marbles, of the Venuses, of the Apollos, and of the Graces and the busts of the great men; nay, even among flowers, and if possible while some graceful innocent girl is playing an old pianoforte in the adjoining room: and thus dies the hero of my novel. — Far from courting the Sympathy of mankind, I would rather be forgotten by posterity, than to give it the gratification of ejaculating preposterous sighs because I died like Camoens and Tasso on the bed of an hospital; and silice I must be buried in your country. I am happy in having insured for me the possession during the remains of my life of a cottage built after my plan, surrounded by flowering shrubs, almost within the turnpikes of the town, and yet quiet as a country house, and open to the free air. Whenever I can freely dispose of a hundred pounds I will also build a small dwelling for my corpse under a beautiful oriental plane–tree, which I mean to plant next November and cultivate Con Amore. So far I am indeed an Epicure; — in all other things I am the most moderate of men. I might vie with Pythagoras for sobriety, — and even, (in spite of my enthusiasm, for Beauty) vie even with the great Scipio for continence, whenever love must be bought.

Now my prospects depending chiefly on my literary exertion, — and being unable to study amidst daily anxieties, I hope you will approve of the plan I have devised, not indeed as the most desirable, but as the only, and the undesputable one. To pay the L. 600, and to subsist during twelve months it will be necessary for me to have L. 1000 —; but as I cannot guess what profits the novel might bring, or how many articles may be inserted in the Quarterly, I cannot borrow this sum but the condition of repaying it in five years, at the rate of L. 200 a year. I should pay the interest of 5 per cent, and in order to secure the principal I would insure my life in the sum of L. 10000. I should then altogether borrow at near 8 per cent interest — but the sum of the loan would be decreasing every year; and when the whole debt has been discharged, I shall have gained the advantage of having paid five years of the insurance which I mean to continue that I may be able to die without fear of being cursed by some creditor, — and that I may also leave some small legacies to my friends in England. —

In order to pay the L. 200 a year with the interest and the insurance, I shall always leave in your hands half of whatever sum you may allow for my writtings; — the other half added to my personal income (which by the bye I have already received for the whole of the present year) will be sufficient for my support. I am aware you think that I do not at all times finish my intended works; as indeed several things I meant to publish which remain still half done. But if you consider that besides the discouragement arising from depending on translators, my mind has been almost night and day distracted always to death, and that I often composed under the pressure of cares and the anticipation of additional misfortunes, perhaps you will even wonder that I could preserve fortitude enough to exert my faculties during a single month. — As to passive Fortitude it is not a difficult virtue; but when the Fortitude must be active it has first to fight against the sense of actual sufferings, and the prospect of threatening distress; and let even the victory be obtained, the mind having been already exhausted by this previous struggle, cannot apply to study with all its natural powers. However, I write with amazing rapidity, yet I am distressed by my own exuberance; thus even in my less unhappy days I could never send my manuscript to the press as so on as transcribed; nor do I consider any page worthy of being read until it has been deliberately rewritten. Immagination must produce, and taste polish: the former is ardent wild and extravagant, — the latter is cool, prudent, and oeconomist: no writting can last without the combination of imagination and taste; but they cannot, as I have long experienced, work at the same time. So I write the whole of a volume in a fourtnight, and I rewrite it during two months to condense it in a few pages.

However my progressive proficiency in your language enables me now, and will every year enable me still more to depend less on my translators; — and having already not only collected the materials, but written the first draughts of several papers intended for the Quarterly, I could, if M.r Gifford allow their insertion, supply with an uninterrupted series of them several of your ensuing numbers. I would not make such a proposal, had I not been assured by you of the favourable reception of my articles. — As for the novel, the whole is written (warmly I dare say, — and perhaps too, originally written) but partly in French, partly in Italian, according to the translators I had in contemplation, and I also wrote a portion of it in English; and as style and language are the principal requisites in a novel, I cannot pledge myself of its being ready for the press before five or six months. If the experiment be successful I will submit to the trade of providing amusement for the idle: I cannot expect to acquire the fortune of your great manufacturer of novels; still I may enable myself to purchase a small annuity and devote the latter part of my life to more honourable and useful work. — Now, as my determination depends on your answer, if you assent to help me to this plan I may be tranquil for sometime, and perhaps happy for many years: in the contrary case I must speedily take the steps most effectual to deliver my mind from what I consider an approaching disgrace. I should prefer receiving the sum through you rather than from you; and this for many reasons; at all events I cannot rely for it on any one but yourself. Still under any circumstances, nothing shall induce me to depart from the conditions I have proposed, to which I add that I will leave in the hands of the lender or yourself the sum of L. 457, for the discharge of my three greater debts; and I will receive as money M.r Clowes's receipt, — my note to Mess.rs Harries and Farquhar, and the bill of M.r Foresti which will be presented when due to any banker may be appointed. The balance of L. 543 should be paid to me in the following proportions — L. 243 at the commencement of September in order that I may discharge several small claims, and settle in my cottage by purchasing with ready cash the fixtures which would be infinitely more expensive if purchased on credit. — The remaining L. 300 should be paid to me at the rate of L. 25 per month for 12 Months, from the first of the ensuing October to the last day of September 1823. — Thus, if after six or eight months I should not have earned enough to liquidate the first part of the loan, and to pay interest with insurance of my life, there will remain a ballance to supply the deficiency from the residue of the loan itself. I am sure you think these provisions and restrictions upon myself, as calculated to convey the idea that I distrust even my own honor. But honor and conscience, if overpowered by necessity, are firelocks which, although made of excellent materials, become rusted and useless for want of ammunition. In seeking out a way of salvation I think it incumbent on me to prevent the tyranny of necessity that I might not be compelled by it to endanger my character and the interest of a friend whose Kindness I have always experienced and whose assistance I am obliged once more to solicit.
Maintenant Adieu. Do not trouble yourself to write an answer; the task of reading this letter is heavy enough: appoint a day and I will call upon you. — Adieu —
Your grateful friend etc. —

Farò pregare il Sig.r Milman di ricambiarvi questo foglio, e così ve lo rimando senza averlo neppur veduto. Egli ha avuto giudizio di non curar di conoscermi, dacchè sono da gran tempo una persona morta, e di percorrere rapidissimamente il mio paese, per non rammentarne che la terra, e il cielo. Io non avrei potuto farne meglio gli onori con quest'uomo sapiente, che facendolo presentare dal mio Sigismondo agli uomini dotti e alle signore amabili di questa città, e voi buonissimo Ugo che conoscete le mie circostanze questo solamente chiedevi da me. Ma il Sig.r Milman ha fatto le sue cose senza di noi due infelici, de' quali altri non ho a dirvi, se non che il povero Sigismondo sostiene nobilmente la sua sciagura, ch'egli è sepolto in carcere e ch'io lo sono nel mio dolore. Addio. Vivete felice, sano e amico nostro. La Fulvia.

div1.n: 2693. Della sorella e del nipote (22 agosto 1822)
div1.p: Mio fratello — Scorso è ormai un anno che priva mi trovo di tue lettere. Non è nuovo è vero questo tuo silenzio, ma cessato il motivo che ti credevi obbligato a tacere molto più riescemi mortificante. Nel mese scorso di marzo hai pagato una cambiale di venti zecchini che io ti ho pregato con una mia lettera di pagare, ove ti pregava di assegnarmi il tempo che meglio ti comoda giacchè io trovomi in necessità di farti tratto tratto tali rimesse, nè tu mi hai dato segno di vita. Le tue nuove le ho è vero per vie indirette: ma non sono queste che mi assicurano il tuo amore. Per i primi del prossimo settembre ti spedirò la solita cambiale di venti zecchini, così si combina il semestre, come ti scrissi con la ultima mia. Tu sei il padrone di pagarla e non pagarla: nè io vanto diritto alcuno delle tue sostanze, ma solo mi rivolgo al mio fratello, tanto benefico verso della povera sua sorella. Il fratello mi somministra la solita pensione di lire trenta di Milano: sarebbe moralmente impossibile che io mi avessi potuto sostenere senza altro soccorso; il buon nostro cugino Naranzi mi ha sempre soccorsa, ma sarebbe ormai tempo di sollevarlo di simile peso: che se tu ti trovi al caso di assistermi in continuazione conviene sollevarlo assolutamente. Quello che ti raccomando si è di scrivermi il tempo prefisso: se ti comoda anche da anno in anno che ti rimetta una cambiale di venti zecchini io mi contento. Bastami solo il sentire la tua volontarja approvazione. I tuoi soccorsi in questo anno mi sollevarono dal poverissimo stato al quale mi trovava. Ho supplito a tanti bisogni per mio figlio, dal qual figlio spero un giorno il compenso de' miei sacrifici, ma che ora mi obbliga a delle spese e per la decenza del vestiarjo e per i libri giacchè lo studio si rende tanto necessarjo e senza del quale non può arrivare alla carriera ecclesiastica alla quale aspira. Ti raccomando di nuovo a scrivermi. Quanto io ti sia grata a' tuoi benefizi lo sa il cielo, il quale prego ti dia la ricompensa: ma il tuo soccorso unito al tuo silenzio mi fa mangiare il tuo pane misto di amaro avvilimento. Addio. Mio fratello l'Angiolo doveva per i quindici del corrente partire da Vienna per portarsi in Boemia. Sopra tutto scrivimi come ti trovi in salute. Addio. Tua sorella ecc.

ps.p: Stimatiss. zio — Colgo la favorevol occasione che mi si presenta onde darle con queste due righe un sincero pegno della mia gratitudine a tanti suoi beneficj, e del mio non poco affetto verso di lei. Ciò pello scorso anno scolastico non ebbi il piacere di fare, attesochè mi ritrovava in Seminario, in cui per quanto fu in mio potere mi son dedicato con tutto l'impegno allo studio della Theoretica Filosofia, unitamente alla Geometria, ed alla Greca Favella, rimanendomi ora quello della Pratica Filos. della Fisica, prima di entrare nelle scienze Teologiche, nel corso delle quali dovrò ancora occuparmi nello studio del Greco e dell'Ebraico Idioma, esigendo così lo stato Ecclesiastico che mi scelsi, ed a cui a mille brame aspiro. Frattanto le rinnovo i miei sentimenti, protestandomi di cuore.
Di Lei Umiliss. ed Obblig. servo e Nipote Pasqual Mollena Chierico.

div1.p: Dear Foscolo, — J'ai reçu votre lettre avant hier seulement — Je ne suis ici que pour un jour, autrement j'irais vous voir a Southbank. J'ai reçu encore hier une lettre de mon pere me priant de vous dire qu'il espere vous voir a Woburn — que le Docteur Hunt et M. Westmacott y seront Lundi prochain et qu'il vous engage d'y aller le même jour — je vous prie de repondre a lui meme a Woburn. Je conçois bien que cette histoire magique de votre ami vous ait travaillé et l'esprit et le coeur — encore c'est une raison pour vous distraire un peu a la campagne. Si vous avez fini votre prose italienne vous pouvez la porter avec vous et D.r Hunt la traduira mieux que cette main dont vous m'avez envoyé un echantillon. Les vers paraitront en italien seulement sans traduction.
Pourquoi je vais demain a Tunbridge Wells —— je vous prie de m'y adresser un mot pour me dire si votre maison de Wimpole Street est a louer encore.
Votre devoué etc.

Mon cher Monsieur Foscolo, — Depuis que j'ai eu le plaisir de vous voir à Londres, j'ai été serieusement malade, et dans ce moment je ne suis qu'a peine convalescent; mais je serai très charmé de vous voir ici. Je sais que vous avez eu une correspondance suivie avec le Docteur Hunt, et mon fils, au sujet de votre Ode sur le Voile des Graces, et le Docteur m'a communiqué les malheurs qui vous sont arrivés concernant le paquet, que vous lui avez addressé. — J'ai prié Lord John de vous engager à venir à Woburn le commencement de cette semaine; vous y trouverez le Docteur Hunt, qui vous montrera ce qu'il a déjà écrit sur les Graces, et je vous avoue franchement qu'il me semble inutile et superflu, d'avoir une traduction de votre bel Ode Italien, en Anglais, qui ne saura jamais rendre les beautés et les graces de vos vers. La Description de mes Marbres n'est pas pour le publique, mais seulement pour mes amis, et les savans en littérature; et assurément la grande majorité des lecteurs de cette ouvrage, sauront apprécier la finesse de la langue Italienne.
Faites moi le plaisir de venir ici le plutôt possible, car Mons.r Hunt sera obligé de me quitter avant la fin de la semaine. Agreez je vous supplie, les sentimens de mon estime.

Caro Amico — Siavi raccomandato il Sig.r Hatfield amico mio ch'io stimo ed amo per molte sue doti, ed al quale io vivo e vivrò sempre riconoscente per infinite cortesie verso di me. Viaggia per acquistare salute, e per istruirsi; benchè s'ei fosse sano quanto è dotto avrebbe poca necessità d'uscire di casa sua. Amatelo anche da che ei torna in Italia non per fredda curiosità, bensì per amore del bel paese. Un mal di capo da più ore mi toglie la forza e la vista da poter tenere la penna, e neppure posso dettare.
Addio dunque da tutta l'anima
L'amico vostro ecc.

Caro Cicognara — Vedi che al S.t Hatfield, dotato di più ingegno e sapere che forse non ti parrà conversando, sieno aperte le biblioteche sì private che pubbliche tanto ch'ei possa vederne le curiosità e le anticaglie — Lucietta mia ti mando un bacio da vecchio. Etc.
