div1.p: Dear M.r Murray, — I forgot to send you yesterday a copy of my terms, as some may question you; but you need not trouble yourself to enter into particulars; let any person apply to M.r Andrews, — I also forgot to tell you that as the security of the lease will be very probably declined on account of its legal invalidity, I will offer the insurance of my life, for L. 600 = of which I may ripe some benefit even after my death through my executors. — M.r Cohen told me that he borrowed money on his life insurance; — but I am afraid that what is very easy for others to do, will turn out to be almost impossible for me — Yet today I am relieved from the headache — Adieu
Yours faithfully etc. —

Dear Sir — M.r Murray had the kindness to tell me that he will pay to you on my account the £. 30 which had already become due, and for which, if I have not been harrassed, I owe it to your friendship and forbearance; accept therefore my sincere thanks; — and if you either present, or send this very note to M.r Murray, I have no doubt that he will settle with you for this sum, and of which I shall be indebted to him —
Believe me, Dear Sir, Your very sincerely obliged etc.
div1.closer: To M.r Richard Bentley Dorset Street Salisbury Square —

div1.p: Read this note first and act accordingly without delay. Without even looking at my longer note, do give orders to Mess.rs Bentley that the Essays be published as soon as possible; — some circumstances reach my ear in this very moment, which send me to the conjecture that a portion of the first private edition might have been appropriated some way or other in an article on Dante about to be published in Blackwood magazine. — Yesterday showing Lady Dacre's last revisal of the cancels, as soon as brought here by the postman, were sent without a moment's delay to Mess.rs Bentley; — so they may freely print off.
Adieu again — etc.

My dear Sir, — Suffer me to express the greatest respect and admiration at the mind which has produced the essays I read and have just finished reading — Their characteristics are, in my apprehension, criticism that no English writer could pretend to cope with — philosophy expounding criticism and the highest poetical sympathy illumining both —
Do not suppose me intrusive in these opinions. I am carried away by impulse and speak only what I feel strongly.
pgs 40–1–2 — pgs 82–3–5 — 88 — a little passage you pointed out — the splendid philosophy of 171–2–3 — and the acute criticism of such passages as the last of p. 178 —
Here are points in which I caught most quickly the spirit and [...] of the writer.
The translation, after about 25 pages, is admirable — first glowing — sincerely — with none of the trait of translations in general.
Meantime if you think fit I could direct your attention to a press error here and there which it would be a pity to overlook —
When you shall have received the Essays again will you permit me to proceed with them?
Believe me, my dear Sir,
Yours obliged etc.

My dear Sir, — You will oblige me by again lending me the commentary on Dante for a day or two, I wish to show it to a friend. I am collecting a few notes on opera for you: you will find in the Spectators, Tatlers and other periodical works of that day, observations of the effect the opera then had: and the reasons pro, and con. There is also something in Burney's and Hawkins' History of Music.
I send you a Hare, part of the produce of our Pope.
Yrs always etc.

div1.n: 2766. A Samuel And Richard Bentley (? gennaio 1823)
div1.p: Dear Sir — I now send you the rosewood table, — and the bearer will tell you how it ought to be kept clean — I send also the drawers of the library table with their key. Pray do not forget the characters, — and if instead of a professional compositor, you can recommend to me a youth who should be satisfied with light wages for light labour, I should be more obliged to you —. I should also like, nay prefer to have a professional compositor every other day to whom I would willigly pay for the three days fifteen shillings. Adieu — dear Sir, and believe me
Ever yours sincerely obliged etc.

My dear Friend, — Since I called twice in vain upon you, I must submit only to write as I can in good and bad English, but also to give you the trouble of decyphering one more of my usual long notes. — I learnt yesterday at Albermale Street that no list has been delivered, although I sent it a week ago by the same footman who got the two copies for Liverpool; — and the fellow must have forgotten it in his pocket; thus I enclose it again, bitterly complaining at the same time of the misery of depending on occasional Messangers. What follows is still a more serious occurrence. — A gentleman proposed to me to write a Review on a new translation of Virgil by a friend, (as I am told) of M.r Gifford; thus M.r Simon (the translator) is pretty confident that the Review will be inserted in the Quarterly. The delicat part of this proposal consists in the suggestion which was repeatedly given to me “that the Translator intends to pay for the Review” — which implies that they will purchase praises; these, poor as I am, I will never submit to sell; — I answered, therefore, that being obliged to have a translator, I must expect an exorbitant remuneration, and I pointed out a gentleman who could do as well, and for the half of my price. I think it proper that you be informed of this conversation; — an information, however of which you will awail yourself with discretion. — Lord Dacre, and others are of opinion that if instead of giving Lessons, I were to give Lectures I would with less labour and more honour be soonner relieved from my embarassements. Lord Dacre seems to be almost certain that I would easily get more than two hundred subscribers at five guineas each for twelve lectures from Easter to the end of June. To my objection that I could not deliver lectures unless in my maternal language, he answered that the persons who are in situation to pay for admission are, (or wish to be consider so) Italian scholars. There is, however, another objection, namely the repugnance I feel to do any thing which in my apprehension looks like a quackery; thus with all the strenght of my nerves, and my former habits of speaking in public, I fear that there is a wide difference between feelings of a speaker, sorrounded by his own countrimen, for fame, and of a lecturer before a fashionable assembly for money. Yet if you and M.r Hallam think that this plan is likely to succed I will submit to the experiment, as soon as I am assured that the Essays on Petrarch have been successfull; for in case of failure of the book, I could not depend on many subscribers to my Lectures. — At all events I must take a decisive step and without farther deliberations advertise either for lessons or for Lectures, since while I am projecting for the future, I am every day more and more threatened both with dangers and infamy by the present. Lord Dacre having thoroughly considered the matter of the leases, decided that to prevent information and forfeiture, they ought to be speedily destroyed, and the possession transfered on trust; but even this, as things now stand would be impossible for me, on account of the expenses for the legal acts and new deeds of the transfer. To get out at once I was until now negociating with the builder to have returned the money I paid him, and give up to him the rent of the next cottage, and the property of this I inhabit, and continue to keep it as a tenant at will, at L. 80 per an. I would thus be at great loss for the future, but relieved from the horrible present; and the bargain was so advantageous for the builder that he promised to do his utmost in order to raise money, and thus kept me in hopes which are still disappointed; and he now begs two or three months delay which, if granted by me, would ruin me both for the future, and the present.

I return Orloff's work on Music. I read it throughout, with loss of patience and time, as it only affords for my purpose the title page to be placed at the head of the articles. If tomorrow the weather be not as dreadful as to day, I will call and look at some translation of the Atys of Catullus and borrow some lines to describe the curious Monstrum of our singing Eunuchs, so as to preserve Virgins and Matrons from the double trouble of guessing and blushing. “Oh, my dear Sir, I was oftenly told, Decency is every thing, you know!» —— My whimsical W.S. Rose is in town with plenty verses and prose for you, and as I engaged, and indeed I am very willing to revise the proofs of his translation, have the goodness to order your clerk to forward them to me in small several parcels by the two penny post. Now Adieu —
Ever yours sincerely obliged etc.

Mio caro Amico — Mi duole assai che l'amico mio Hallam v'abbia parlato e richiesto di ajuto per la malavventurata faccenda delle due Lease; — egli me ne avverte ora solamente; chè s'ei me ne avesse preavvertito l'avrei pregato di smettere il suo progetto, e l'ho scongiurato oggi di non farvene più parola; e prego anche voi, mio caro amico, quanto più so e posso di non parlarne a Lord John Russell, da che Hallam mi dice che sì fatta era la vostra intenzione. Non vi pensate più, ve ne scongiuro; io troverò forse altra via d'uscire de' guai per mezzo di avvocati e gente d'affari, — e ad ogni modo Fata viam invenient; ma il più grande de' guai per me consiste nella afflizione e nelle noje ch'io reco agli Amici miei; e quanto sono più affezionati e generosi tanto men devo turbarli, — e meno che meno in questi tempi scabrosi per tutti. Mi affretto dunque di scrivervi affinchè dimentichiate il progetto di Hallam, e non ne facciate motto a Lord John. Nè per voi nè per Lord John è bisogno d'aggiungere beneficj; la mia gratitudine vivrà quanto avrò vita ed anima. Addio di cuore.
L'amico vostro — etc.

My dear Friend —— I should have called on you for the bad weather and the almost impassable roads, which, as I am not a great walker, turn me back home with the wish rather to go to bed than to write — Have the goodness to direct your clerk to send the inclosed parcel to the Hoo by any stage coach — I sent it yesterday evening to Chesterfield Street, but nobody answered the door. I have drawn up the prospectus for the lectures, and you shall have it on Thursday morning, even ere I know Lord Dacre's opinion to whom as the chief manager of the Speculation I submitted the outline of them; — and indeed I should let you have it even now, were not I distressed for a Copist. At the same time I am nervous at every letter delivered by the postman, and tinkling of the bell; — and since all my endevours to escape through a mortgage or a sale from these torments of Hell have been of no awail, I must have recourse to you. The list in your hand contains debts already become due; and am now receiving intimations from lawyers; do therefore what you can; — and so soon as I am a little out of this situation I shall do what I ought. As for the generous intentions of M.r Hallam and M.r Wilbraham, no man could feel more gratitude than I do; but believe that neither H. and W. will agree as to the mode, nor possibly myself; if as I apprehend the money was to be given in the way of a gratuity, which would be neither honourable to me, nor indeed necessary, since I am certain that my own means will be, before the end of the year, equal at least to my wants. Thus I hope that if you do for me what you have done for M.r Belzoni, and friendly agree to become the Administrator and Trustee; both on your and my behalf, of whatever products may come from my exertions, I shall have the double satisfaction of more easily reimboursing you within a twelve months, and being indebted for my present redemption to you alone. Look therefore at the list and do what you can. Here you will find a letter from my builder, — whose credit of L. 50 is returned in the list as becoming due on the 22.d of this month; it appears however that I ought to have pay sooner. I will therefore receive it as a great favour if you could send to him a draft before evening, as the credit of the poor man is at stake, — and in case your messanger does not find him at home, M.r Davis will undoubtely send the bill receipted to you, — as you shall have all the bills mentioned in the list, that in case of my sudden death, you may have a claim upon my little property; — but I shall not die so soon, since I have survived to so many blows during the last three months. — I want only six months time, provided they be six months of tranquillity, and then will be able to get at least the Fatal twice three hundred pounds which con tinue to distress my soul to death. Of the first L. 300, you have already paid L. 30 to Mess.rs Bentley, — L. 33. 7. 0. to M.r Kelly, — and L. 14 to M.r Antonini; and if you pay to Davis L. 50; I will remain in urgent want both for the daily claims, and the daily subsistence of L. 170. As for the other L. 300 which are due to the two banking houses marked in the list some expedient also if not equally prompt, is equally necessary in order to obtain a respite at least of six months; and in this I cannot succeed, without a proper security which owing to my awkward lease I cannot offer —
Now Adieu in great haste. Your grateful friend etc.

Caro amico — Il Sig.r Eyre Crowe mi ha recato jeri la cara vostra del 29 luglio 1822; vi ringrazio della buona memoria, che conservate di me, e del piacer grande che mi avete procurato col farmi conoscere questo garbato, ed amabile gentiluomo. Egli mi ha trovato pieno d'acciacchi, e ancor travagliato da una lunga e funesta malattia d'occhi, che da otto mesi in qua mi ha costretto a cessare da ogni lavoro. So d'avervi mandato per via del librajo Murray una copia de' miei Sinonimi italiani, appena usciti alla luce nel 1821, ma non so se gli abbiate ricevuti. In ogni caso il Sigr Crowe ne ha una copia per voi. Accoglietegli come solete le cose del vostro amico lontano. Io non potrei dirvi con parole la consolazione che mi danno le lettere vostre, nè il mio mal umore quando passano gli anni senza che me ne venga pur una. Ricordate nell'animo vostro, mio caro Foscolo, che io sono tenacissimo nelle mie affezioni, e però quella stessa amicizia, che a voi mi univa, quando aveva il bene di vedervi, è, e sarà sempre quella a malgrado d'ogni distanza di tempo e di luoghi. Se la Provvidenza vorrà una volta darmi pace, o qualche sollievo, altre cose ho in pensiero di stampare, e sopra tutto la continuazione di questi Sinonimi, che mi sta a cuore. Se avrete via di mandarmi le cose vostre, mi farete un raro favore: già sapete che posso legicchiare l'inglese, e che posso capire, se non sentire, quello che viene scritto in quella lingua.
Il traduttore Leoni ha posto alla luce il primo canto dell'Iliade da lui tradotta: il primo verso è il vostro: vedrò degli altri.
Addio, mio caro amico, amatemi come fate, e credete che nessuno v'ama e vi stima più di me, che sono tutto vostro ecc.

ps.p: P.S. — Vi mando gli affettuosi saluti del Marchisio, del quale voi vedrete una tragedia.

div1.p: Mio caro Amico — Troverete qui annesso un prospetto di Letture; e il pensiero di leggere a un'adunanza di soscrittori mi fu suggerito da Lord Dacre e da altri. Nè io ci avrei difficoltà se non questa unica di leggere in lingua Italiana ad Inglesi; il che mi sa di ciarlataneria, e quanto più m'avvedrò che gli uditori non mi intenderanno, tanto più perderò animo, perchè bench'io sia nato coraggioso, anzi ardito, anzi imprudente nel resto, la vergogna mi fa vigliacco: pur s'ha da appigliarsi a tutto, e soffrire tutto per evitare la vergogna maggiore e l'inumana ingiustizia di non pagare i proprii debiti; — e l'uomo stretto da' debiti non ha neppure la libertà di morire. Però, se avrò soscrittori darò le letture; Voi, mio caro Amico, leggete il prospetto, e consigliatemi — Addio dal cuore — L'amico vostro — ecc.

My dear Sir —— I have much pleasure in requesting your acceptance of a Copy of the “Engravings and descriptions of the Woburn Abbey Marbles”, as a trifling mark of my Esteem, as well as an acknowledgment of the kindness with which you have contributed to give an increased value and interest to work.
Believe me always with mine regard
Your very faithful Serv.t etc.

Mio caro Amico — Certo, il librone fu mandato a voi, per voi; primamente per gratitudine alla vostra biblioteca, — che mi fu sempre utilissima
“E sempre si ridica
Come pur m'era amica.”
Inoltre le bellissime cose hanno da stare fra bellissime; ed io pover'uomo ho da contentarmi di libri tali che possano servirmi non come ornamenti di studio, ma come ferri di bottega; — e sì bella edizione conservata con amore da voi si guasterebbe forse presso di me: — finalmente m'era caro che voi leggeste le mie poche pagine, e i versi miei su le Grazie in quel libro, care e belle deità ch'io cessai di cantare da che Napoleone, e l'Austria, e la Fortuna m'hanno dato in età provetta ad essere educato sotto le lezioni, e le battiture delle disgrazie. Godetevi dunque e serbatevi quella edizione ch'io destinava a voi prima di riceverla, — e che mi fu doppiamente cara e per chi me la diede, e per chi doveva accettarla da me; — E fate anche che la vostra nipote — la più giovane (Anna) riceva la copia del Petrarca destinata a lei, e che vi manderò tosto che avrò qualche errand boy, al quale io possa confidarla. Addio dall'Anima. — Addio.
L'amico vostro ecc.

Marvellous Foscolo — I have read your translation from Ariosto over and over with fresh wonder. —— The ease and flow of the lines are superior to what any of nous autres translators have attained. — I have put a pencil mark to every stanza meaning “excellent”, and a little additional mark to lines peculiarly happily render'd. — The cross signifies a mis–point, or a doubt of the passage. Two or three of these I have turned otherwise in my mind, but I think it too impertinent to offer any thing of mine to such a translation, so I only put a X to attract your notice to the passage. Two or three of my marks I will explain, as they only refer to trifles of idiom. —

You see how I have sifted and resifted every line and word, and picked a quarrel whereever it was possible. — Du rest doubt not my admiration and astonishment at such a translation of a foreigner, and in a particular style of english poetry. — You have given also an antique air to the language without hunting after obsolete phrases in an affected manner. It is easy harmonious spirited and every thing one can wish. So thinks at least your humble admirer and friend
B. Dacre who would be very proud if she had done it. Lord Dacre admires your translation as much as I do. — My pencil marks may be easily effaced, and are only meant for yourself. —

The review of your book in the literary Gazette is very favorable to our lectures. — I am well pleased with it. I am sure our lectures will answer our wishes but I must take the management of your money into my own hands, I believe, or you will give it all away in elegant presents to us Ladies young and old. —

Dear Foscolo — Your translation is quite astonishing. It has the perfect ease and flow of an original, and has also what I consider as a great merit — extreme closeness to the italian. There are two or three mere trifles which I will point out when I have considered them more, and notwithstanding the warning you give thro' Lord Dacre, I shall work and scratch like a little terrier after a rat to find faults, for I cannot bear to be thus beaten black and blue with my own staff. — You also write English prose not only correctly but beautifully — Never write me another word in french for your life, I so greatly prefer your English. We are delighted with the prospectus of your lectures, but Lord Dacre will tell you how much we object to the publishing and giving copies of them. It would swallow up all the profits, and must not be thought of. I will write again, and play the critic with all the airs and graces becoming so important an office. I must now take my leave, and mount my beautiful horse to go from home for a day —— Adieu wonderful Foscolo
Yrs sincerely etc.

Dear Foscolo, — I send you the promised stationery. I am very much obliged by yours remarks — I would not have left out the Fà di se bella e improvvisa mostra for five guineas. I am also much flattered by the opinions of your critic whose sex I suspect, but whose judgements I do not less appreciate on that account. Some of the passages objected to I have altered and some that I have not altered, are left because I do not know (after long study, not now first bestowed) how to correct them. Thus; I acquiesce in the objection made to Bonnibal; but there is I fear no such word as damisel or damasel the proposed amendment, in the language. The critic but found out one very grievous omission in my translation, the omission of pietà or some equivalent in the version of the line
Che di PIETÀ potrian ferrnare il sole.
I shall be very anxious for the honor of the critic's acquaintance, if I do not already know her.
Most truly yours etc.

ps.p: P.S. — I am sorry that you should have so unnecessarily plagued with typografical errors such ad he for had salcon for falcon andren for Arden etc. etc. Ho perso il frontespizio della prova che voi mi avete rimandata. Ve ne accludo un altro: ditemene il vostro parere e fatemelo riavere col mezzo del latore.

div1.p: The enclosed proofs I received by the two penny post only yesterday Febb.y 21 — after I delivered my note to your man —, and wrote you that I should call today; which however I cannot do having a parcel of things legal oeconomical and litterary on hands; — Adieu donc until Monday; — By the bye I cannot conscientiously say I am quite satisfied with the Introduction of the Innamorato ; — It appears to me rather laboured and the poetry runs more fluently than the prose. But I am, possibly, wrong. Adieu — Do not delay sending the enclosed for Rose's considerations of my marginal notes. — Adieu encore. — Ever faithfuly and gratefuly yours etc.

ps.p: P.S. — Before sending my letter to Rose pray do read it; — Adieu —

div1.p: Madam — With my full and perfect convinction that I might die suddenly, and all the dread of the disgrace which a sudden death should inevitably cast on my memory, I have been so busy since Saturday last, that I could not spare half an hour to answer your letter; — for, let us suppose that I should have died without having made the Declaration “That the Poetry so higly admired, and so kindly criticised by Lady Dacre was not mine” — certainly no orator's power and sophistry could have disproved that I was an Impostor. I must, indeed, have expressed myself in my letter with so foolish an ambiguity as to lead your Ladyship to believe that I was the wonderful author of the translation. Misterious I intended to be; for I send you the proof sheet without asking the Author's consent for whom I was anxious to get a competent and impartial criticism; still I witheld his name pour menager son Amour propre should your Ladyship have pronounced a less encouraging opinion on his undertaking; and now I am bound to confess that I returned the proof sheet with the observations extracted, but transcribed by me alone from your letter, without however mentioning your name — and as he must naturally be very curious and eager to be acquainted with his critic, I intimated to him that his curiosity will never be satisfied before I find an opportunity to introduce personally the happy translator to the generous critic, and the generous critic to the then happier translator. In the mean time, I will continue blushing for the usurped praises extorted by my ambiguous letter, — yet, how could I have imagined that I poor pupil of your language should have been even regarded as the author of such poetry? The awkwardness, however, of my situation after your mistake through my fault is partly compensated by my vanity since such a mind as yours has thought me capable of such a performance — and partly — I should say chiefly, — by the enlogium deserved from you by the oldest of my English friends, who is also one of the least happy and yet merriest men in this world. I trust therefore that upon these considerations your Ladyship will forgive my blunder, — while on account of your forgiveness my gratitude will become warmer (if indeed any thing warmest can ever be warmer). I intend to send at the Hoo in the course of the week a parcel of copies of the Prospectus which is now at the printer's, and from which in compliance with the wise advice of Lord Dacre, I expunged the condition of printing the Lectures. Neither this condition (for I too possess my portion of wisdom) originated from me, — not, in truth, on account of prudential anticipations, but because I am convinced that though learning, industry, and Genius may compose as many books as there are weeks in the year, still Time alone by virtue of its unremitting and experimental improvements can bestow on writings the magic power necessary to resist the ravages of Time itself. — With regard of your kind offer to become the Banker of the subscription, I had already devolved the management of it on M.r Murray whom I also furnished with a list of my creditors that they may be satisfied à fur et mesure the money is paid in Albermale Street; and I am certain that in case our job of the Lectures produce one thousand pounds, and I can at the same time be delivered from the nets of the Alien law and attorneys concerning my cottages, I will in point of money live and die in Santa Pace; I would not venture to say “in point of Ladies” since you, Ladies, have an Attorney General at your service — a devil with flesh and bones, and yet invisible, full of cunning, sophistry, special pleadings, — and fears, whom you call Love, and a boy too, but who really is an old Devil without mercy of old men like me and Bouverie. Be so good as to remind me to Milord for whom I will prepare a letter with a paper to be submitted to his consideration; as I cannot write another letter at so late an hour for the already singing bell of the postman. Adieu donc Milady — and congratulating you and my little volume for all the past, present, and future, printed and talked over, and all well deserved praises of the translation from Petrarch, I entreat you again to forgive my English prose, and never to imagine that English poem whenever it goes beyond sixteen lines, can be attributed to me poor fellow!
I remain your's faithfully and respectfully etc.

ps.p: Extract from the letter of the real translator — The opinion of your critic by whose opinion I am much flattered, but whose judgement I do not less appreciate objected to many passages which deserved to be altered; and I have altered them; and the few that I have not altered are left because I do not know (after long study, not now first bestowed) how to correct them. Thus I acquiesce in the objectJon made to Bonnibel, but there is not I fear no such word as damisel, or damoisel in the language. The critic has found out a very grievous omission of Pietà — an omission which deserves no mercy.

div1.p: Mon cher Foscolo, — J'ai reçu avec un grand plaisir la lettre que vous m'avez écrite par M. Jullien. Je vous remercie beaucoup de votre dessein de rendre compte du discours que j'ai écrit sur l'influence du commerce. Je serai extremement flatté de cette marque d'estime et d'amitié donnée par un homme tel que vous.
Je pourrai de temps à autre vous donner quelque article pour le journal littéraire que vous projettez: informez moi de l'epoque, où vous commencerez à le faire paraitre.

Quelles sont les belles choses que vous faites maintenant? La littérature de toute l'Europe est interessé à vos travaux; et si l'on se plaint à votre égard, c'est que vous ne fassiez pas assez promptement jouir le public de tous vos trésors.
Adieu, mon cher Foscolo,
Je vous embrasse de tout mon coeur etc.

Foscolo! Foscolo! You have done me an irreparable injury! You have stamped me the odious thing, a blue Lady. Now next to having a good hand on a horse's mouth I pique myself on that ignorance crasse which is so anti–blue. — Finding I had made the mistake of thinking you the translator, you should have burnt my remarks, knowing I could not have meant them for any other eye — Believe me, I would not have done what I did for any other person but yourself. — Adjured, as I was, by your irksome labours in the Price case, what could I do but criticize à toute outrance the little trial of your strenght which I imagined you sent me? I fancied from the great secrecy enjoined, that you might not be pleased with Mr. Rose's translation, and had tried a passage yourself, and why should I doubt your ability now to do this, after the lines to Calirhoe two years ago? Indeed why should I doubt your ability to do any thing except to become wise? — On reading over your first letter I have discovered how I made the mistake. — I read the word prayers”, pages. — Now had I imagined the Stanzas an Englishman's one great'object of my admiration would have disappeared — namely the perfect ease and english ear with which they are written. (Nota–bene — Yours to Calirhoe have those qualities as well). — I should as soon have marvelled at Mr. Rose's perfectly english pronunciation of English — but if you were to make an english oration in which no foreign accent could be detected, of course we should crier au miracle. I do not mean to dispraise the translation. I think it excellent, but no longer wonderful. — I know Mr. Rose a little. He has met you at our house I think, but if you tell him it was I who criticized his lines I can never look in his face again. — I had endeavour'd to trans[late] the passages I did not quite like, myself — the «per pietà» for example — how glad I am I did not send my attempts! — To you I could say any thing I might think of your works — for you I would do any thing in my poor little power, because I am sure of your indulgence and of your candor — besides you are so powerful to be umbrageous, but to pretend to criticize the work of a regular established english poet! I might as well tell Sir Tho' Lawrence how to paint portraits, or Chantrey how to make busts. — If you ever tell it was I, I will swear it was Lady Beaumont or Lady Davy, who are established blues, and cannot be bluer by it.

We are in high spirits about our lectures, but Mr. Murray rather differs with Lord Dacre, I believe, about the printing. — My idea is, that if the lectures should be well understood and liked, you might make a fresh bargain for the MS of them. — I am all for the money you see. ——
And now I must take my leave the room being full of visitors. Adieu poor Foscolo — I remain no less your humble admirer than before ——

dateline.date: by Pickford & Co who have a warehouse Solitude of Sale in Paddington tomorrow (Saturday) 27 Feb. 1823.

div1.p:
My dear Sir — As I promised, I take the first opportunity of sending you such roses as have multiplied with me. Some of them are very good ones, ancf will, I make no doubt, flower beautifully with you: it is not of roses, as of the fairer things, that we can way nimium ne crede colori, for that is with me their most dilect attribute.

I am now going to trouble you, if you will not think it irksome, to send me word whether that cottage next to you is yet unlet; and if not, would wish you to rent it for me, for a year, if it would be had for 2 guineas a week furnished: indeed I should not require furniture for the study, having my own canary wood.

I am arranging my affairs as first as possible, and think that by March 25 I should be ready to enter; I should wish only to preserve a few of my choicest plants in the garden, as Sale will be sold this spring, and it is so uncertain when a permanent situation may be found.

If you should know of any other small house more detached near that situation, exercise your own judgment, only let it be day, and if possible erected on principles a little more Palladian than the other with the serrated top.

I have projected a ground plan of a beautiful villula which I think might be executed in brick for 2000 L. but Taños Geëv kv yodvoot westor questo top fatto così mi fa vomitare. Once more desiring news at your first leisure, believe me sincerely and cordially your friend etc.

My gratitude for Your Grace's present is enhanced by my pride in having contributed to a monument of your patronage of the fine art, and of the elegance of your taste — And I hope that Your Grace will not think it impertinent on my part to praise the Descriptions of Wouburn Abbey since I'd offering my respectful acknowledgement I entreat Your Grace not to consider my opinion as dictated by the idea that Your Grace stand in need of approvation of the world, as I know that the pleasure of protecting whatever is noble and beautiful is the only reward to which naturally sought for by a mind like that of Your Grace —

Dear M.r Murray — I have been and still am so busy with my writtings, that I can scarcely find time to walk even in my room; — since I engaged to forward the open–paper to M.r A. before the end of the next week. But I will call on you to–morrow without the least doubt, — and give you the copy of my letter to M.r Andrews, stating only matter of facts to which he will not dare to plead but guilty. I wrote the letter to him, and kept a true copy witnessed by a transcriber, — because who knows what may happen, and what reports may go abroad against me? — In the meanwhile I enclose a letter from Lord Dacre concerning the lectures. I have not received any proofs of Rose's Ariosto, after the second sheet, of which I had two copies; — the one I returned by the twopenny post; the other I send now to you — I find the translation admirable, — and some body whose opinion you hold in high estimation wrote to me wonders about the few stanzas I transmitted — without however naming the Author, nor indeed the subject. Be so good as to send the inclosed to M.r Wilbraham your neighbour — and forgive my scraps — as they are done by a pen and hand writting from seven o'clock —
Adieu de tout mon coeur — Yours ever — etc.

Dear Murray — After you have done with the magnificent Gallery I let it by carried to M.r R. Wilbraham Stratton Street, — in the meanwhile have the goodness to forward the letter to him in which I inclose a copy of the prospectus, — Hallam and Rose had it, — and you will find yours in the annexed parcel with the proofs of Ariosto, and my opinion about the specimen I perused of the translation. — Again Adieu de tout mon coeur
Ever yours faithfully, etc. —

ps.p: Memorandum —
Let the bearer have the 4 copies of the Ess. on Pet. for Paris.
My dissertation is at the end of the volume

div1.p: My dear Friend — Here you have the prospectus of the lectures; — and as I have sent a copy of it to M.r Hallam and to M.r Rose, they will be so good as to suggest us the alterations it may require before being published — I compared last night the original about a score of the 41 stanzas contained in the proofs which you will find here enclosed; the truth of the translation both in the letter and spirit, seems to me to be preserved to a scruple; — but having now read over the whole of the sheet, I often wondered at the beautiful versification, which sounds more like an Italian than an English one — And at the poetic warmth and boldness which indeed I little expected in Rose'style, whose prominent features I until now considered to be wit and elegance. The last nine stanzas, from 33 to 41, are admirable, but more particularly so the 34th I did not meddle with the typographical error, — and I have noticed one only stanz. — 40. The names of the warriors are altered, as I believe, on purpose, — and, I have not doubt, for very good reasons; — Thus Agramante Agrament — Ruggiero–Rogiero — Marsilio–Mercilius — Bajardo–Bajordo; — But I am not pleased to find the Hero of the Poem called at one time Roland and at another Orlando Adieu —
Your's most sincerely etc.

Milady — J'avais cacheté, et j'allais dépecher une long lettre à Milord, — lorsque je recois votre Foscolo! Foscolo! et les cris de terreur au nome de bleu. Je vais donc ouvrir la lettre pour Milord, et à fin de la rendre moins pesante pour les droits de la poste j'ajouterai à cette–ci deux papiers imprimés que je vous prie de lui remettre, — et je me hâte de vous repondre pour vous faire revenir, s'il est possible de la frayeur causé par ma faute. J'ecris en Français, Madame, parceque je n'ai pas la force de exercer l'attention dont j'ai besoin pour m'exprimer en Anglais devant un Hypercritic tel que your Ladyship; je suis faible et etourdi comme un petite fillette, — depuis hier que un medecin ami de M.r Murray me rencontrant avec assez mauvaise mine, me examina d'après les regles de la faculté, me trouva avec la fievre, et m'assura que sans une dose puissante ecrite en son latin, j'aurais été condamné au lit pendant une semaine. Ainsi il ecrivit son latin, et un des commis de Murray alla achêter la dose puissante qui me retournera en santé demain peut–être, — mais aujourd'hui sans doute me tourmente et m'opprime dix fois plus que la fievre et la bile qui m'affligeoient depuis quelques jours; — mais l'on ne m'accusera point de refuser les bons conseils pas même des medicins auxquels en general je ne prête pas boucoup de foi. Quant au bleu le nom, et le ridicule en appartiennent aux personnes qui affectent plus de savoir qu'elles n'ont, plus de Genie qu'elle ne possedent, et qui se melent en fait de savoir et de Genie plus qu'il ne conviendrait à leur sexe, et à leur education. Mais lorsque le savoir se laisse entrevoir sortant d'un esprit qui s'en est nourri, et qui apprecie les beautés et les fautes non d'après des regles pedantesques, mais par la force d'un sentiment profond du beau, dans ce cas, Madame, le sobriquet de bleu ne sort que de la bouche des sots dont les sages rient — et en ont pitié; car les sots seuls, et pour cela il faut être sot en meme tems et stupide, resistent à l'influence de la flamme et de la lumiere qui eclatent du Genie; et le Genie provoque l'envie, mais jamais le ridicule. L'on peut bien rire de Mrs. B— et de Lady D— parceque elles etalent instruction et Genie et en font parade comme dans un Shop Window, pour l'admiration des passans; — de pareils savantes sont non seulement ridicules, mais ennuyeuses, — du moins pour moi, et comme je ne puis pas meme en rire, je les evite, et lorsqu'elles me cherchent je suis tenté de les donner au Diable. Mais vous n'affectez pas d'etre ce que vous n'êtes reellement; bien loin de cela, vous vous appreciez vous même bien moins que les autres ne vous apprecient; et tout ce qui sort de votre esprit, et de vôtre etude est l'effet irresistible de nature, assisté de l'amour des arts et des lettre que vous avez cultivé par la même impulsions naturels; et tout ce qui est l'effet spontané de la Mere Nature a un pouvoir si soudain, des charmes si irresistibles, et un tel stamp de verité a procurer l'admiration. Ne craignez pas donc le titre de bleu; et quant au fait de vos remarques sur la traduction de Rose, l'extrait de sa lettre doit vous avoir prouvé qu'il est non seulement reconnoissant mais docile, et qu'il a suivi autant qu'il a pu, vos avis. Je ne vous ai pas nommée, mais Murray vous a diviné; je n'ai rien affirmé; et le fait est que j'y ai gagné, car Rose enchanté des ameliorations qu'il a obtenu d'un critic inconnu par mon entremise, m'a envoyé en present de gratitude assez de papier doré pour ecrire mes longues lettres aux Dames pendant plus de un Année; et c'est le papier sur lequel je vous ecris, Milady, et j'ai l'honneur de vous faire souvenir que
«Saro qual fui, vivrò come son visso»
Votre devoué pour la vie; ce que Petrarque disait à Laure.

My Lord — I difered offering my respectful thanks to your Grace, because my duty to peruse attentively the description of Woburn Gallery was often compelled to yeld to the irresistible importunity of friends requesting to be allowed a sight of the Magnificent Work. It is indeed of a rare magnificence; for it is graced throughout (both in the typographical and in the litterary execution) with a tasteful delicacy perceptible to every eye, though it is in the power of only a few to combine with such a luxury of work–manship, and of learning. Many unknown things are noticed in the illustrations, and many prevalent errors detected, without the boast and the pedantic pride unhappily so usual on such occasions. I do not venture to pronounce on the style; still a foreigner may be permitted to express opinions which he derives from his own feelings and from the universal principles of litterature; — and I traced in each page the stamp of a gentlemanlike language naturaly kept in harmony with the subiect and with the aim of the Work. My gratitude therefore for the gift is enhanced by a kind of self congratulation at having been called upon to contribute however slightly, to a monument of your Grace's patronage of the Arts and of the elegance of your own mind; and the praises bestowed upon it, are in my opinion a good omen in favour of the fine Arts in England. I entreat your Grace not to consider this manner of offering my aknowledgements as dictated by the idea that your Grace stands in need of approvation; since I know that the pleasure of protecting and cherishing whatever is noble and beautiful is the only reward sought for by a mind like that of your Grace —
I am My Lord
Your Grace's respectful servant etc.

dateline.date: London. 8.th March, 1823. Crown & Anchor Tavern, Strand.

div1.p: Sir — I have the pleasure to inform you that several Friends of the Greeks have met together for the purpose of advancing by all the means in their power that most important cause.

It is their primary wish to give action and effect to that sympathy which they have reason to believe is very widely diffused over the Country, and on this ground they venture to calculate on your cooperation and to hope that you will allow your name to be added to the Committee, a List of whom accompanies this.
I have the honor to be, Sir, Your obedient humble Servant etc.

ps.p: P.S. — The Committee will be obliged by an early answer addressed “To the Chairman of the Greek Committee” at the Crown & Anchor, Strand”.

lg.l: Of late with passions of some difference,
But let not therefore my good friends be grieved
(Among which number, Cassius, be you one;)
Nor construe any further my neglect
Than that poor Hatfield with himself at war
Forgets the shows of love to other men.

div1.p: This putting Shakespeare in the race of my apology I mean to say in plain popular English that since Wednesday when I was favoured with your prompt communication I have been perfectly overwhelmed with affairs. My goods except my books and my bed are all this week come sub hastâ: my letters and old private papers are all consigned to the limping Deity of Lemnos and I wander, tout enragé, along the forsaken terraces of the castle which overlook the moat toward S. East wing (as you will recollect) accompanying the wind as it sighs along the deserted corridors and starting at the sound of my own voice. Were indeed the worship of the “mighty mother” still fashionable: I should be tempted to take a trip to Phrygia and execute a tripudium with the amiable Menades. As it is I must feed, I fear upon my own distempered thoughts a little time longer.

From your elaborate and copious description of this cottage it appears to be as nearly suitable as one can expect on the sudden and, if you think there would be room for my 3 book–cases, and for 2 minor articles of furniture, and if the proprietor w.d let me, by making a small furrow and flue, convert the little green house into a store I may contrive to pass my time agreeably till a permanent domicile is procured. I sh.d be obliged to you therefore to engage it from May 25 for 1 year with liberty to continue if I choose afterwards. If you can for 110 tanto meglio per noi; it not for a little or less than is possible for it is my intention for 4 years (to use a nautical but expressive phrase) to lie under snug canvas, and this little affair seems to second my views. I agree with you in your sweeping denunciation of lawyers: they are the toxicodendron of plants, the hydra and jackal of beasts (i.e. respecter habits ad counsellor and attorney) the creeping daemon that infests our paradise and this you may perhaps think Billings–gate enough at present.

You will scarcely read this execrablè scrawl I think if a spider's legs were dipped in ink and trailed along the virgin white they would do as well but I must give a truce to my jaded plume as it has carried me this 8 letters folio this post — Send me your Beúzepou poveí8e¢ concerning the house as soon as you can enjoin to find your spirits so good and constantly wish your health and high fortune messer Foscolo
Yr sincere friend etc.

dateline.date: 5 King's Bench Walks Temple Monday March ten 1823.

div1.p: Dear Sir — I am happy to inform you that M.r Douglas Kinnaird has returned to London, and I must again entreat you not to omit having my name wholly removed from all responsibility before 12 O'clock on Wednesday. He mentioned to me having found on his table a letter from some medical gentleman; — but his absence prevented him from seeing the bearer, who, he conjectures, brought with him some adeguate security in the place of mine. M.r D. Kinnaird expresses every inclination to accomodate you, by which I will be quietly and without further unpleasant efforts relieved from the inconvenience I now suffer.

Though I acquiesced in an estimate above two months ago for printing a private work of my compilation, I cannot permit myelf to put it into the printer's hands till my security for your £. 140 is altogether cancelled and annulled. You must be aware that I might be called upon at any moment to pay this money, and that if any one of M.r D. Kinnaird three partners required the payment he could not with propriety object to its being demanded. My book will cost me upwards of £. 200, and though I have this sum of money perfectly idle, and have thus appropriated it, I certainly cannot with convenience to myself expend double that amount. You doubtless recollect as distinctly as I do the circumstances that led to this transaction and those that took place during its progress; and you are now also fully aware of the very great sacrifices I have already made of personal convenience for your accomodation. My firm resolve therefore to finally relieve myself without further delay, from being any longer liable to so large a demand at the sudden will of persons with whom I am wholly inconnected, can by no body be considered as unreasonable; much less by you, acquanted as you are with your own communications and engagements, as well as with my remarks and feelings on the business.
I am, dear Sir, your's truly etc.

Dear Sir. — I am so ill and overpowered by a combined attack of inflamation on the chest and nervous headache that I can only answer that Memorabile is quite mispelt and that it must be written memorabili. I noticed the error myself after I had the pleasure of seeing you and so did also my friend Rog. Wilbraham. Now, dear Sir, as a retribution for my prompt answering, though from bed, be so good as to acquaint lord John with the accident which prevented me from sending some letters I intended; — by doing so as soon as possible, you will really oblige me very much. I hope to be able to rise to morrow from bed. Adieu — Yours very sincerely — etc.

My dear Sir, — I return you the papers — Your course is quite clear — You must pay the L. 50, you mentioned to me, to M.r Grace now and you must name at once some lawyer (I mean a Solicitor) who will meet M.r Grace's lawyer and give him a security. In order to effect this, you must name a Trustee, and your lawyer will apply to the Ground Landlord, of whom you rent your ground, to grant a fresh lease to him — The Trustee can then give M.r Grace a security; untill he can raise the sum you want upon the lease — In the mean time you must let M.r Grace know the name of your Solicitor and his address as soon as possible — If you are in want of an honest one, I will recommend one to you. The matter is simple and easy — but it presses — and nothing can be done without the lawyers —
Yours truly etc.
Sir — I enclose for your consideration a prospectus of the plan on which the Proprietors of the British Review propose to induct a new Series of this Journal.

It is my wish (as Editor) to introduce occasional articles on foreign literature, and I therefore write to enquire whether you are inclined to undertake the department of Italian criticism and to furnish an essay of about 30 pages for every number, or of about 60 pages for every alternate number; for which the Proprietors propose to offer you 20 guineas a sheet.
If you wish to enter into such an engagement I shall have great pleasure in calling upon you at any hour you will appoint in order to give you any further information you may require.
I have the honour to be your dev.d Serv.t etc.

My Dear Sir — As I don't hear from you since my last letter delivered to the post Monday last (now more than a week) I presume that you are still waiting for the letter which I promised when I endevoured to give you in my anomalous English a description of the Cottage — which I thought fit for your purpose, with the only objection “that the rooms are rather small”. — The owner called on me; — but I could not venture making an offer to him; he still asks £. 130 for a twelve month; and four g.s week for the six summer months — But I was unable to acquaint you sooner with this circumstance that he does not seem inclined to lower his pretensions; for, since last Monday I have been confined to my bed by a sudden attack on the chest relieved only by troublesome and torturing blisters, — and together with this inflammatory Kind of disease I suffered and still suffer of a nervous head–ache to which I can no find remedy but patience. To day I am better, and tomorrow, I hope, I will be able to quit my bed–room; —— but the weather is still so uncertain, and the winter so obstinate that I do not know whether I may be allowed to go out of doors before the end of this frosty and Eastwindy month.

My dear Sir. — You must excuse my not franking my former letter, but you know we have no opportunity of doing it, we poor country mice — and to pay postage is a thing which I can not bear to do, unless to strangler, and filthy lucre'men; but “time is, my tedious song should here have ending” my roses and Hedychiums and Amaryllis is and are all exulting in the madness of superfluous health at the return of Favonius, who has I hope ere this pound his salutary balm in to your bellows, what a frightful disease! For me I should have gone pessum, and ere this been carted into the Appian way, let me hope that you do not quack yourself but pray to Oesculapius in the form of an English physician: tho if I remember you always commend physic to the doss pray, to avoid any more trouble, nail the Cottage at L. 130 I bring 2 beds with me so that I shall without ceremony project those that I find, at a given angle 43o25'11“ forth from the window, chimney–sweeper not excepted, if he shews himself at all insolent. M.r Roscoe is shortly going to publish a botanical work on 1st class plants, I which I am so fond of; I sent him your Essays as also Hodgson, who seems much delighted with them. The moment I hear that you have engaged this nidus Braithwaite will precede with his 'frivola', plants, glasses and such traps in order that I may not be overwhelm on my coming — B. desires me to thank M.r Foscolo for his kind notice and says that he will possess himself of the required information And: now for your prospectus —— wide an interminable as the realms of other, but the 'field of view' is too wast for my present faculties, the prime thing to be hoped is that Health may buoy you up in time. In hopes of two lines by return, I am in the spirit of sincerity yours Altog.er.

Sir, — I had two days ago the satisfaction of disengaging M.r Grace from any liability on my account, and of disembarrassing myself from his fri[gh]tful solicitations; and, thank Heaven, the Banker is paid: — and as I succeeded last night in settling definitively the two leases on trustees, the parcel of distressing matters, which for several months kept my mind in constant anxiety, are at last at an end: — and I am the more happy as I found also the Original Letters of Petrarch which I missed during three years, and which belonged to Lord Holland, to whom I could not make any human compensation for the loss of such valuable papers. —

I begin nevertheless to feel, since last night, some anxiety concerning yourself; for my trustees required, and I owed to them, a candid and full statement of our transaction about your Cottage; and they are now bound, according to our agreement, to grant to you a regular lease for five years, and receive the rent —— but on being acquainted with the circumstance that part of the furniture is to be paid by installments, and another part quarterly during five years as a portion of the rent, they intimated that they could not consider you as an householder according to the law of England, since in case of default of payment either of the rent or the taxes, the furniture would be liable to seizure; and thus the interest of the mortgage should not become legally insured by the rent of the cottage. They added, however, provided you give a legal security for the amount of the furniture, there will be no need of rescinding the agreement: — but on my proposal that I would readily answer for your punctuality, they replied, that, although I trust you as a friend and a gentleman on account of my personal acquaintance with you, yet the trustees, being accountable for the payment of the principal and interest of the mortgage, they were strictly bound to act in the proper and regular way of business. I leave therefore the matter to your consideration, and be assured that whatever you think expedient, I will do every thing in my power to accommodate you.

A thousand thousand thanks, my Dear Foscolo —— I congratulate you on finding the MSS — and am satisfied it has pleased you even more than me, tho' I do not deny that I am very glad to see them again —
I am Dear Foscolo truly Yours etc.

Madame — C'est le premier jour que je quitte le lit, et c'est la premiere fois que je puis prendre la plume depuis 9 jours — J'avais même perdu la voix — et toute connoissance — aussi, Madame, ne me croyez pas ingrat, et je vous remercie de vôtre aimable invitation aussitôt que je le puis — et je regrette de ne avoir point joui de votre societé et de celle de vos amis. Ayez la bonté de dire mille choses de ma part a M.r Merivale, — et entre autres que tot au tard il aura, sans doute, un exemplaire de Petrarque qui lui appartient de droit — Je suis, Madame, et je serai toujours votre ami et serviteur devoué etc.

J'imiterai, Milord, si non autre chose, du moins la resignation des Heros de Homère, — et je laisserai les maisons «sur les genoux des Dieux» — J'en ai assez troublé moi–même, et les autres; et j'en serais moins faché; mais sans ma faute ni la faute des autres, l'affaire est devenu «a piece of work» — but let it work by itself; — et je me suis proposé de ne sortir plus de chez moi, ni m'occuper d'autre chose que des Lectures —, puisqu'il le faut, et c'est le seul moyen de salut; aussi le prospectus est deja imprimé et j'ai ecris a M.r Murray de le distribuer, et de menager, et administrer tout le Job, ne me reservant pour moi que les soins, 1.r d'ecrire jour et nuit, ce qui m'est tres–possible, — et 2.d de donner à mes nerfs et a ma physionomie assez de Fibra cornea pour me presenter à lire de l'Italien à ceux qui porteront moins d'oreilles que des yeux; — ce second effort me parait presque impossible, mais je le tacherai de toutes mes forces, et probablement qu'elle suffiront; et si je commencerai et finirai en même tems comme Cowper devant les Lords «in Parliament assembled» — j'aurais la consolation de avoir un compagnon illustre de malheur.

My dear Mr. Redding, — For heaven's sake send me by the bearer, and you shall have them returned to–morrow, — all the numbers of the N[ew] M[onthly] M[agazine] in which I wrote, but more particularly all those in which I wrote about Pietro delle Vigne, and Guido Cavalcanti, and if you have any remaining proofs of the article on Sordello or my French MS., or that of your own translation of the Sappho, send it to me.
Do not disappoint me, because I depend on those articles for some quotations — good bye.

The bearer will wait for an answer. Forgive the dictation of my letter, because I am sitting for my portrait before M. Pistrucchi, poet and painter. If you wish to hear his improvisations, you must come this evening to tea at eight o'clock.
Yours faithfully etc.

Mon cher Monsieur, — Un de mes amis Italiens ayant ecrit la piece ci–jointe, et l'ayant faite traduire (le ciel sait par qui et de quelle maniere! je crois de la maniere du diable) se flatte que l'on pourrait l'admettre à l'experimentum crucis a 'Drury Lane'.

Mon ami a aussi entendu que vous avez quelque bonté pour moi et me sollicite de vous prier de lire sa piece, et de dire franchement, si on l'accepteroit. C'est malgré moi, Mon cher Mons.r, que je dois vous soumettre a cette ennui; — car c'en est une, et je sais comme tous les auteurs (surtout les Martyres de la scene) est jour et nuit sur les epines. Adieu Mon cher Monsieur. Lady Dacre aura la bonté de vous remettre cette lettre, et elle la lira d'abord à fin de m'aider par son intercession pres de vous; — et je fais copier mon griffonage pour vous epargner la peine de le dechyphrer.
Adieu encore de tout mon coeur,
votre devoué etc.

My dear Sir, — Health has been equally a stranger to me as to yourself; owing to indisposition I could not go to the Theatre before last night, when your letter of the 1st inst. was delivered to me. I had asked Wallace for instructions before — on your note to him — and he intended writing to you. I will give you most certainly the earliest possible information respecting the play of Zama, I but must warn you of the necessity of a little patience, as Kemble, who reads the plays sent to Theatre, is at present in Paris, and is not expected home before the middle or end of next week. I will on his return (for the Committee do not go into this kind of business before) procure you a decisive answer, which you shall instantly recieve from me. I beg you will not think any office a trouble in which I have de pleasure of fulfilling your wishes, and of manifesting to you how very faithfully and sincerely
I am, dear Sir, Yours etc.

Mon cher Monsieur Cohen — Lorsque Graham vint à abiter près de moi l'on a acheté des meubles qu'il s'engagea de payer et qui servirent à fournir son cottage; mais le pauvre Graham entrainé par ses passions, ses anciens amis, et surtout ses malheurs, s'eloigna tout d'un coup, et il–y–a presqu'un an qu'il a disparu de mes yeux. — Les meubles néammoins devaient être payés, d'autant plus que j'en avois répondu au Marchand — aussi j'ai arrangé de payer en trois fois à la fin de chaque trimestre. —— J'ai payé à peu près 15 L. à la fin du premier trimestre; et lorsqu'il a fallu payer autant pour le second j'ai demandé les Items d'un lit fait pour Graham; car le bedstead étant mal fait du commencement, le marchand avoit consenti de le reprendre, et il s'agissoit de donner une compensation, en faisant une déduction pour le bedstead qu'il avoit repris; — le Marchand tout en convenant de mon droit à la compensation n'offrit de déduire que cinquante shellings; — ce que j'ai refusé, parceque le lit consistant seulement de deux petits matelas, l'un de laine, et l'autre de crin, et d'un très–petit bolster; et le Marchand, sans marquer le prix de chaque article, comme c'est la règle, avoit en grosse et en masse porté un compte L. 12. 18 pour le lit complet. Aussi si j'eusse accepté les L. 2. 10. — j'aurais consenti de payer pour deux petits matelas et le bolster la somme de L. 11. 8. — ce que je devois refuser d'autant plus que d'autres Marchands de pareils effets sont pret de jurer que la demande est exhorbitante, en m'assurant que tout tradesman est obligé par les devoirs constitutionels de son metier, et par les Lois du pays, de donner precisement dans son compte les détails et le prix de chaque objet séparément; et cela d'autant plus que le lit n'a pas été acheté tout fait, mais chaque article a été manufacturé expressément d'après l'ordre de Graham. Toutes ces raisons je les ai écrites et je les ai fait repéter par M.r Davis, mon builder, au Marchand, et en même temps j'ai fait le second payment d'à peu pres L. 15. — et alors j'ai insisté pour le bill avec les Items; — mais je n'ai jamais pu l'obtenir. Aujourd'hui L. 14 — sont due pour le troisieme et dernier payement, et bien loin d'envoyer les Items, insiste pour que j'accepte la déduction de L. 2. 10. — et il fait le diable a quatre pour me reduire de payer le reste. Il sait qu'en détaillant les Items j'aurais un document pour faire estimer les articles du lit, par des gens de son metier; — ce qu'il ne veut point — Mais ni moi non plus, tout en me soumettant de bonne grace a payer la dette d'un ami, je ne veux pas m'assujettir à être triché par de pareils gens. Le Marchand s'appelle Gray and Hull; il est ce que vous appellez an Upholster, et sa boutique est au coin de Wardour ou de Dean Street à Oxford Street. — De toute ma narration j'ai des documents et des témoignages, car ayant d'abord connu le caractere et les intentions de l'homme, je n'ai rien fait que par l'entremise ou à la présence des témoins; et je lui ai dernièrement fait savoir que je ne veux plus avoir à faire à lui que par le moyen d'un homme de Loi, et que je m'adresserai à Francis Cohen, Esq.r, 1, King's Walk Temple. — Aussi, mon cher Monsieur, dans le cas qu'il ne m'envoye les Items, ou qu'il ne préfère de me proposer un arrangement honnête, je vous écris cette Iliade, et je la fais copier à fin de ne pas vous condanner au surcroit de peine de dechyfrer mon écriture.
Pardonnez–moi, je vous en conjure et croyez que je vous trouble malgré moi, et que je ne le ferois si je n'étoit sur d'être grondé par vous et par vos amis pour avoir negligé de vous consulter.
Adieu de tout mon Coeur
Tout à Vous etc.

Dear M.r Murray — We have settled with Lady Dacre that the job of the Lectures shall take place on Tuesdays o' night without farther delay as proposed by you. Pray do send some man to take your Greek wine which I have caused to be placed with plainty straw in a large basket; and I have also a smaller one ready for the oxonian Aristophanes to whom you will be so good as to forward it through some of your intelligent clerks. —
Adieu de tout mon coeur —
Your grateful friend etc.

Dear Murray — I read in the Times of yesterday the following words — “There are a few names in the literature of the present day better known than that of M.r F— it is therefore with pleasure we hear that this gentleman is about to give lectures on the history of litterature of Italy” etc. etc. — I cannot guess by whom they received this communication; the person who send it seems well acquainted with the prospectus which I have shewn only to you — to Lord John — Hallam, — Rose — Lord Dacre — and Wilbraham — but I am thankful to the unknown person, and not less so to the Editor of the Times. — Here you have the prospectus revised; — I should like to see another proofs of it before its being published — Adieu.
Yours faithfull etc.

ps.p: P.S. — I send you a specimen of my Printing office, of which you must make use with some caution as I may run the danger of an information on account of the leases.

div1.p: Mio caro Foscolo — Impossibilitato di congedarmi personalmente, vi scrivo se non per augurarvi felicità non compatibile in core italiano, per augurarvi almeno salute, ed onde rinnovarvi gli attestati della stima, ed amicizia che vi professo. Non credete ch'io parta pieno di dolci illusioni: parto rimembrando più tosto quell'Ateniese in Maratona che si prefisse d'impedire la fuga di un legno nemico dal vicino lido. Li venne troncato il braccio dritto, ed egli impiegò il sinistro, e perdutolo anche si ajutò co' denti, finchè troncata ebbe la testa.

My dear Sir — Will thou oblige me by the acceptance of the enclosed copy of my Translation of Garcilasso, a poet whom, should'st thou be unacquainted with him, I would thus recommend to thy notice, as an admirer of thy Petrarch: — accept him as a proof that thou liv'st in my frequent remembrance.

I have been very desirous of learning how thou art going on with regard to thy health; as the last notice I received of thee was that thou wast still suffering in bed under the effects of fever —— and I remarked that thy Lectures were in consequence put off. I hope, however, that long before this thou hast been able in thy pleasant garden.
“to range about,
Visit thy trees, and number every spout”.
I was much obliged by thy notes, through Lord John, of the termination of Italian adjectives.

I am fast proceeding with my Tasso; just completing the 18th Book, and writing the Life, in which I find thy edition of the “Rime” very serviceable. Could'st thou oblige me for a time with that number of the New Monthly which contained thy Essay on the Lyric Poetry of Tasso? if sent to St. James's Square by Thursday next, I should receive it on Friday. My printer says he shall spare no powers, and I shall certainly spare no expence to make this a most beautiful book. I have been thinking how valuable an addition would be a short Dissertation from thy pen on the Genius and Gerusalem of Tasso!
Have the goodness to let me know in a little time how thou ast, and believe me, with many wishes for thy welfare.
Thy very faithful friend and servt. etc.
A new leaf for page xv of the Preface will be furnished, when the present leaf may be cancelled. —

Monsieur, — Je crois pouvoir vous adresser un de vos compatriotes, — M. Marconi, qui a été longtems en Suisse d'où il m'est adressé par plusieurs personnes recommandables, et qui se rend en Angleterre, avec l'intention d'y donner des leçons de langue italienne. Je saisis avec plaisir cette occasion de me rappeller à votre obligeant souvenir, et je désirerais avoir quelquefois de vos nouvelles directes et vous voir prendre un intérêt un peu actif à notre Revue Encyclopédique dont M. Roy doit vous remettre, chaque mois, un cahier, et que vous pourriez annoncer avec soin dans les deux grands recueils, Edinburgh Review et Quarterly Review, que nous avons souvent annoncés avec les éloges qu'ils méritent. Je suis étonné de ne pas recevoir ces recueils en échange, quoique je leur fasse envoyer notre Revue.
Notre ami M. Salfi s'est chargé de rendre un compte détaillé de votre dernier ouvrage que je me suis empressé de lui transmettre.
Agréez, Monsieur, les nouvelles assurances de ma considération distinguée et de mon ancien et sincère attachement etc.

ps.p: P.S. — Je vous prie de me rappeller au souvenir de vos aimables voisines et à celui de M. Murray.

div1.p: My Dear Sir — A friend who sets out immediately for London, just allows one time to put the enclosed in an envelope. I need not say that it comes from one of those numerous men of literature and distinction, for whose acquaintance I am indebted to you. I will not return you commonplace thanks for your letters of introduction. — I brought others to Italy. They procured me civilities and attention. But your name was an electric sound, that caused me to be treated more as a prince, than as an unknown youth of letters. S.r Bertolotti was not at Milan while I remained there, which I much regretted. He seems to have made himself many enemies. Monti was at Pesaro too, while I was there, but I met and knew Mustoxidi, who avoided carefully all or any conversation that might at all touch upon Ugo Foscolo. It is honourable, that those who do not love, respect you. A propos, I became very well acquainted with an ecclesiastic at Rome, learned and acute, who had been a fellow student of yours at Padua; he had been afterwards engaged in public instruction at Parma; strange to say, I have altogether lost traces of his name. Count Velo was not at Vicenza, as I passed, and Pellico has been long removed from his place at Genoa, as indeed his name might indicate, so that your letters to the personages still remain unopened. Of the Marquis Capponi's kindness to me I cannot speak too highly. I met several literary characters at his palace at Florence. The first rule of whose orthodox cruscanism is devout admiration of Foscolo. Nevertheless I disagreed with the Marquis and his society on many topics, and expressed my dissent freely like a son of your adopted country. M.r Capponi gave me letters for De Rossi and Cancellieri at Rome, neither of whom I liked, and for Selvaggi at Naples, whom I admire and love. So mild, so learned, so amiable a man as Selvaggi I know not. Grassi agrees with me in thinking him uno dei pochi. — Need I say that Grassi himself deserves the same classification. He has given me his Synonimi for you. How he, how all your friends speak of you? There is an ardour of friendship, and an infantine, simple mode of expressing it in Italy, that enchants me above all things — but they want the spirit, the fiery soul — which one, whom I know, could give them, if such things could be communicated.

I have sent a Review of your Essay to Blackwood, but as those gentlemen alter every thing, I cannot be answerable for any impudence they may think proper to add. I love them not, but am bound to Blackwood personally for many acts of kindness, and I am not so much of Brutus to sacrifice private gratitude to any shallow–founded public principle that my ill–fed and ill–founded political knowledge could suggest.

I have received hints from this person and from that person that the Hall has separated and from you, poor fellow, I'm afraid, he's wild. But I hope, you had no cause of complaint against him. If so, you are most unlucky in translators and transcribers.

I hope to be soon in England, and to talk with you on the project which filled my mind when I left England, it is still uncertain, but the death of a relation, which happened the other day, may furnish me with the means of carrying my wishes into effect.
I hope to be in England for your lectures, which must be interesting, and which are
Believe me, dear Sir, your grateful friend and admirer etc.

ps.p: P.S. — I beg to be remembered to Redding, and Banim, if you know the latter.
Bettoni is publishing beautiful edition of your four classics. I wish you would be quick with yours.
Your Oration at the Congress of Lyons was reprinted at Naples during the Revolution. —
Grassi has given me a copy of Synonimi for you, in case you have not received the one he sent you, — if not, for myself.

div1.p: Ugo mio: — Ti scrivo un verso profittando della venuta costà di Lord Dillon, il quale è mio buon amico, e forse tu lo vedrai, e potrà darti nuove di me e di tutti gli amici nostri. Io non ho da dirti di me alcuna cosa particolare, perchè potrei cercar tutto il giorno, non troverei da che ti ho lasciato una cosa mia che meriti di esser detta. Tanto ho vissuto nell'inerzia, e nella ignavia, e nel veterno cioè alla Fiorentina affatto, o per dir meglio alla Italiana, o meglio anche alla Europea, giacchè mi pare che questo bel ritrovato di aver fatto di tutta l'Europa una famiglia sola, non abbia servito ad altro, che a estendere da per tutto l'esempio dei peggiori. E lode al Cielo, che presto ne avremo assicurata l'ultima prova, e non vi sarà più dubbio che alcuno possa uscire ormai dalla regola generale, e allora metteremo l'animo in pace, e vivremo tranquillamente la vita dei paria, primogeniti della creazione quanto al senno, e filosofi per eccellenza. Tu hai la fortuna di vivere nel paese dell'ipocrisia, e così hai le sole consolazioni che possano aversi, poichè quello è il solo omaggio che si renda ormai alla virtù. Io se potrò una volta tornerò ancor io a far l'ipocrita, meglio che saprò in Inghilterra, e vi resterò, ma per ora non posso, perchè ho famiglia, che ha tuttora bisogno di me, per quanto io le faccia poco, ma quel certo bisogno, che è fondato più che altro su certe convenienze sociali rispettabilissime almeno di nome. Il Velo poi l'ha passata meglio di me, e di ogni altro. Si è nascosto là in mezzo ai Sette Comuni, dove non esce mai, e dorme quanto gli occhi ne possono, e poi pianta ed annaffia, e non legge neppur più mai gazzette, nè vuol sentir parlar delle cose di questo nostro mondo, e ingrassa, e si ride degli altri. — Tu scrivimi un poco una volta qualche cosa di te ma in un modo circostanziato, e che tenga luogo di una chiacchierata, di quelle che si facevano ogni giorno, ed ora mi contenterò di una in tre anni. Manda una volta qualche cosa per l'Antologia, che non è cattivo giornale, e per certe parti quasi un miracolo per l'Italia. — Niccolini ti abbraccia, e volea scriverti. Addio dal cuore
tuo ecc.

Mio caro Foscolo — II Sig.re Demetrio Zervo mio amico è il latore di questo foglio. Egli è nativo di quest'Isola, e mio amico, e nelle circostanze attuali nè ha tradito i doveri della consanguineità, nè se n'è mostrato indiferente, benchè collocato in situazioni assai delicate e dificili. A tali titoli io lo raccomando alle tue amichevoli attenzioni ed alla tua benevolenza. Egli potrà appagare, meglio che non poss'io, minutamente la tua curiosità sopra assai cose, di cui per avventura non ti sarà discaro l'avere esatti ragguagli e sicuri di testimone le più volte oculare dei fatti che narra. — Mi afflisse assai di non avere mai riscontrato di te nemmeno una sillaba, risguardante l'oggetto principale delle mie lettere mandateti nel 1821 col Sig.r Fox e col Co.llo Napier. Se ti richiami di dette lettere, giudica tu del mio giusto dolore; e penetrato di ciò, cerca comunque puoi di fare riparo. E potrai non poco ancora se tu ti adoperi con impegno pari all'altezza de' sentimenti e allo zelo, che altre volte ho in te ammirato ed amato. — La Grecia a tutta possa orrevolmente lotta per ritornar Grecia, nè si è sottoposta a sì inauditi sagrifizj nè è pronta ad incontrarne di nuovi per amore dei Russi o per vaghezza di divenire loro ancella, ma per tutto suo conto, e unicamente per se stessa, ella pugna; e questo è l'anno che deve redintegrarla nella sua libertà e nella prisca sua gloria, od esserle fatale!... Io ho cessato di essere nulla in questa parte. — Domani rimpatrio colla mia famiglia; ed indi seguiro le ispirazioni del mio Demonio. Iddio ci dia il contento di rivederci con onore! —

Ho una piccola vaga Aspasia, la quale finora mostra più intelligenza che corpo. Mi dicono che tu vivi in domestica beatitudine: se così è ne godo, e teco me ne congratulo: se poi no, desidero che presto sia. Di me ti ricorda, ma innanzi a tutto che io e tu ebbimo comuni voti, i quali vieppiù strinsero il reciproco e caldissimo nostro affetto, e che al compimento di tali voti noi dobbiamo quanto è possibile conservarci! Addio coll'anima. Addio
Il tuo affezionatis.o amico ecc.

Non che dimenticarmi, Signor Marchese carissimo, de' libri per Gino vi ho portato jer l'altro un indice stampato di quanti n'ha pubblicati Murray ultimamente, perchè poteste voi sceglierne; — se non che dalla lettera dell'amico nostro ora m'accorgo che nè da voi nè da me si potrebbe scegliere senza stare a rischio di comperarne o pochi, o troppi, tanto la sua commissione è generale; ed espressa in termini che ci giustificherebbero se gli facessimo arrivare in Firenze tutto il Pater Noster Row imballato. Nondimeno andrò leggendo gli avvisi di nuove opere, e i cataloghi d'antiche, e ve ne compilerò una lista, della quale vi gioverete voi per lui come e quanto il Cielo e il vostro giudizio vi spireranno. L'avrete per Martedì fra le ore 2 e le 3; perché allora dovrò servirmi d'un Fiacre per andare alla berlina mia delle letture, e così potrò portarvi anche le due copie de' Saggi sul Petrarca, l'una vostra l'altra di Gino, che avete lasciate sul mio tavolino. Intanto vi rimando la lettera e m'è stata carissima, e farò di scrivergliene una che se non gli riescirà tanto cara sarà ad ogni modo egualmente lunga, — e fors'anche più pazza della sua. Ma così va quando s'ha da vivere in modo diverso da quello con cui siam nati, e ci siamo educati a sentire — Addio.
Tutto vostro — ecc.

Sir, — After the late pecuniary settlement between us, effected by my friend M.r Fitzpatrick, I have waited in hopes of receiving from you some satisfaction for the misstatements you made of me to others. You have sent no communication and I therefore write this note.

From a gentleman mutually known to us both I am authorized to state that you represented me as having obtained money on the bills I accepted for you, and afterwards leaving them unpaid. I will not — because I need not — pause to contradict this gratuitous and wanton falsehood, nor detail the contrary pacts and contingent occurrences that I want with a feature of additional cruelty and duplicity. It is absolutely necessary however that I point out its impervious operation on my character as a man of honesty and honor, and call upon you to make me some atonement.

Neither of us can afford to be slandered. I further know that you cannot afford to be exposed; therefore, in seeking to protect myself I am willing, after all you have inflicted on me, to spare you as much as possible; and, at present I require from you only a written acknowledgment of the misstatements before mentioned, together with an undertaking not to proceed in them. To accomodate you more I voluntarily pledge my honor that I shall never exhibit the document unless you compel me to do so by renewed injury. The post I leave to oblivion and your own prudence.

I should you think proper to decline those terms I leave you that I have been legally advised, and that it is my solemn determination to institute against you a legal action for defamation of character.
In conclusion I must say that under all the circumstances I can receive none but a written communication from you; and for that I shall wait the usual time. Etc.
Dear Sir, — Having sent to town this day to an office where a considerable sum is due to me I received the enclosed, which is necessarily a disappointment.

As I try to keep out of debt in the neighbourhood and have arranged some small payments for this day, the 2 sovereigns remaining between us since the Pact understanding would be valuable under the circumstances.
Dear Sir, Yours truly etc.

div1.n: 2815. Di Archibald Rosser And Jones.(5 giugno 1823)
div1.p: Sir, — M.r Banim has consulted us professionally on the loss sustained by him in consequence of your slanderous attacks on his character and has also detailed to us the circumstances which preceded them. On the latter, we are happy that it is no part of our duty to make any comment; but with regard to your aspersions on M.r Banim, we inform you that we are instructed to commence an action against you, to recover damages for the injuries they have occasioned.
