To your other printed inclosure, there are objections. — General publicity upon points, of such nicety, is far from advantageous. — No one need be acquainted with the difficulties which may exist in your title, to your leasehold property, but the persons who shall claim under it, and the atty who may be employed to remove those difficulties. — It does, I must own, seem to me most extraordinary that your difficulties, as to title, should so, stick to you. — If I had money (if I were not an impoverished Land–owner) I should not hesitate to advance the 1300 L. so soon as the lease was made, by the builder, to trustees to hold for your use–subject, always, to the charge of the advance. —— If the houses are as valuable as your calculation makes them, there cannot be any difficulty.
The droit d'aubain — which is cause of your difficulty — is not the Alien bill — but ancient law of the land — stupid, perhaps, as it is ancient. —
You may consider it as an axiom, in English existence, that nothing is so dangerous, so ruinous, and destructive, as being in the hands of a roguish, low, attorney. —
Vale et me ama!

Dear Foscolo (for you once told me never to say Mister or Monsieur) —— I cannot say how much I am obliged to you, for thinking of giving me so valuable a book as this edition of Virgil must be, though I really hardly like to take it quite away from you. — Remember if ever you repent of your generosity, your old friend shall be restored to you, with almost as much gratitude for the loan, as I now feel for the gift. — In the mean time I expect the greatest pleasure in examining our Virgil (for we will be partners in the possession of it) tomorrow, for le Roi de Trebisonde will be in London and will bring me any parcel that is left in Chesterfield St.
We may therefore feel at ease about the safety of our joint treasure. —
I have perused and studied the translations from Plato and Hierocles, and as the Prince and Princess are as yet too young to profit by them, we will hope that may not be wasted in their mother.

I like the manner in which they are translated very much indeed. I think a plain literal translation gives one a better idea of the original than a very finished and studied one, for the exact meaning of the Author is made more clear to one, and one's imagination allows a great deal for all the graces of language that are not attempted to be given. —

Your account of your health is most melancholy and I believe change of scene, and seeing friends around you would do you more good than all the Doctors in Europe. — Your health depends very much in your spirits, and I am sure we should do you good if you will come among us. — Lord Dacre and Mama are going into Shropshire, and we are going to Cassiobury, but when we are reassembled here the beginning of November, you must really come and let yourself be put in better spirits by seeing happy people around you. You are too kind hearted not to rejoice in the good fortune of others who have all their kith and kin around them. — “The next thing to being happy ourself, is to see others happy” — as a very interesting girl crossed in love once said. —

Now goodbye, dear Foscolo, and if it does not hurt your eyes too much write to us again to sfogare your griefs — I must once more tell you how much I shall value it on that account as well as for its intrinsic beauty and utility. — Once more goodbye. Ys obliged and sincere friend etc.

Dear Sir — We shall be glad to be of any service to you in setting the affair with Mess.rs Pole & C.o to save you what expence we can. If you will state to us your view of the matter, we will see the plaintiff's attorneys on the subject. The account we have had a copy of is
For printed
L. 150 — Interest
7.10.9 Stamp
4.6
157.15.3 Costs
10. 3.4
167.18.7

The officer informs us that he took L. 160 — leaving due L. 7.18.7. It will be necessary to take some steps speedily to save further costs, and perhaps you will give us a call when we can explain to you the state of the proceedings as to from, better than by letter. The mere payment of the L. 10 — for costs, beyond the payment of the sum sworn to, does not in itself except you from further proceedings, if the plaintiffs have re[....] further claim against you —
We are, Dear Sir, Yours very truly etc.

My dear Sir — I called upon you yesterday to get you to sign a receipt for the L. 150 which you had the other day. The old receipt you shall cancel, if you please, for, as that was my own, I can do what I choose with it.
This latter L. 150 I must beg of you to repay me as soon as you can as I shall shortly have to account for it to my brother's trustees.
I trust that your mind will feel somewhat relieved my this communication and beg you to believe me in sincerity yr friend etc.

My dear Sir — I burned your mem.m of the first 150 L. immediately on receiving it, so think no more of it: it is gone; non esiste più. The other I should wish to be repaid by December 21st as very early in January. I have a legacy of L. 300 to pay to a young lady who then comes of age. It is these things and certain law expenses together with sundry annuities to poor relations, which have employed my income for 4 years; however by retrenching for 3 or 4 years I hope to find my finances as prosperous as ever. This is the real truth — As to any little paltry acts of civility, which it has been my pleasure to render you, I consider that I have had value received, and sure I am that if you had the power, your right hand would be as open as any body's.
In haste and sincerely yours etc.

Dear Foscolo — I have lately heard something which makes me think it probable that Mr Hall of the Spanish Committee may communicate with you, respecting your opinion of him such as you conveyed it to me at Whitton —
It is necessary therefore for you to be put upon your guard and to be told the following facts
1st That I thought it my duty to communicate to a brother Committee man what I had heard respecting Mr Hall. Mr Hall being confidentially employed by the Spanish Committee.
2ndly That I did this without mentioning your name and without giving any hint by which my informant could be suspected.
3dly That my brother Committee man promulgated the story and, contrary to express stipulation, gave me up as his authority.
4thly That Mr Hall wrote to me to know my informant and that I declined to give him any explanation whatever.
So that if Mr Hall pretends that he knows my informant it must arise from his own suspicions and does not come in any way from me —
It is proper you should know this in order to regulate your conduct in any communication with Mr Hall —
This is enough for the present. I will tell you the rest when we meet.
Yours truly etc.

Sir — I am directed by Mr Murray to send proofs of Forsyth's work to Italy for your inspection, and to say that Mr Murray does not wish to give you further trouble than that of making such verbal corrections as you find necessary. If you will have the goodness to say whether the bearer shall call for the proofs, or you will return them by post, it will greatly oblige
Your most obed hble Servant etc.

Dear M.r Gleen — Be so good as to deliver to the bearer three copies of my Essais on Petrarch, and let them be put on my account, as they are not for my own use, but are to be sent in Italy. It is necessary that they should be delivered on tomorrow before evening, that they may be given to the gentleman which is going to the Continent — I shall be in town in a few days, — meanwhile I send you in a parcel my corrections of the three last sheets of the new Edition of Forsyth Travels — be so good as to send them to the printer, who is unknown to me. My love to M.r Murray —
Yours sincerely obliged etc.

Vi piaccia leggere l'acchiusa. Essa contiene ciò che la mia situazione e il mio dovere di comune amico mi suggeriscono, anzi m'impongono. Rimandatemi la lettera ond'io possa inoltrarla, se non ci avete obbiezione.
Siete troppo giusto per non approvare la mia deliberazione. Sono troppo schietto per non comunicarvela chiaramente.
Desidero di potere in questa occasione darvi una testimonianza della sincerissima amicizia che mi onoro di portarvi, senza offendere i miei doveri verso un altro amico.
Vostro aff.mo amico ecc.

lg.l: Così ne' sensi, — ma più breve

div1.p: A me, caro Conte, non s'appartiene di approvare o disapprovare la lettera che intendete di scrivere al S.r Ugoni. Vi ho richiesto di assistermi da padrino, e vi avrei scelto per giudice, nè vi ricuserei come mediatore; pero vi lessi la mia risposta al S.r Ugoni, e la mandai perchè l'avete approvata, e m'avete promesso la vostra assistenza. Quale e quanta parte avreste poi da assumervi, o da rifiutare, l'esito de' primi passi, e il vostro giudizio v'avrebbero dato norma. Con questa reciproca intenzione, a quanto credo, ci siamo divisi jer sera; or voi fate come meglio vi pare; io non voglio fare se non quel solo ch'io devo fare; ed è di condurre l'affare con le regole prescritte in tutti i paesi, e con le forme richieste in Inghilterra per evitare il biasimo che la violazione di sì fatte forme provocherebbe da' gentiluomini del paese. Ho anteposto un Italiano e voi fra gli altri Italiani per dare quanto meno scandalo si potesse; —— ma quand'io non trovassi un Italiano, non m'accuserete spero, se ricorrerò a Forestieri — Addio —
Tutto vostro — ecc.

My good friend — I of course shall be happy to lend you my personal assistance if I will be unfortunately required — In conseguence of your Note, I shall call on Count Collegno — on my way to the Theatre where I am engaged to night — whether I see him or not — I shall come to you tomorrow morning soon after nine — If you desire see me earliest, you must come to me —
Yours sincerely etc.

My good friend — I trust that I have settled the matter happily and correctly — and I hope also satisfactory to you — what I have proposed and to which Collegno immediatly asserted — was that each party should write as follows —

Mons.r Ugone par son ami le Compte Collegno reconnoit son tort de s'etre permis des expressions non justifiées vers Monsieur Foscolo et exprime ses regrets de ce qui s'est passé entre eux — on the other hand —

Monsieur Foscolo par son ami le Colonel Jones reconnoit son tort de s'etre permis des expressions non justifiées vers Mons.r Ugone et exprime ses regrets de ce qui s'est passé entre eux — both of you having been in the wrong. I do not see you can object to our exchanging — Collegno and myself — this explanation — which compromises neither — which leads to no discussion and which settles the absurd quarrel without difficulty — Collegno answers for M.r Ugone — I therefore rely on your permitting me to do so for you I shall be at home at five o'clock when I shall wish to see you — be punctual —
Toujours à vous etc.
¼ to four —

dateline.date: N.o 21. Cavendish Square Thompson's Hotel [October 1823 by the end].

div1.p: My Dear Foscolo — I was yesterday so engrossed by business of one kind or other that I could not get over to you last night. Believe me I regretted it exceedingly for you are of all people in the world he whom I value and cherish most — your heart's present would I feel as if it were my own, and would gladly contribute my sympathy and affection towards alleviating it were it in my power. But ***— However I hope some happy change in your affairs will soon take place, and that your ardent soul find occasion to sfogarsi in more stirring occupations than those to which of late it has been contemned.

Take this letter as my farewell, since I cannot have the happiness of pronouncing it viva voce — Trust me I shall never forget your kindness to me and wish you every comfort and consolation that is to be found on earth. If you have any letter or any thing also to send to me, please write to me Fermo in Posta — Roma.

My Dear Sir — I doubt not that you will long ago have procured admission to the Traveller's club for our friend M.r Schlegel, and that your kindness will have readily suggested to you the cause of my silence, which could be no other than absence from home. I returned yesterday from a long round of engagements of business in Ireland and Wales.

I had heard of M.r Schlegel's arrival in London and I heartily hope and trust that he is still amongst us, and to remain some [....] I have the greatest respect and admiration for [....] and agreable qualities; and I am besides personaly obliged to him for kindness shown me long ago in Italy. You will particularly oblige me by a line for post to let me know where he is, and I shall fly to salute him. Should it happen that he is still without admission to the Travellers pray hasten your kind answer. And believe me my Dear Sir with the greatest regard and esteem.
Your sincere friend and servant etc.

My Dear Brother —— Since I find myself once more in the land of the sun, in my way to places and scenes which always fill me with delight, my thoughts naturally revert to you, whose society would double all my pleasures, and long but long alas, in vain, that it were possible to annihilate the distance that separates us, and from Albaro gaze with you on the blue expanse that now glitters before me. How is it with you? Has any change for the better taken place in your affairs? Are you still to remain stationary “devouring your own heart”?,These and a hundred other questions I would wish to have answered in the instant, but must wait for the slow return of the Post, before I can even know whether you be well or ill, or any thing else about you. But you will remember how deeply I am interested in all your concerns, and lose no opportunity of writing to me to the care of Torlonia, Banker at Rome, and be sure I shall often gratify my affection by conversing with you by letter.

Bad weather pursued us during our progress through France but on gaining the summit of mount Cenis at daybreak last Tuesday week, I had the satisfaction of seeing the Alpine peaks around the Hospice already tinged “celestial rosy red” — by the sun that was rising to greet my arrival once more in the plains of Italy — Yesterday we crossed the Bocchetta, and have halted here for a day or two — to an English fancy nothing can be conceived more lovely than this soft autumnal weather, the brilliant sun sky and sea that form the landscape here, when it comes to ones mind, what is the probable state of a London atmosphere at this period — for me, who love the sun beams as my life, it is a source of ever new enjoyment, which has but one drawback and that is the lack of yourself to enjoy it with me. I shall pursue my journey southward in a day or two, praying a visit on my way to the Quarries of Carrara. At Florence I shall probably see your friends and shall remember you to them. By the way now I think of it, I may as well say that I hope you delivered that letter I sent to you to the person it was addressed to. I was charged to deliver it myself, but could not find him out. I shall see the person who gave it me, and shall confidently say the letter reached its destination. At la Tour du fin as we were going to Beauvais in there happened to be a fair hold, the sides of the narrow street were lined with cattle, the middle space occupied by a smelly crowd that would neither give way to our carriage, nor pass on by it — the confusion was increased by the arrival of a flock of sheep, which remained wedged among the people. There we stand in spite of the execration of the postilion, the clamour of the crowd, the services of the gens d'armes appointed to keep order, for a considerable time — at length the sheep were carried one by one through the living mass, and we contrived to proceed amidst the grimaces, and the outcries of a French mob. But enough of this my journey hitherto has been like all other safe journies, without adventure, or incident worth detailing — in my future letters I may perhaps have something more worthy of transcription, if not, you must rest satisfied with the effusions of my friendship and affection.

By the by, I should like to know why Sophocles calls the Narcissus xxygospuc; — does the narcissus grow in tufts? Adieu, my very dear brother, believe me with every sentiment of true affection and sincere regard
most truly your etc.

ps.p: The King of Sardinia is improving his roads very much, in a short time they will equal if not surpass in goodness our Mac Adam ones.

div1.p: [1] [....] of extracting from Mr. Reading such answers and admissions as to disable him to trouble me and again with the gossip of parish about his real or immaginary disgrace. A Lady who witnessed his conduct and heard the whole of our words from a low window, was forth coming in a carriage accompanied by my counsel and a reporter. — Yet I defered less to the rapresentations of the magistrate than to your silent attendance, — not with any view of deserving your thanks, but only to avoid from all gentlemanlike scholars a just blame on the ground that those whose talents have attracted the attention of their countrimen ought not to expose each other to be laughed as for having brought themselves in contact with halfgentlemen and halfscholars; — thus since I have fallen under such a misfortune I ought to try to get rid of it, without committing my equals, at least, as long as it lies within my power; — for, after you allowed him your interference, I cannot avoid mentioning your name without weakening my means of silencing a host of hawkers of small litterature whom I must and will, and can compel never to boast that they served me as translators and copyists.

They are six in number. The first was the Irish doctor who availed himself of your sympathy to be introduced to me — and soon after went to King's Bench, where he resorted to tears and tricks hand threats to extort from me the money which he wanted for the insolvent act. The award which silenced his claims and cleared my conduct even on the score of humanity was of no use against the complaints which I know he went on, and very likely goes on still repeating of my having behaved to him like a tyrant. Three others, of whom you scarcely know either the achievements or the names followed the same course, and I have lately taken such steps as to expose this most singular conspiracy. They themselves are not aware of their conspiring, — and yet they did, and still they do conspire with the instinct of ravens flying one after the other on the back of a wounded horse.

Their common want of early education — their assumptuous pretensions to talents which were soon humiliated by the experiments through which I convinced them unequal to their pretensions —— their ambition to appear moving among gentlemen humiliated likewise by my adversion for the habits and feelings and esprit de corps of natural society — their needy situation incitated by their extravagant expectations — their calculations on my confidence arising from easiness and which they mistook for blindness — my womanish sympathy — my bashfulness to enforce precautions in money transaction — my contempt for their repeated provocations which at last they construed into a monkish resignation to bear and forbear — all these features and circumstances were common to them all, — so they all acted in the same way, and the result has been the same. They all seemed eager to end their service for me with a duel, — but none was ashamed to be ignorant of the rule — “that not only between men of honour, but even between knaves all money accounts ought to be definitively settled in the eve of a duel”. — Had Mr. Reading, when he intended to knock me down, looked at own accounts, possibly he would have remarked a ballance in my favour which, although very small, might have charged his conscience more than my blood, — since the offence of which he charges me, if it be not a pretended one, ought certainly to be revenged with blood. —
But has he duly considered why and of what evidence my blood ought to atone for the offence?

Let then, Mr. Reading, remember that some twenty three months ago he introduced to serve me as translator a man as a friend known for more than ten years, and as a gentleman — holding chambers and furnitures of his own in the Temple besides a room in some Inn in the West End of the town for convenience of Society?

that a cottage was rented from Mr. D. for the gentleman of the Temple; he was to pay the rent and L. 36. for the fixtures and furnish it with goods and books from his professional chambers — that some more furniture has been bought for the gentleman of the Temple in his presence and on my security from Mess. Gray & Hull, upholsters in Oxford street —

that the gentleman of the Temple before establishing himself in the cottage did pay L. 17. to a tradesman by name Kelly on account of the L. 36 — but that no sooner he was established in the cottage then turned out to be destitute of home, of books, of cloth, of shirt, of shoes, of credit, of friends — except his old friend Mr. Reading, and myself, a very new friend, indeed, but who kept him at my table, and on whose support he solely depended.
that a few days before he declared his real situation, the gentleman of the Temple gave up with exception of two rooms the whole cottage and garden to Mr. R.

that Mr. Reading tenanted it for eight months or there about, and paid L. 15.15. — for rent, and their friend paid almost nothing, whilst from regular claims and receipts it appears that I paid for those eight months, namely from February to October L. 33. 6. 8. to Mr. Davis for rent — and L. 14. 13. 4. — to the collectors of King taxes, Parish rates, and charges for water. True it is that Mr. Reading held that no rent ought to commence but from a quarter–day. — Yet the bills and receipts will convince him that neither landlords, nor collectors would admit the practibility of his doctrine. — I said that his friend the gentleman of the Temple paid almost nothing for rent, since out the L. 17. which he formerly delivered in the hands of Kelly I settled a bill for clothes ordered to my taylor by the gentleman of the Temple, and I paid to M. Kelly and Mess. Gray & Hull a discount on consideration of taking back some part of the furniture which on my security was made new on purpose for him —

that a few months after he cohabited with his old friends, the gentleman on the Temple suddenly disappeared, — and wrote — a pathetic letter on indigence, idleness, suffering and despair, begging of me not to judge harshly; of his conduct repeating thanks and acknowledging the disappointment and expence he caused to me, exclaiming that my general benevolence and in particular my kindness to him deserved something better: — yet even under the influence of such an unbounded sentimental gratitude, he calculated so well upon [....]

[2] This second introduction, however was not a matter of civility. The late tragicomedies of Italy having obliged me to give up even the hope of being buried near my forefathers — and to recover the greatest part of my income by manufacturing work of genius I studied even the folly of building in order to find myself to be wise in seething for ever in a country which with its fogs, its stock jobbers, its petty attornies, its slankes of small litterature, and its upstarts, still enjoied the greatest share of justice of liberty and marks that the nature of man has even allowed to any nation on hearth [....]

[3] [....] soon after the turrist in a note from Russell square reminded me of the introductory letter, which indeed I had not promised and certainly had not refused. On this charge the only one of which I can be justly accused by him, I plead guilty — however conceived that the Italians are pretty well aware of their right to retaliate the animadversions on their manners, prejudices and calamities with which english turrists by virtue of their twofold authority of bookmakers and eyewitness think proper to acquaint all mankind; — and that the Italians not being allowed the same freedom of travelling and publishing are more unmerciful in their reprisals on ridiculous foreigners or unlicensed sportmen who shut more eagerly on the hares and partridges, of a jewish stock–jobber promoted by the exchange to the rank of cunning gentleman. Indeed since for my own part I feel deeply grateful for the liberal hospitality I constantly enjoy in England and I have often occasion to give introductory letters, I always pay an anxious attention not to recomand any englishman who was likely to become a fair game for ridicule — so the note of my visitor remained unanswered; and although now and then I remembered my incivility, I lost all recollection of his countenance, and his name. — After the last of nearly four years he reappeared to join a kind of conspiracy of certain men who under the name of translators and copyists were instinctly prompted to fly, one after the other like ravens on the wound of a horse.

The late tragicomedies of Italy had compelled me, to resign even the hope of being buried near my forefathers — and to begin life again and become pupil in a foreign language after the age of forty, with no better prospects than redeem my remaining years from penury by renouncing the calling and language to which the whole of my past existence has been so fondly and so manly devoted. My pursuits have been generously encouraged by the love of my countrimen (I feel conscious, I say this without either modesty or pride) not so much on account of [....]

[4] [....] still with me the servility of toiling was encreased, as its earnings were courtailed and its merit, if there was any, was all forfeited through the necessity of publishing my foreign drudgery in english. Let however my admiration and gratitude be publicly expressed to more than one amongst the men of great parts and genius in England.

They generously offered to translate for me, and some one actually condescended to perform a task the more uneasy and ungrateful as it lies far below the reach of minds accustomed to higher pursuits. The favour being such as to admit of no competent retribution, not even from the most devoted gratitude, — I felt bound always to decline it; and when it was forced, as it were, upon me, I disclaimed that I could ever want it again.

Mr. Henry Coliar has been the first, and translated for me, as a partner interested in the concern, and is still the only one whose name I can write in full letters. But I must call not my translator a man in whom I lost at once a scholar, a gentleman and a friend. His cheerful assistance reconciled me with the servility of my task; — his constant society for the course of eleven months prevented me from perceiving that my home was too large for me alone, — and his kindness was always watchful on the sorrow which the public as well as domestic calamity of that year in Italy, imposed upon me to feel and bear without any expectations for remedy. But he was gone. I welcomed him lately on his return from the continent only to bid him Adieu again for a longer absence — and when I informed him that his warnings on my future translators and copyists have been more than fulfilled, he answered — “This was the only ansiety that during my absence I felt on your account”.

[5] hich I did before hand at the rate of ten guineas per printed sheet; — but I was called also to deliver an equal sum, or a bill of exchange into the hand of his attorney — having promised, and endeavouring to do what I could to deliver a french family from the jail” — and retourning from the country with the intention to do my best, I found a letter in which he shortly declared to scabe the matter with his attorney to him he has delivered my letters. The attorney therefore did not lose time to summon either to pay, or to be arrested. He inlaughed, — the translator took fond oath friend to enable him to take the insolvent act.

[6] [....] now, dear Sir, should you have it at hand, take the trouble to look at the Sophist of Plato I whose works I have not by me, and you will set right any alteration of mine in the following extract which I must quote and translate from memory — Indeed Socrates answered if it be really so that he does not evince any shame, I am at a loss what sort of tutor I would recommend for your son — “Tell at least”, replied the father, what you would do yourself were it the case with your own son? — For my own son, Socrates answered, I should privately request the magistrates to put him under the tutorship of some honest jailor. — Friend said the Father this I have already done more than once; but the magistrates let him lose again since they cannot bring home to him the crime of sacrilege or of parricide, and the like”. — Faith, quoth Socrates, the case is not an easy one; — however I have read, I believe, somewhere in Homer:
If clad in impudence mankind he braves
Then tell it loud, that all the Greeks may hear.

[7] [....] and distressed my feelings to death. — But they shall do it then for the last time; for they will appear absolutely unworthy to be believed, — and then let them talk and write as they please.

However should I thus succeed to have done for ever with the gentleman of the Temple and his fellows, still I will not easily redeem my name from the charge of having brought myself in contact with such people; — and I daily hear from every quarter that nothing can justify an honourable meeting between a gentleman and a Knave. I knew this long ago; — I knew even more, — since the necessity under which I was to employ translators and copyists afforded me thousand occasions to observe during more than three years the human heart as it is modified in halfgentlemen and halfscholars. The contrast between them and english gentlemen and english scholars, added interest and impartiality to my sad observations. Let my grateful admiration be expressed to more than one amongst the men of parts and genius who generously [....]

[8] [….]which they are unable to perform — of insisting on emoluments which they have not deserved — and of aiming at distinctions which they can never obtain. Thus almost all young litterary adventures hunting fortune and fame through pamphlets, newspapers and magazines can not but grow beggarly quacks, and barefaced impostors. The garb they assume of professional authors induces them to think that they really are what they are interested to appear; — and by endeavouring to impose upon others, they only succeed in imposing upon themselves. But as soon as their claims to celebrity are utterly defeated, their enraged vanity dwindles into a lust for notoriety. They are quarellous, adventurous, they are instinctively prompted to varnish the falsehood, which can only gratify their passion with some appearance of truth, which, if unmined, cannot but disappoint it; — their instinct, seconded by habit, has improved their skill; and animated by success, has dreadened in their mind the discriminating faculty between truth and falsehood —— they are unintentionally calumniators; and whenever some among them happen to deal in that species of small litterature which publish the printed scandal, and conceals the handwritting they are certainly dreadful opponents and still more dreadfull guests.

My own disposition and national manners rendered ten times more dangerous my long connexion with some of them. I knew enough of the litterary adventures of my own country not to be cautious with those who were quite strangers to me. My precautions however have been confined in checking their expectations of establishing themselves in my house, and of becoming acquainted through me with my friends. But while I thus exasperated their vanity, my childish good nature, and franckness, enabled them to take advantage of my easiness in money matters, and reconnoitre the points more open to them for a future attack. They have perceived that, however I was learned in the characteristics of whole sets of men, I was easily as I shall always be betrayed both by a natural [....]
[9] A Letter to No Body
for the information of all persons concerned in a late duel, as well as in several chalenges and provocation, to chalenge, —
By Ugo Foscolo.

«Indeed», Socrates answered «if it be so that he does not feel ashamed I am at a loss what sort of Tutor I might recomend for your son». — «Tell me only, replied the man, were you in my situation, what remedy you would resort to» — «I should, quoth Socrates, request the Commonwealth to put my son under the tutorship of some jailor». — PLATO in the Sophist .

[10] This I have done, quoth the man, but the magistrates soon after reliesed him, telling that they would not keep in custody longer unless he be indicted for murder. —— Faith, said Socrates — The case is puzzling — however I read somewhere in Homer —
If clad in impudence mankind he braves
Then tell it loud that all the Greek may hear!

Sir, —— The nature of the inclosed letter will justify my application to you, — and I hope that you as an impartial editor and a gentleman will insert it in The Times of to morrow, (and should it not be practicable) — the next day. Mr. William Wallace and Mr. Sinclair Cullen who assisted me as seconds, live in the Temple, the former 1. Elm Court; and the latter in the Cloister; they have been already put at the trouble to contradict viva voc the report that I did fire —— and that the shot was not returned; — but I will not suffer them to take notice with their signatures of the paragraph alluded to, as Mr. Wallace is on the eve of taking his oath as a Barister and his name in the newspaper on account of a duel may be injurious to him at this moment. — I inclose you also a copy of the paragraph as you may have not seen it — and if its non–insertion in the Times has been unintentional, I beg of you to accept my thanks. — I hope I shall have no occasion to trouble you again about the matter, — although there is a species of vanity, which rather than starve, submits to feed on disappointments and disgrace.
Believe me, Sir,
Your very obb.dt obblg.d serv.t etc.

ps.p: P.S. — I think proper to add a few lines in my own handwritting as an additional warrant of the statement; should you not be found by the bearer, I take the liberty of requesting you of a short note; — but in case you be at Home, the bearer is an individual in my service in whom I place the utmost confidence, and, however a foreigner, he will correctly report a verbal message —

dateline.date: 1 Elm Court Tuesday Ev.g 6 ½ o'clock [Dec. 2.nd 1823].

div1.p: Dear Foscolo, — I shall send the following notification to the Morning Herald. viz.

“We copied into the Herald of Monday, from a Sunday paper, a paragraph relating to a duel, the particulars of which we are informed, were incorrectly stated. M.r F. — desires it to be stated, that he merely received his adversary's fire, and, addressing himself to the persons present, said something to the effect that he should not deign to return it — That upon this the matter ended, — but without the least approach to or attempt at any amicable understanding between the parties”.
It remains for you to exercise your own discretion whether you think it necessary to address a statement of your connexion with Graham to any of the papers — I am dear Foscolo
Yours truly etc.

Dear Foscolo — Reflexion to day confirms my first impression of yesterday — that you took the right and loftyest way with your malefactor — I still think that you should not take legal proceedings against him for the assault — first because after having him called out — i. e. taken the law into your own hands, the law would not afford you the gratification of any material punishment to him and second because the trial would lead to the exposure of an historiette not dishonourable but ridiculous. I still think too that you would do well to prosecute him as a swindler, if the facts and evidence of them be sufficient to convict him or at least to secure you from the danger of becoming liable to him in damage in case of your failure in prosecution. Collect all your facts — and the names of persons who will prove them — and the correspondence between you. Then send me a note and I will come and examine them or lay them before some wise and learned friend for his opinion. If you take a single step towards prosecution without this — you will expose yourself to the risk of being prosecuted — and to ensure your success, take care if possible, that he shall have no suspicion of your intention, till you are ready to act. He deserves to be made infamous before the public.
Yours — etc.

My poor Foscolo, — What are you about? What is all this history of fighting a duel? Is it true or not, and what was the cause of it, if true? — You know probably of the melancholy scene which we were called to witness on our return from Shropshire — We remained in town with my poor afflicted Sister, till all was over, and we then brought her and Mr Bouverie down here. Mr Bouverie was obliged to return to London last Friday, but my Sister remains with us. — She is in the deepest affliction for the loss of her only Son, as you may well imagine, but as her health has not materially suffer'd, I hope to see her more composed in the course of a little time. The first thing that happen'd after so much misery was Lord Dacre's having a dreadful fall hunting — He broke one rib if not two, besides bring bruised an hurt all over. He has suffer'd very much, and is still confined to his room — but his Physician assures us he is recovering in the best manner possible, and will be able to come down stairs next week. — Thus you see how sadly we have been engaged since you heard something of us, and now I beg to hear something of you — How you are in health, what you are doing in the literary way, and why you fight duels. How are your eyes too, if you please? — I am engaged all day in answering letters of enquiry from my Sister's anxious friends, and also concerning my poor Lord since his accident, so I cannot now enter into any chat with you. — Let us hear of you and believe me ever
Ys sincere friend etc.

Sir — Though an entire stranger to you I trust that I may be excused addressing you on the present occasion. To be thus assailed, however, is one of the effects of your literary reputation, and as I am glad of an opportunity of shewing my respect for your talents, I herewith beg the present to you a copy of my translation of your Tragedy of Ricciarda. Poetry and painting form the occupation chiefly of my leisure hours, although there can hardly be a less literary place in the world than Calcutta, but I was so much pleased with the classical manner in which you have embodied the characters in that work, that I resolved upon an attempt to introduce them to the English reader. Imperfect as the translation is, and feebly as many of the passages are rendered, I trust it will prove in some degree an acceptable tribute to distinguished merit. A few lines of the original are omitted, and some lines superadded, having, after translating the Tragedy, gone over the whole as an English work, without refering again to the Italian, as I was afraid of imbibing some of the Italian idiom.

I at the same time take the liberty of offering to you my translation of the first Canto of Ricciardetto make in 1818. I find that Lord Glenbervie has since published (in 1822) a translation of the same Canto. I shall be happy to hear further of your literary success, and beg to subscribe myself, with cordial wishes for your prosperity.
Your most obedient servant etc.

ps.p: P.S. — My Agents in London, Messrs. Bareth, Farquhar, Crawford & C.o will transmit to me any communication you may feel disposed to favor me with. I have almost completed a translation of Tassonis Bucket and intend publishing it with characteristic designs.

div1.p: As soon as I received your last note, I went to M.r W. to propose a contradiction by us of the paragraph in the Morning Herald and to request him to give my name with his own to the Editor — as responsible for the contradiction to any party concerned. I have since seen to the Herald as you no doubt have also — and tho' the double contradiction makes a little confusion — one thing is clearly shown — all the truth that was necessary for your dignity. — To connect your name further with the squabble or with the persons, will have a very different effect from that you seem to anticipate. To have been under the necessity of treating the affair as serious or one of honour or the persons as your equals — was unfortunate and disreputable and you will find any further connection of hostility or amity equally disreputable. You may talk of pride and feel as much as you please — but you will only prove it and shew yourself a proud gentleman by dissociating your name and self as quickly and quietly as possible from your opponents. My advice must be sincere and well weighed because I think my own reputation concerned along with yours — not to be connected in print — writing or talk with the people or the story and I don't think that your name has power to save either you or myself. I beg you my dear F. to consider — that I cannot fail to estimate more correctly than you — the effect of those things — and persons which are all natives to me and foreigners to you. Choose the highest and most accomplished gentleman of your acquaintance for our judge and I am sure he will decide in favour of my advice and if he is willing as I am to deserve your friendship be risking it, he will tell you that folly and ignorance (ignorance of English mankind) brought all this trouble upon you and that your best way to get out of it and keep out of it with honour and ease is to put entire faith in your faithful “Aristarchus and Seneca”.

I shall come to exchange praise or blame with you before the wall is over — and pass an evening with you in Digamma Cottage — and shall hope to find you are spending your time more profitably and famously than in writing a prose Dunciad or Blackguardiad — or repeating anybody's scandals or publishing anybody's confidences —— or troubling yourself about any bodies calumnies.

Madam — I find your letter on my table, — and it must have been brought by the postman a few moments after I started for Mitcham where I remained two days only. — I felt, and deeply felt, for the loss sustained by your sister — one of the few women whom I should have choosed for a wife, for a sister, for a daughter, and for a mother — I felt her affliction, — I should have wished to seat near her in deep silence, and to listen to her complaints, without uttering a word of consolation; — for in such an affliction there is none, — and those friends who think it proper to forward a letter of condolence are more eager to perform a duty, than wise in administering balm to recent wounds. The poor young man has been unfortunate indeed! Still heaven has not reserved to him the everlasting calamity, to which I am doomed myself, of continually remembering with bitter sorrow, the want of a mother; — even now at the age I am — and now I want mine more than ever; — for there are mothers whose kindness, whose virtue, whose very words and conversation are not to be met with in any human being. Tell Mrs. Bouverie, in case she mentions my name, that my mother always warned me “to prepare myself for the heaviest of blows, — that of renouncing all hopes of seeing her, of hearing from her again in this world — And that the distress I must some day or other feel and bear for such a loss was her only real anxiety on my account” — Tell then your sister that she is now, at least, delivered from such an anxiety — and her son from finding himself in my sad situation. — Having made lately a point not to read any newspaper lest I should feel ashamed of the notoriety courted foolishly and basely enough by some body else, I was not informed of the accident of Lord Dacre until the morning. I left town, — and on my returning I intended to write to Mrs. Sullivan for some correct account of it, when your letter relieved me from all fears; — indeed there is not friend of mine whose fondness of foxhunting does not make me fear that one day or another he must undergo some dangerous fall from his horse. But as an English perfect gentleman and a nobleman too, feel himself bound to risk a portion of his income in contest for elections, and some of his limbs in pursuing an animal in order to leave it to the dogs, I thank heaven that our Lord's accident turned out rather a painful than a dangerous one. — As to the duel every thing is over, I hope. — The fellow being connected with newpapers concerns and periodical publications caused an article to be published to palliate the contempt he underwent; — but my seconds compelled him to publish a retractation, with which I ought to be more than satisfied. — However I send you a letter which I intended for a gentleman to whom I owed the introduction of two of them. — Nevertheless since the Hero of the duel ended by exposing himself and now enjoys the notoriety he deserves and wished for, I keep back my long letter; — indeed, after all silence is the parent of tranquillity and dignity. The perusal however of my statement will give you an insight of the soul of certain characters quite unknown to you, and were I a Fielding, I easealy might find enough in the whole of the two years wilanies to make a second Jonathan Wild; — but without Fielding's genius I have more taste, and the despicable wretchedness of the human heart ought to be left in its dark recesses. I trust my Novel will be at least the book of a gentleman, and since I have made up my mind either to translate myself, or to starve and beg as my Master Dante, — the whole of my novel shall be written in English by me alone, with the exceptions of some grammatical and idiomatical corrections, which I hope some friend will attend to, without expecting to be paid, and afterwards to be allowed to shoot over me. — Therefore the long letter may serve you as a specimen of my English, which I hope will improve, as I shall never think, nor write nor read, nor talk but in English. The contents of the letter, of course, ought to remain within the walls of the Hoo; — and as soon as you find it convenient to give me the favour of your hospitality and your society, you may return it to me — or either burn it, or keep it as you like best; — since indeed it is a curious thing, although I have alluded in it to the three fourths of the facts. Now, Milady, I must take my leave, and ask your pardon for this long chat, — long as usual — and request you to have the kindness to acquaint me with Lord Dacre's health; — and to tell all the inhabitants of the Hoo that I feel grateful to them all — and very grateful to your Lord, — and most grateful to you — Thus I am and shall always be your Ladyships most devoted friend and servant etc.

ps.p: P.S. — The long letter alluded to will be sent in two parts, both addressed to Lord Dacre — tomorrow Wednesday without fail —

div1.p: Ciciliano carissimo quanto fratello — Trovo, dopo sì lungo tempo, occasione di ringraziarvi con tutto il cuore e tutta la mente di parecchie lettere vostre sino dalle prime arrivatemi per mezzo del S.r Fox. — Nè altro posso oggi dirvi se non se ch'io vivo, e penso, e sento, — vecchio come pur comincio ad essere, — nelle stesse guise ch'io pensava e sentiva quand'io era giovine e vicino a voi; pero vi amo quant'io vi amava, e l'amore è rianimato dal desiderio di rivedervi. Or addio, Michele mio — siate felice, — e godo che siate ammogliato, nè credo che nella Bibbia vi siano parole più profonde e più vere di quelle Guai a chi è solo! — e ne fo lunga e dura esperienza, — e con assai poca speranza di non Morire Solo. Addio dal cuore —
Tutto vostro ecc.

Madam — I am afraid that you do not relish my long letter — for three reasons, — first, because you do not honour me with any answer to assure me that you received the first eight pages of it, — next, because the letter is more than prolix — and last, because the subject of it is neither moral, nor entertaining. — However, as I promised you the whole of it, and you have not, as yet, explicitly delivered me from my obligation, I send you twelve pages more, and the last three pages which conclude the lunghissima tiritera will be forwarded certainly on Monday next. The reasons of the delay, are many; I have been forced to live my house during three days to pay in the country a visit, which I had quite forgot I had promised to pay — then I was called upon again and again on some business, and obliged to spend two whole days in the Jewish town called the City — and your Ladyship ought to add that my copyst can not go on without me, since my manuscript besides my habitual hieroglyphics had thousand scraps and chasms, because I wrote it tutto d'un fiato in less than two days and three nights, — and then I left it in such a state as to be hardly read by its own author. Had I not made up my mind to keep back the letter, I should have unmercifully cut all its luxuriant parts, and arranged the whole in a better order. But as this second finishing of the work is, at least with me, the most troublesome and show stage of composition, I entreat your Ladyship to read it as it is — if indeed you will have the patience to go to the end of it. — Still I am under the necessity to retract my former condemnation upon it; I wrote you that you might either throw it on the grate, or cut it to make your papillotes — Yet I began to pity so many pages, and I should be glad to have my manuscript back, at your Ladyship's own convenience — as I hope that several of its moralizing passages may be easily adapted to one of my novels, — since your Ladyship must know that I am now going on with my youngest; — the eldest one I have almost translated into English; — and as to the youngest it shall be called a Mulatto English born from a foreigner. The former pages I did send, are from the 1 — to the 8 — inclusive, — and you will find inclosed the 9 — 10 — 11 — 12 — whilst under another cover Mylord will find the 13 — 14 — 15 — 16 — 17 — 18 — 19 — 20. — and thus with the 3 pages more, on Monday, you will have the whole — namely 23 pages.

Now, Milady, were you to scold me and upraid me, and tell me that I duly deserve to be flogged back on account of the style and of the subject of my tiritera, do not suffer me to live without any news of Lord Dacre's health. —— I hope is better, and up, and walking about the Hoo — Still I am
Alla speranza incredulo e al timore.
Therefore be so good as to deliver me from the uncertainty which has ever been the most implacable tyrant of the devoted heart of your devoted servant — Etc.

I have but one moment, caro Foscolo, to tell you both your paquets are safely received — I did not write for 3 reasons — first because I every day write so many letters about Lord D. since his accident, and my poor Sister since her dreadful loss, that I can scarcely get thro' my daily work — 2ly because I every day expected the second part of your letter, and could not judge of the case, or feel in possession of the fact from the first only, and thirdly because Lord Dacre did not wish to read the first part till he had the second, as he says he is more master of a series of facts when he reads the whole tout d'un trait, which he means to do this Evn. I am delighted to find you intend to write your novel in English. The few foreign idioms you may be guilty of will be easily rectified by any friend. — My little possible is at your command. We shall read your whole letter with attention this Evn. From the first part it appears to me that the person who first introduced the «Gentleman of the Temple» to you is the guilty person. — Lord Dacre is much better, but still complains much of his back. My poor unhappy Sister is rather more tranquil. — When she leaves us we shall be happy to see you — While she is with us we do not ask any but our nearest relations and oldest friends — I will write to you again very soon — In the greatest haste
Ever yours truly etc.

Dear Foscolo — Lord Dacre and I have read your long letter with attention and I will return it to you by degrees as I can get franks for the purpose. — Be not vexed when I say it is not in our power to enter into the merits of so intricate a case. — I will frankly own to you that the chief impression left on our minds is that of sorrow — sorrow that the energies of a man of your genius, learning and elevated mind should have been occupied in the manner they have been of late. — We have no advice to give but that you entirely withdraw yourself from such associates and such objects of pursuit — that you, who may command the first society in this Kingdom, should not thus waste your time, your talents, your feelings, and your dignity of character. — This is the language of real friendship, my good Foscolo, even tho' you may hate me for it. — Awake, let me entreat you, as from a fever'd dream — drive all recollection of the past from your mind. — Be yourself again: — above all; move in the sphere you ought to move in — not in one so far far beneath you. —

I hope you will ere long proceed with some work worthy of your literary fame, and write with freer thoughts and renewed vigor. — When you come to us you will perhaps bring us some of your English composition. I find from the letters of our friends, who have been prevented paying us their usual winter visits by Lord Dacre's illness and my Sister's sorrows, that they are coming as soon as we can receive them, in greater number than our rooms will admit. — I will let you know when we have a bed to offer you, as I am very impatient to see you and scold you to your face, more and unguardedly than I can do by letter. —— Lord Dacre is gradually mending, but still suffers from his back, and must be consider'd as an invalid. —— My Sister is somewhat better. Le Roi, la Reine, le Prince et la Princesse de Trebisonde se portent bien et moi aussi. — Le petit Prince will enchant you with his pretty little language. — He is the delight of my eyes and the joy of my heart. — We have never reed the last 3 pages of your letter which you promised by Monday's post “without fail” — but we conclude they cannot contain any thing which can change our sorrow into joy. I will therefore send this and begin restoring the sheets to you, hoping that excepting some passages and high sentiments you will commit the whole to utter oblivion — Believe me
Yours perhaps too sincerely etc.

dateline.date: Mercoledi 24 Dicembre 1823 33, Howland S.t Fitzroy Sq.e

div1.p: Ornatissimo Sig.r Foscolo — Mi scrive da Parigi il Conte Orloff, e mi dice che varj mesi sono le inviò due Favole russe, pregandola, quando ciò le fosse piaciuto, di tradurle in versi Italiani. Non avendo avuto sinora, egli soggiugne, alcuna risposta, desidera ch'io le ne riparli, e ritiri da Lei le suddette Favole, per ispedirle di nuovo a Parigi, nel caso ch'ella stimasse di non tradurle.

Sarei venuto volentieri in tal circostanza a farle una visita; ma sul dubbio di non trovarla, o di esserle di qualche incomodo, me ne sono astenuto. Spero ch'ella vorrà compiacersi di darmi su tal cosa un riscontro. Coi sentimenti della più alta stima ho l'onore di segnarmi.
Di Lei, Ornatissimo Sig. Foscolo, d.mo Servo ecc.

dateline.date: (Lettera scritta dal Foscolo sotto nome del suo copista] [Post 24 Dicembre 1823].

div1.p: Signore — In risposta alla sua lettera al S. Foscolo, io ho ordine di scriverle ch'Egli non ha mai ricevuto lettera o favole Russe dal Conte Orloff — Che se le avesse ricevuto non avrebbe potuto tradurle, — ma che ad ogni modo non avrebbe nè lasciato la lettera senza riscontro, nè tardato a rimandare le favole —
Suo devotissimo Servid. And. Schorno

Madam — Whenever you think it necessary to advise chide and upraid my folly, you are always welcome. I upraid myself ten times more; not with any view of amendment; my days are over to hope for it; but my study, — a sad and a foolish one indeed, — has been, almost from my childood, up to my present gray hair, the human heart; thus I excite my own heart with all sorts of reproachs, and am sorry that I can not actually flog it, so as to enable myself to know through its movements those of the hearts of my fellow creatures. I never expected that either you, or Lord Dacre himself would be able to go through such an entangled matter and decide upon it; — I send you what I did write in haste, — and were I to write it again with the perspicuity of an historian, I am certain that no effectual and definitive judgement could be obtained unless through the verdict of a Jury. But if they do not trouble me again, I will forget, if I can, — and certainly forgive. And fool as I am, I am satisfied to be heureux à ma maniere, car il n'y a point d'autre pour l'etre dans ce bas mond — that is, I went on during more than two years believing, assisting, forbearing, forgiving, suffering without complaining endevouring to redeem men and women about me from the dangers of misery and vice, bearing impositions, provocations, and ingratitude, exposing my hfe and so on —— and always in compliance with my conscience, and with no fear, in the very midst of calumny and slander, to offer the whole of my conduct to the scrutiny and sentence of the whole world. Certainly I ought to be laughed at for my imprudence, but your Ladyship must also allow that however imprudent I may have been, I was compelled by allpowerful necessity itself, to have translators and litterary assistant, and that almost all of them have been introduced and recommended by distinguished litterary characters. — This Lord Dacre will see in the conclusion of the letter, which I send only because I did promise it, knowing and even wishing that you should not trouble yourself any longer with it. I chiefly did send it with the expectation to hear from you and Lord Dacre, if I may venture to write in English, — since the long letter has been scribbled in hurry without the least attention to language, and under such circumstances it may enable you to decide whether the English pupil past forty, can write in his new acquainted language for the printer and the public. The conclusion of the letter was promised by the post of Monday, — and your Ladyship has some reason to scold for the delay; — but I promised THREE pages, because I thought that the remaining of my manuscript will not be longer; — and the copyist having performed his task of the three pages, told me that I must not expect to have it finished in less than five; but that he must go freely to enjoy himself; — (apparently to get drunk) with his friends from Monday evening, until tomorrow morning, to sanctify Christmas with some other of his countrimen residing at Greenwich; — and there he went, until tomorrow — when, if he does not return dead drunk — for he is a bit of a German, — your Ladyship will receive the five pages which form the conclusion of the lunghissima tiritera, — and this letter by the same post. — My respects to Lord Dacre, and compliments and good wishes for the new year to all the inhabitants of the Hoo, and my good wishes will certainly be welcomed when offered through you that make happy every body near you — and even distant from you, like your most devoted grateful servant — etc.

Dear Murray. — Be so good as to send word to the printer that I want the whole of the sheets, of the new edition of Forthys's work, since the one before me underwent so many transposition as to prevent me for correctly quoting the pages of the extracts. — You told me that the interleaved copy has an account of Forthys's life. There is not a word about it; therefore you must either accomodate me with the edition to which such an account may be prefixed, or furnish me with a few particulars about [h]is character and vicissitudes. — I should likewise feel obliged to you for the loan of the Diary of an invalide which I did lend, and was never returned to me; — there is a remarkable passage about Italian women, which I should like to compare and quote with one of Forthys's on the same subject —
God Bless you — Your friend etc.

However the progressive proficiency which I make in your language enables me, and will every day enable me still more, to lessen the labour of my translations; and having already not only collected, but written the first draughts of several papers intended for the Quarterly, I could if M.r Gifford allow their insertion, supply with a series of them, several of the ensuing numbers; I would not make such a proposal, had I not been assured by you, of the favourable reception given to my former undertakings. As for the novel, the whole is written, partly in French, partly in Italian, and a portion of it in English; but as none of it is finished as it should be, I cannot promise the delivery of it before the end of February next, I may pledge myself of its being then quite ready for the press. And, if the experiment will be successful, I hope that by providing amusement for the idle, though I could not expect to acquire the fortune of your great Novelist, I may enable myself to devote the latter years of my life to more durable and useful undertakings. Now, as my determination depends on your answer to this plan, if you assent to it, I may be tranquil for some time, and perhaps happy for many years; in the contrary case, I must speedily take the steps most effectual to deliver me from the giving anxiety, and still nearer approaching disgrace, of my present situation. I cannot rely for the loan on any one but yourself, and I should prefer receiving it through you, rather than from you. —

Dear M.r Murray — Diary and Journal are quite synonimous: Johnson's Dictionary explains Diary by the word Journal; and Journal by the word Diary. Be so good as to make this observation to M.r Matthews. — You will find here a title page according my taste; perhaps I am wrong. M.r Clowes did not send the first sixteen pages — Et apres mon barbare anglais je vous dirai Bon jour en français qui n'est pas meilleur que mon anglais.
Tout à vous. Etc.

Caro Scalvini, — I sei scellini per il water–closet saranno pagati da me; — benchè io abbia già pagato perchè fosse ripulito quando la casa fu lasciata dagli altri inquilini — ed essendo allora la casa in cura di chi serviva gli amici nostri, M.r Green dev'avere adempito al suo debito di lasciare ogni cosa netta e sana come l'aveva trovata. Può darsi ad ogni modo che il water–closet non sia stato ripulito a dovere; — ora è ripulito — e dev'essere restituito in buono stato; — appunto al pari di tutti gli altri mobili–fissi, come camminetti, specchi, (se ve ne fossero), e vetri di finestre. Il water–closet dev'essere tenuto di conto da chi abita la casa; tanto più che è una specie di ordigno facile a guastarsi da chi non sa usarne. Inoltre chi abita non dev'egli pagare lo spazzacammino anche una volta al mese, se a forza di troppo fuoco ottenga più fumo e fuligine in una settimana, ch'altri in sei mesi? Chi avesse servi e figliuoli necessitosi ogni dì di rabarbaro, certamente non potrebbe far senza di chi gli sgombrasse le latrine a ogni poco. — Mentre chiunque come il Furio di Catullo, e la nonna e la madre e la zia di Furio,
quod culus illi purior salillo est,
nec toto decies cacat in anno,
atque id durius est faba et lapillis,
quod tu si manibus teras fricesque,
non unquam digitum inquinare possis.
Certo con sì fatti inquilini non ci sarebbe mai che dire per sapere a chi sta a pagare. — Intanto pagherò io, perchè forse Green non ripulì a dovere. — Addio.

You cannot have lost all recollection of a Manuscript sent to you, about a year ago, with the double request of correcting and inserting it in your periodical work — and you returned it with the proper answer that your Editor distrusted by no means the critic and the correctors all of papers offered for publication. — The author deserved to be so checked the more as he took such liberty towards you only because he saw you once in my house, — and he was so far aware of the impropriety of his application, that he did not become to acquaint me with it. You must certainly remember his countenance and his name, and even the peculiarity of his address, which betrayed a proud [...]

Dear M.r Reading — Could you through your connexions with the gentlemen of the press get a place in any of the daily newspapers for the enclosed letter addressed to the public and particularly to his customers by poor M.r Kelly? Perhaps M.r Baldwin of the Courrier may assist us on this occasion; — by the bye, you always promised, and never kept your word concerning the visit of M.r Baldwin at Digamma Cottage. After his interference in the affair of the Doctor, I cannot send to him an invitation with propriety, — and unless you introduce him, I must loose the very hope of becoming acquainted with him. Not a word of reply from the Maecenas of Conduit Street to my letter about the Essay on Filicaja. — Forgive my English et Adieu de tout mon coeur

Carissimo — Spiacemi dell'affar di jeri; ma io stava indispostissimo, ed ancora
quatit aeger anhelitus artus.

Mi rincresce pure de' tanti errori di stampa, tanto nella parte inglese che nell'italiana, ma io non sarà mai buono a nulla che esige attenzione ed esattezza. Vi ringrazio intanto moltissimo delle correzioni, e me ne varro nella seconda edizione. Vi direi quel che ha detto Hinves poi di voi, quando lui non giurasse di buttar via il biglietto a meno che io non promettessi di tacermene. Donnez lui la question là dessus.
Il vostro ecc.

ps.p: Fra' tanti errori indefensibili in Veneziano, Italiano, francese ed inglese ce n'è che si dovrebbero indossare allo stampatore; come per esempio il verso zoppicante che si doveva stampare da verso mozzo, il quale però lo completterò colla vostra assistenza.

div1.p: Caro Foscolo, —— Vi cercava poi per ringraziarvi della critica che dovete fare della mia traduzione del Furioso nel Quarterly Review , dietro quel che mi ha detto Murray; e ci avete aggiunto un'altra grazia, che mi riuscirà tanto cara che la prima. Però al mio solito, ho dimenticato e questo, e un altro oggetto che aveva visitandovi. Vi portava pure la pallottola da te di cui ti ho bell'e parlato. Ecco il modo di adoperarla. Caricata che è di te, se la mette in una chicchera, e ci si versa sopra dell'acqua bollente. Poi, secondo il colorito che piglia questa, si giudica se la bevanda sia perfezionata.
Il vostro ecc.

My dear Foscolo — I expect A. W. Schlegel to pass this morning with me — As he always talks of you with admiration I think it would be shewing him a mark of my respect and kindness if I could persuade you come and meet him — Have the goodness to let me know if you happen to be at leisure — and disposed to look in upon us about 9 o'clock —
Believe me
Yours very affectionately etc.

My dear Foscolo — I have read your Essays with great attention and with great pleasure, and the only fault I can find is, that in some places, particularly in the Essay on the Poetry, I could have wished you to have gone more into the detail of particular beauties. I confess that where there is really a lively and deep perception of the more minute excellencies of a Poet; there is to me a great charm in that kind of criticism, which analyses without coldness, and points out beauties which may have escaped even the most poetical reader. And I assure you candidly that I know no critic whose opinions I find so entirely coincident with my own notions of what is excellent and beautiful — a consideration which of course gives me great pleasure in finding my own notions supported by such authority as yours, and so well expressed as by your language.
“The bearer of ill tidings
Make but a thankless office”
says Shakespeare, but I must inform you of two errata which I have discovered — in Page 18 in the Italian stampi should surely be scampi and Page 97 in the last word of my translation round should be wound. I think also that there should be a comma at the end of the third line, but it is not very material.
Believe me with great regard
Ever very truly yrs etc.

lg.l: Oh mine own Italy! Though vain twill be
To speak of all those mortal wounds,
That on thy lovely form too–frequent shall I see —
Well did all–provident Nature fence our land,
The bulwark of the Alps She bade raging
Between us and the frantic German stand.

div1.p: My dear Foscolo — I am delighted with your Essay, if the others are equal to it, it will form a perfect and admirable comment on Petrarch —
Believe me ever most sincerely yrs etc.
Povero Foscolo! — Lord Dacre dit — “on no account take the smallest notice of John Bull's impertinence and nonsense” —

Je pense que la traduction de «Chiare fresche» de Sir W. Jones est absolument mauvais, aussi mauvais que mon amour propre le pourrait desirer — absolument anglais et ne ressemble en rien a l'original. — Enfin — abominable. — Mais ne repetez pas ce que je dis, car c'est un grand homme et moi je suis une petite femme — Mon «grand homme» ressemble un peu au — “Brutus is an honorable man” de Marc Antoine dans la tragedie de Shakespeare. — Entre nous on n'est pas poete pour etre «grand homme». Lord Byron est poete mais non pas grand homme. — Adieu. — Soyez avare jusqu'a ce que vous soyez encore une fois libre de prendre votre essor, et prenez soin de vos yeux,
Votre Maman etc.

Dear Foscolo — À force de vouloir trop faire souvent on ne fait rien — Lady Holland ever since the arrival of your kind letter and valuable present has been meditating a letter of thank to you in which she meant not only to express her sense of your flattering attention to her but all that the perusal of the work itself suggered to her about Dante Petrarch Poetry etc. etc. now so many for to have class without a letter that she desires me to say she is ashamed of write so tardy as acknowledgement of your present — She has read it or rather devoured it however with great pleasure, and no wonder, for is so much originality of thought, pertness of observation as well as agreable information on it, that it makes me hope that you will give the public some more of it and continue your dissertations on the character and writings of other great Italian Poets — Berni Ariosto Tasso and even Marini who if deficient in taste, was I have always heard a man of great genius whose defects as well as beauties had great influence on the literature of his country and thought that, on the taste of Europe — England and Spain in particular — How very good Lady Dacre's translation of the verses you quote are? — Have they been published or did she furnish you with them? — They seem to me to be excellent — I hope you are quite recovered — Charles who is here and not quite well, is full of gratitude for your attentions to him — Will Greece succeed bet– ter than Italy? — God grant she may —

Eccoti il mio scartafaccio. Io ho sempre creduto che qualunque scrittore per affascinato che sia sul merito delle proprie cose, sia però sempre il primo a riconoscere nel fondo del proprio cuore o l'intera debolezza delle medesime, o almeno il lato ove pecchino. Almeno a me è sempre succeduto così, anche nei piccoli scritti che presentavo al ministro quando ero impiegato nelle Finanze. Ora con questa persuasione nell'anima, mi permetto dirti, che non sono scontento del mio lavoro, s'intende già della materia, e non dello stile, o dell'ornato, che ho pochissimo lavorato, sapendo che dovea soggiacere a necessario cambiamento sì per trasportarlo in altra lingua, si per rifonderlo come più a te piaccia. Ardisco garantire la verità, e la sicurezza delle cose positive che in esso troverai siccome pure ho fiducia di poco errare nella prattica di tutte le cose appartenenti a Teatro. La materia mi pare nuova e dilettevole e sotto le tue mani potrà divenire anche più interessante.

Ho parlato spesso di me: tu lo perdonerai a quella volontà che ha ogni autore di procacciarsi nome: ma in questa circostanza vi è anche un principio d'interesse, che potrebbe risultarne per me. Ti prego dunque di non dimenticarmi, e ne confido sull'amicizia, ed attaccamento che mi dimostri. Sarà amore pel mio sistema, ma a me non parrebbe sì difficile che il governo Inglese prendesse parte un giorno o l'altro nel sostegno di un Teatro nazionale; e se non altro mi parrebbe che si potesse ascrivere a pregio di novità nel proporlo, o almeno parlarne. Anche il cenno sul teatro la Domenica è ardito, ma so che da molti Inglesi si desidera.
Del resto io mi tengo a nullo, e ti faccio arbitro di fare quel che vorrai de' miei fogli.

Ove però ne nasca un articolo in qualche giornale (sia il Quarterly review , od altro) vedi se fosse possibile di averne un esemplare staccato per me; fossero anche fogli di correzione! In ogni caso salvami il mio originale dopo averlo ridotto, e tradotto, che bramerei di conservare, non avendone copia. A proposito il mio carattere sarà egli intelligibile?

Scrivo sul tuo tavolino. Mi dicono però che forse sarai qui domani di ritorno. Cercherò di tornare da te più presto che potrò: ma se capiti in Città procura di venire da me dovendo communicarti qualche cosa che ti potrebbe essere utile: venendo però cerca che ciò sia più a buonora che puoi per trovarmi; io sono fuori di letto dalle otto di ogni mattina. Per tuo governo Lunedì o Martedì partiró da Londra per Cheltenham ma per soli 15. giorni. Addio.
Il tuo aff.mo ecc.

Dear Foscolo — It is a pleasure to scold you: you take it so well, — and yet your good nature disarms me. — There is much reason in what you say in your last letter, yet my sole wish is that you should entirely forget the existence of all the personages who figure in your long letter, and all the objects of interest alluded to in it. — I hope, and trust and entreat into the bargain that you will not suffer yourself to be imposed upon, and preyed upon any more, but keep little income clear, and make as much more as you can by your talents, and live comfortably and respectably in your own elegant abode, and visit your friends at times, and in short spend your days as a learned Englishman ought to do. You write English so well that I really do not think you can ever want another translator. The few tournures that are not perfectly English any friend can point out — They do not affect the style at all. — In your letters to myself I do not perceive one expression that betrays the foreigner. — At the end of your long letter you speak as if it were possible you might be induced to publish it, let me conjure you never to think of such a thing. A clear simple and succinct statement of facts is all an english public would attend to. — Nous sommes moqueurs, and any display of an individual's feelings and sentiments would not be well received. — But let the whole vexatious thing pass into oblivion I entreat you, and begin the new year being your former self, before these low unworthy troublesome people disturbed your tranquillity. Let me hope too, that you never will again be involved in pecuniary distress. — In short my good Foscolo I wish you to be respectable and happy — respected I should say, for if I did not think you highly respectable I should not be thus anxious for your welfare, and thus bold in declaring without reserve my impressions in what has passed. — The house is so full of company, and my attention is called so nyany ways at once, that I must take my leave, wishing you a happy new year, and all sorts of good things. — Believe me
Ever truly Yours etc.
Lord Dacre is a great deal better.

Dear Foscolo — Our engagements in the neighbourhood, which have taken us from home will be over next Tuesday. From that day till the 26th we shall be quiet (except dining out on Wedi) till the 26th, when we go to Cassiobury. — We shall be in Town if our house can receive us the 2d or 3d of Feb. — Thus you have la carte du pays and I hope will be able to come to us from Tuesday to the 26th ___ We are now setting off for Sir Gore Ouseley's for a day, so Adieu. — As this is a mere summons I shall say no more at present, but reserve all my friendly scolding for the chimney corner — Lord Dacre is better —
Ever sincerely Yrs etc.

ps.p: Bring some part of your Novel pray, and we will see about your English which I expect to find astonishing.

div1.p: Dear M.r Murray. — The action for which you have bailed me with M.r Rossi is to begin tomorrow — 23rd — and to resist it without further trouble to myself or my bails the money ought to be deposited; — should you think that the manuscript I send you may be inserted in the Quarterly I will feel obliged to you by your delivering to the bearer the retribution it may be worth of, since tomorrow before noon I must call upon my lawyer. Believe me that it is with the utmost repugnance and sorrow that I have recourse again to your friendship, and I should have not done it were not that I trust of being soon out of the necessity of troubling my friends — Adieu —
Your's faithfully — etc.

Madam — Certainly my long silence must be construed at Whitton Park into an unaccountable neglet of social duties, — whilst I feel that I am liable even to the suspicion of ingratitude. Still I can never forget the reception I met with at Whitton, and there is scarcely a place that I ever left with more regret. I often remember the kindness of all its inhabitants, and sometimes too the very words of each of them. I went away in the hope to pay soon a morning visit at Whitton; but no sooner I reached my home that I was welcomed with troubles — and some of them quite unexpected, and others of such a new description to me, that I was at a loss how to act. When I received your invitation I wished to avail myself of them, — while indeed I was aware that I should hardly be able to leave my house, not even for a single day. My answering therefore has been put off from day to day, until I began to feel ashamed, and afraid that my thanks would already be returned too late. So childish is the human mind, particularly when some circumstance compels it to labour under a perplexity which cannot but become habitual, and make us act with irresolution in every thing. I trouble your Ladyship with this piece of philosophy, which indeed does little honour to my firmness, — not so much with any view to exculpate my silence, as to persuade you, and Sir Benjamin and the young Ladies that I am not an ungrateful visitor; — and I feel still more grateful since the last letter which has encouraged my apology. I beg your pardon for my English; — but my penmanship is so bad, that I prefer to be laughed at for my style rather than become troublesome to your eyes. —— The four pots I was able to send want only to be sheltered from the frost, and kept in doors without any fire; I should have sent more particularly two rhododendron, — but they are in large pots and too heavy to be carried by a man. There are not, as yet, in this part of the world, the travelling wagons so convenient for my smoky neighbours the Londoners. I may perhaps be able to call some morning, and then I will bring them with me; and take my leave, since I am afraid I must quit England, and endevour, before I return here again, to settle some way or other my concerns with the Austrian in Switzerland; — if however the Swiss cantons are not already desired to send me away. Now, Madam, I beg your pardon for my long letter, and believe me really your grateful — devoted Servant — etc.

Caro Mami — Dite due parole (nè state a scrivere) su la vostra salute al S.r Andrea. Non ve ne date pensiero, perchè non dev'essere che un po' d'indigestione; — bensì abbiate cura a quello che mangiate. Oggi forse dovrò passare dalle vostre parti, — forse no; perchè ho mille faccende da riparare.
