Intanto vi avverto che per guadagnare tempo ho dato a un galantuomo un biglietto diretto a voi per poche lire da pagarsi con certo danaro che s'ha da riscuotere. Fatemi il piacere di dirgli che voi avete eseguiti nella passata settimana i pagamenti ch'io aveva registrati, — e che ora sino a SABBATO PROSSIMO non potete riscuotere; bensì che SABBATO può tornare, e sarà puntualmente pagato. — Io avrò cura che sia pagato prima, e che non torni da voi; — intanto senza questo mezzo termine io non potrei liberarmene, — e avrei il galantuomo mattina e sera alla porta. — Addio di cuore. —
L'amico vostro ecc.

Dear Sir, — You will find inclosed a list of seventeen volumes belonging to several travels through Italy, which I now return you, since I have no further occasion for them. The other books you had the goodness to furnish me with, will be sent to you as soon as I have put in such a state as to be printed the different papers intended for the Quarterly and of which I have written the draughts. — Thus I hope to balance our standing account for the poor speculation of the Italian Tragedy, and the illfated Book on Parga. In the meanwhile be so good to place to my credit, and in the way of your repayment towards the settling of the balance the amount you think proper of the paper on the Turrists. If it so happen, however, that neither the materials nor the language of that article, are fit for the Quarterly, be so good as to send me a word, that I may think of some other place, to reimburse the expenses for the work on Parga. —
Believe me dear Sir, your sincerely obliged etc.

Dear Sir, — I am not yet able to give you my answer on the subject of your passport, which you would excuse in consideration of this being a most difficult moment to obtain an answer on any subject from the principal public offices. But will you in the mean time favour me with your company at dinner on Thursday next the 12th instead at 7?
Your sincerely etc.
Perhaps you will have no objection to send me the passport with which you came to England. It shall be returned to you in case of no other being to be obtained.

Dear Sir, — I return you your old passport with this. With respect to a new one, pray, let me know whether a passport from the Colonial Office for Malta would answer your purpose; but before I can ascertain whether such a passport will be granted, I must request that you will let me know distinctly — supposing that you have no objection to do so — whether you will be content to go to that Island.
The passport of the Foreign Office are only given to British Subjects.
Sincerely yours etc.

Mio dilettissimo Foscolo, —— Colgo l'occasione di un amico che parte per Parigi, onde dargli una letterina per voi ad oggetto di sgridarvi ed accarezzarvi nel tempo stesso. Dico sgridarvi perchè non solo non mi avete mai scritto, ma nelle vostre letterine ad altri dirette, mai non si trova un segno di ricordanza, mai un saluto per Isabella; ed accarezzarvi poi dicendovi che siete sempre presente alla mia memoria, che il vostro nome e le vostre lodi sono famigliari nella mia casa, e che quanto io posso vi onoro citando spesso i vostri bellissimi versi nelle mie descrizioni delle opere del Canova. Al quale proposito, mi scrivono da Londra che le stanno traducendo, e che già ne sono uscite varie puntate; ma siccome non mi dicono di più, vorrei che mi faceste il favore d'informarvi e di scrivermi, se le traducono così come sono, e se intagliano i rami, o pure se fanno come in Francia ove ritagliano i rami e le traducono, ma ove per verità la testa spesso e la coda non mi appartiene. Fanno inoltre una strana applicazione de' vostri versi prendendo per la citazione Sepolcri, che sieno que' versi da voi scritti per essere collocati in questo e quel sepolcro. Ora appunto che sto facendo la descrizione del modello per Nelson, ho potuto abbellirlo de' versi: — ove clementi / Pregaro i Genj del ritorno al prode / Che tronca fe la trionfata nave / Del maggior pino, e si scavo la bara. Pregovi dunque a scrivermene qualche cosa; e se non vi fosse difficile, vi prego di acquistarmi una puntata di questa traduzione, e con prima occasione mandarmela. Ma intanto che la non facile occasione vi si presenti scrivete. Vi raccomando poi questa mia operetta, della quale sono presso che al termine, essendone già uscite ventisette, o ventotto puntate. Amatela almeno perchè porta si di frequente ripetuto il vostro nome.

Veggo qualche volta la sorella vostra, e sempre Naranzi; sicchè potete credere che delle vostre nuove non sono digiuna. Vorrei sentirvi contento; ma pur troppo è vero che uno scrittore Italiano non è gustato e apprezzato quanto merita che in Italia, perchè altrove poco si studia, e si conosce la nostra lingua. Cosa mai farete in Inghilterra del vostro bellissimo stile, sia che scriviate la prosa od il verso? Se chi parla la lingua non propria dicesi che rimanga con la metà del suo spirito naturale, figuratevi poi chi la scrive! Ed è uno di quei prodigj che voi solo sapete operare, d'essere tanto stimato quanto lo siete nell'estero. Qualunque Inglese, uomo di merito, bene inteso, qui arrivi, o di persona o di fama vi conosce perfettamente; ed è per me un piacere dolcissimo quello d'intrattenermi di voi: piacere che ho frequenti volte anco con l'ottimo giovane Frere.
Pindemonte sta bene, ed ora riposa sopra i suoi allori, dopo la traduzione dell'Odissea. È questo il primo inverno in cui ci ha abbandonati, ma promette di ritornare in marzo.
Monti è vecchio, sordo, mezzo cieco, e tristissimo dopo la morte del suo e nostro Perticari.
Soranzo Tomaetto sta bene e vi saluta, e il mio Giuseppino poi con tutto il cuore.
Se mai vedeste Pesaro e Sanseverino salutatemeli. Addio mio dilettissimo amico addio. Scrivetemi una lunga lunga lettera, che in qualche parte almeno compensi il lungo silenzio. Addio.

Dear Foscolo, — I am very sorry to find you have not had the success you wished with your periodical. It is a thing that requires considerable capital. I fear you will find the plan you propose very irksome to you. The shame of it is nothing. The D. of Orleans brought mathematics in America and it is the best thing one knows of him.

I have to propose to you to write for me a history of Italian literature from the death of Boccaccio to that of Lorenzo de' Medici. When I say a history I mean rather an essay of 50 or 60 pages to insert in some illustrations of the history of Europe I am writing. What which is a short account of the lives and works of the different poets and philosophers who lived between the bright ages of Petrarch and Ariosto. If you would write this and deliver it to me printed in Italian, French of English (or all) I could afford to give L. 100 for it. You would find the books in public and private libraries.
Yours truly etc.
In printing it of course I should mention your name and ascribe it to you.

The proposal I made to you is really one that it will be of use to me you should accept. I shall not fail to finish my work. The language must be that you like best. It is very lucky you have been influenzed upon the subject? I advise you by all means to have Roscoe alone — Lorenzo tho' no great hero runs away with his poor judgment. What can we think of the taste of a person who wishes Ariosto and Tasso had written their poems in blank verse? Au reste Roscoe is an excellent man and you would be sorry to attack him.

Your two periods suit me very well — but I should like and indeed must have them differently divided. The 1.st to the death of Poliziano the 2.d to that of Clement the 7th and you may take 100 quarto pages for the two — more or less — as it happens —
I should like to have the first by the end of April —
Yours truly etc.
I have already written a sketch of the political events of Italy during the life of Lorenzo — I suppose you agree with Machiavel as to the fatal effects of the «onesto ozio» then introduced —

dateline.date: 66. South Audley Street. Monday [1824, primi mesi]

div1.p: Dear Foscolo, — I think you are quite right to adopt the plan of your friends of giving lectures — it is not in this country any way degrading. Campbell and Sydney Smith have done so very lately. As to your houses you have a long lease of them, have you not?

I wish to ask you how you get books to consult upon any subject on which you are not writing for the booksellers — on what you are writing for me for instance — pray answer this forthwith. My father thought your house very pretty — pray come and see me when you come to town. Yrs truly etc.

dateline.date: Rivolta in Gerra d'Adda li 16 Feb.o 1824.

div1.p: Dolcissimo Amico — Dovendo io mettere alla luce in Milano per la fine del prossimo Marzo una mia opera sui Paragrandini, [....] sono ad approfittarmi della vostra esperimentata bontà ed amicizia perchè vi compiaciate di assicurarvi l'incarico di esibire al vostro Stampatore la medesima mia opera, che tradotta in Inglese farebbe anche costà del rumor tanto ed avrebbe un grand'esito, con quei patti e condizioni che voi stimerete per me più vantaggiose, mettendovi a parte delle medesime. L'amico vostro ingegnere Cusi e la bella Rosina di lui moglie, miei nipoti ora stabiliti in Bergamo, i quali vi salutano caramente, mi hanno opportunamente suggerito la vostra persona, d'indirizzarmi a voi come ad uomo chiarissimo in tutte le scienze, mentre qualora vi degnate di adoperarvi, oltre l'accreditare di molto l'anzidetta mia opera e procurarmi anche costà quel buon nome che mi sono acquistato in Italia, sarete in grado di farmene risentire un considerabile vantaggio; per cui vi lascio fin d'ora estesi poteri di conchiudere collo stampatore quel contratto che stimerete a proposito, dandomene però un pronto riscontro del sì o del no per mio contegno. Posso peraltro assicurarvi, che quantunque il soggetto dell'opera mia non sia nella sfera delle vostre occupazioni, non la troverete indegna della vostra protezione.

Ho letta e riletta con grande soddisfazione la vostra bella Ricciarda, che meritamente ha confermato nei dotti l'idea grande dei vostri talenti e del genio sublime che vi distingue nel ceto degl'uomini chiarissimi; e godo sommamente di avere inteso da parecchi carissimi amici venuti da Londra l'altissima stima e considerazione, e mezzi di fortuna che vi siete procurato, colle vostre notevoli produzioni. Possa la Providenza conservarvi a lunga vita per via più decorare la vostra Patria antica madre delle scienze, e l'Italia da cui ereditaste sì luminose virtù.
Se vogliate da questa parte i miei servizi mi troverete sempre quale mi pregio di essere di tutto cuore
vostro aff.mo obbl.mo Amico ecc.

The undersigned is born at Zante in the Ionian Islands, where he still possesses some property inherited from his mother — But as the Islands and his father's family belonged to Venice, the undersigned has been always considered as a Venitian.

In the year 1798 he availed himself of the clause of the treaty of Campoformio by which Lombards subjects were allowed to transfer themselves and their property in the Venitian states under the Austrian government, — and Venitian subjects in Lombardy under the new Republic.
The undersigned since that epoch served in the Italian army against Austria, so that when in the year 1799 Italy was in the occupation of the Austrians and Russians, the undersigned retired at Genoa.

He returned to Milan with the army, and having afterwards refused to take an oath imposed by Buonaparte he become obnoxious to the government; and in 1811 was exiled from the Kingdom of Italy at Florence a city then annexed to the French Empire.
When in 1813 the Austrians threatened the Kingdom of Italy the undersigned returned to the army.
No sooner the Austrians took a military possession of Milan, than the undersigned sent to the provisional government his resignation which was not accepted.

The provisional government at the same time peremptorily required of him an oath of allegiance, — but as the Congress was still sitting at Vienna and had not as yet decided whether Milan, and Venice or the Ionian Islands were to belong to the Emperor of Austria the undersigned thought that the Austrian generals had no right to require any oath of allegiance and accordingly he repared to Switzerland.
Having afterwards obtained an English passport as an Ionian he landed in England, where he lives since the year 1816.

Wishing now to return to the Ionian Islands, the undersigned applies to the British government for a passport, as he has never been either de jure, or de facto a subject to Austria; whilst his right to be considered an Ionian cannot be disputed.

The undersigned engages not to interfere in any thing connected with politics, in whatever may concern the Ionian Islands, — reserving however to himself the right of going in the Greek Continent either as a traveller or as a militáry man for the liberty of Greece.

Dear Sir — The Banker has consented to renew the note of L. 100 which was presented yesterday at your villa. The answer out of Town one of the Bankers Kircks brought to me at 8 o'clock in the evening — and left for renewal in case you do not succeed to take it up must be done immediately on a proper stamp as follows —
Yours affectionately etc.

La petite table aussi que le paquet sont destinés pour Whitton Park, et je vous prie de les envoyer au plustôt et avec le plus de soin possible. Lady Hobhouse en a été deja prevenue. Demain vers une heure je serai chez vous; et si vous serez engagé, j'irai tout seul chez Monsieur Rainy — Adieu de tout mon coeur.
Votre devoué etc.

Milord — Je me reproche de devoir vous troubler si souvent avec mes lettres, mais en me taisant je dois craindre que ne pensiez mal de moi. Je n'est pas oublié le devoir, qui maintenant est aussi le plus fort de mes desirs, de vous remettre l'Essais sur la Litterature du XV siecle; — mais depuis que j'eus l'honneur de vous voir je n'ai pu m'occuper des corrections et des additions que je pense y faire, d'autant plus que je pourrai partir, et l'Essais serait imprimé sans ma assistance — Mais il m'a été impossible de m'occuper de rien; la fievre est retourné avec una inflammation à la poitrine et un rhumatisme aigu à une jambe, et je me suis logé en ville comme il plait a Dieu pour profiter de l'assistance de D.r Holland, d'autant plus que le mauvais chemins ne lui permettroient a sa voiture s'approcher de la porte de Digamma. — Mais aussitot que je saurai en etat je devouerai tout mes moments que pour achever de mon mieux ce que j'ai fait pour vous et avec vous. — Quant au passeport je vous envois Milord la copie d'une lettre que j'ai ecrit a un ami de lord Bathurst; car d'apres d'autres renseignemens je me suis assuré de plus en plus que vos Ministres se sont mis dans la tête que je joue ici double jeu; — et tant que je ne les aurai persuadé qu'ils se trompent, je ne pourrai vivre en paix dans les îles, — ni même être d'aucun utilité en Grece, parceque il parait aussi que M.r Hume and Co. me considerent comme un partisan des Russes; — en meme tems que mes cheres concitoyens les Italiens disent tout haut et impriment que le Ministere Anglais m'a payé pour la soppression de livre sur Parga; — a propos de ce malheureux livre qui devait vous être dedié — je promets de vous envoyé une copie mutilée. Sic voluere Parcae! Quel tems j'ai perdu — sept ans et sept mois en ecrivaillant jour et nuit sans repos, et en ne faisant rien qui merite d'etre nommé. J'ai envoyé ce livre tout incomplet qu'il est a quelcun de Ministre parceque on y trouve la profession de ma foi politique concernant les îles.

My dear Sir — Although I am far from being well, I hope to feel a little better in your company, and some coachmen of the King — as they call themselves — will carry me this evening at your door. Since I saw you I discovered that your Government believe that I have not only favoured what they call the Russian party in the Jonian Islands, but that I am also the author of anonymous pamphlets, and newspaper paragraphs on the subject. I therefore applied to Lord Aberdeen, — and that the matter may be sifted in the Colonial department I wrote him an explanatory letter which I hope he will hand to Lord Bathurst, and thus they will be acquainted with the whole of my political creed concerning the Islands. I certainly cannot — I will not, nor I ought, to go there whilst the Masters of the country consider me as a man of faction. —— Of my letter to [....].

Dear Foscolo, — I inclose you L.d Bathurst's note in answer to your application, which seems to me a fair reply to your request. Wilmot added in conversation that the Ionian government having proclaimed neutrality it would be impossible to recognize in an Ionian citizen the right of violating it; that if you went to the Ionian islands and afterwards chose to go to Greece no one would ask any questions but that if you went to fight in the Greek cause you could not afterwards return to the Ionian islands without incurring the penalties pronounced by law; but that if you went to Greece first, and afterwards took out your citizenship in the Ionian islands no obstacle would be put to your doing so.

It seems to me that this is clear and I must add just. I will likewise say that while you have any thoughts of going to fight in Greece it would be improper to ask or receive any office or pension from the Ionian government as your acts would then compromise the government, but that if you chose to stay in Zante, or come back here an application may fairly be made in your behalf.
You have only to write to L.d Bathurst to ask for a passport as a native of the Ionian Islands.
Yours truly etc.

Miss Matilda Hobhouse has only just received the beautiful edition of Petrarch, which M.r Foscolo was so kind as to send to her some days ago — She hopes however that he could not think she would delay for one moment expressing to him, how much she was gratified by this flattering proof of his recollection of her — She must always value the books most highly on this account, if they were in themselves less valuable and her pleasure in reading the beautiful sonnets will be always greatly increased by the recollection that they were his gift. —
The Miss Hobhouses all hope that M.r Foscolo will soon come to see them — and la Signora Poco curante sends her best thanks for the printed poem, he was so good as to send her some time since —

Caro Santa Rosa — Oggi mi trovo più infermo che mai, — e purtroppo non potrò dirvi, Addio. — bensì s'io dovrò partire, vi scriverò, — e vi scriverò anche se non potrò partire; se credete, date l'indirizzo vostro al S.r Andrea, sì che le mie lettere possano arrivarvi; — se no, me ne informeranno gli amici nostri; intanto vi mando una copia de' fogli che m'è riuscito di mettere insieme della malarrivata Storia di Parga. Serbatela non tanto come cosa rara quanto come memoria dell'amico vostro. — Il S.r Andrea ha ordine di ricevere da voi que' libri miei che vi trovaste d'avere; — ed io farò che riabbiate quanto più presto mi sarà possibile la vostra Miscellanea d'opuscoli ch'ora è in mano di Sir Francis Burdett; sarei andato oggi a ridomandargli il volumetto se non fossi costretto di stare a letto. — De' libri che potrò lasciare per uso vostro innanzi ch'io parta, ve ne ragguaglierò a tempo. Intanto Addio da tutta l'anima —
L'Amico Vostro ecc.

Caro Scalvini — Se siete in casa il S.r Andrea vi dirà dove potete trovarmi, — infermo, e giacente, — se no, venite quando potete oggi o domani, — No 3. South Molton Street vicino a Bond Street, — secondo piano; ma guardatevi bene dal lasciarvi uscire di bocca il mio nome; bensì domandate di M.r Flass, a German gentleman who lives in the Second Floor. — Qui finanche il medico mi conosce per M.r Flass; fate dunque di non chiamarmi per altro nome — Ricordatevi anche che il M.r Flass e il mio abitare per ora in città dev'essere un secreto per tutti da voi in fuori.
Sono stato due volte alla vostra porta giorni addietro nè vi ho trovato — Addio —

Sono andato al Digamma Cottage, alle 11 1/2 — Salgo, percorro le camere, le sì ben note camere, e non vi trovo — La fanciulla mi disse che eravate ammalato — ma dove? — Ella non lo sa — pregai che Andrea mi venisse a dare le vostre nuove. — Se il vostro alloggio non è in tale lontananza che vi sia per me assoluta impossibilità di andarvi a vedere prima dell'ora della partenza, io vi darò l'ultimo adio —
Sono dolente, afflitto, in verissimo cruccio di lasciarvi ammalato, e inquieto, e incerto.

Eccovi il mio indirizzo — Se mai le circostanze vi facessero desiderare alcuni giorni di oscura pace venite a me come ad uomo che vi ama. Le mie strettezze non sono strettezze presenti. Ho due o tre mesi assicurati, forse quattro. Le mie parole sono la voce del cuore. — Io ho creduto alcune volte di potervi disamare quando mi avete afflitto — ma ho fatto sperienza di non poterlo. — Non vi abbandonate. Pensate alla madre, alla patria, alla felice probabilità di una vita migliore dove l'Essere degli Esseri farà giustizia dei malvagi, e dei buoni, dei deboli e dei forti. — Pensate alla madre. Fate quello che essa approverebbe. Nelle calamità convien ubbidire ad un pensiero; quel pensiero della madre sia la vostra ancora di salute —

Scusate questa esortazione, ma io vi scrivo come vi parlerei. — Forse mi esagero le difficoltà delle vostre circostanze — ma io mi rammento le vostre ripetute parole sconsolate, onde non posso essere tranquillo. — Dio ci possa riunire sotto al cielo delle due sole contrade del mondo che io amo, Italia e Grecia, nutrici degli ingrati popoli d'Europa.
Vi abbraccio teneramente.

My dear Sir — I learn from my son Lord John that you are about to quit this Country for Greece, or the Ionian Islands, and I write one line to express my anxious hope that we shall have the pleasure of seeing you at Woburn, before you leave England.
I hope I may congratulate you on the moral and political inclination of the Greek cause, must indulge in a sanguine hope as to the ultimate issue of the contest.
If you purpose to give to the Publisher your Poem on the Graces, before you leave us, it would give me much pleasure to present you with a plate from a finished drawing of my beautiful group.
I remain dear Sir with perfect truth of regard your faithful servant etc.

Milord, — De l'ouvrage sur Parga dont j'eu[s] I'honneur de vous parler je ne puis vous offrir que la partie qui peut être reliée; tout le reste a été imprimé en colonnes, — et ensuite pour ne pas augmenter des frais inutiles, j'en ai suspendu l'impression en feuilles. J'espère néanmoins que même un petit nombre de pages de ce volume suffira, Milord, à prouver, que bien loin d'avoir jamais été l'agent ou le partisan d'aucun gouvernement, j'ai profité de l'événement de la cession de Parga pour examiner les conséquences funestes du nouveau droit des gens qui a été et continue d'être si hautement proclamé par la Russie. Au reste quelque impression que cet écrit pourrait laisser dans votre esprit, je suis certain qu'elle ne pourra être que fort juste; et je serai très satisfait — je vous serai même fort reconnaissant, s'il vous plaira, Milord, d'exprimer là–dessus votre opinion à Lord Bathurst. Par le dernier document incomplet dans le volume (et d'autres pareils devraient le suivre) vous vous apercevrez, Milord, que je n'aurais pu publier le livre sans compromettre quelques sujets autrichiens; d'autres considérations finirent par me faire décider de le supprimer tout–à–fait. Cependant je vous prie de remarquer que je l'avais fait annoncer sous mon nom; — car, par la lettre de Lord Bathurst à Lord John Russell il paraît que l'on m'a supposé l'auteur d'écrits anonymes. J'assure donc Lord Bathurst sur mon honneur que tout en gardant l'anonyme dans le Quarterly et dans l' Edinburgh Review , — parce que c'est leur règle, — je n'ai pas moins suivi má règle constante d'avouer tout ce que j'écris pour le public. Aussi je n'ai jamais fait un mystère de l'article sur Parga que j'ai donné à M.r Jeffrey, et à l'exception de deux ou trois passages qu'il y a ajoutés de sa façon, je serais toujours prêt à répondre pour tous les faits et les opinions que l'on y trouve. Je n'ai publié autre chose à ce sujet. Je n'ai jamais envoyé ni directement ni indirectement aucune ligne aux papiers publiques; et dans les différents débats dans le Parlement au sujet des Iles, je n'ai fourni ni éclaircissements ni papiers, — hormis à Lord John Russell lors de l'insurrection et des exécutions à Santa Maura. L'occasion n'admettait ni ménagement ni délai, et je l'ai fait dans la vue d'arrêter par tout moyen possible la révolte d'un côté, et la sévérité de l'autre. Je ne nie pas d'avoir été en correspondance concernant les Iles avec le Comte de Capo d'Istria même du temps du Congrès de Vienne, et je suis prêt de laisser lire toute cette correspondance. L'on se convaincra qu'elle roule entièrement sur ces deux points uniques. — «I. Les Iles ne se trouveront bien que réunies à l'Angleterre. — II. Il faut les placer moins sous la garde du Ministère que du Parlement Britannique». — Par la narration dans mon livre incomplet, pages 147–185, vous verrez, Milord, que j'étais informé de tout côté de ce qui se passait à ce sujet; — et que je ne pouvais être indifférent sur mon pays natal, lorsqu'il courait le risque d'être livré aux Autrichiens. Mais ayant acquis une triste expérience de la phrase diplomatique Protection, j'aurais désiré que les Iles eussent à dépendre de l'Angleterre comme jadis elles dépendaient de Venise. — Malheureusement dans le traité conclu à Paris sous la garantie de trois puissances, la phrase Protection a été mêlée à la déclaration d'Indépendance, de manière à faire établir dans les Iles un gouvernement militaire sous des formes constitutionnelles. Ainsi ceux qui espéraient plus de liberté qu'un pays faible ne peut en obtenir, ont été assez sots pour réclamer la garantie des puissances qui ont signé le traité; tandis que de l'autre côté le gouvernement Anglais dans les Iles en punissant de telles prétentions avec trop de ressentiment et d'alarme, et en prodiguant les places et les émoluments à ses adhérents, a fini par exaspérer les mécontents. Mais je puis prouver que ma réponse à toutes les plaintes sur ce sujet a toujours été: — de ne point alléguer des droits politiques, — de se taire absolument sur le traité, — de se résigner sans des cris et sans des efforts impuissants au gouvernement tel qu'il était, — et que s'ils avaient réellement des raisons pour se plaindre sur ce qui regardait l'ADMINISTRATION, ils ne pouvaient espérer de remède qu'en faisant constater la vérité des faits au Gouvernement et au Parlement de la Grande Bretagne; car ce remède, quoique fort lent dans ses résultats, aurait été le seul honorable, et le moins incertain. Aussi c'était uniquement dans l'espoir d'exposer la vérité des faits que j'ai inséré dans le livre incomplet que je vous envoie tout ce que je savais concernant la constitution et l'administration des Iles. Cependant si malgré mes avis, ceux qui ont cru avoir été joués par le traité et la constitution et opprimés par l'administration ont exagéré leurs griefs et ont réellement intrigué près de quelque puissance, ce sont des choses auxquelles je suis demeuré absolument étranger; je les ignore; et en ce qu'elles pourraient regarder d'autres individus, je ne saurais ni les admettre ni les nier tout–à–fait. Mais je puis et je dois les nier toute fois que l'on m'en accuse. Les intrigues politiques sont audessus de [mes] talents, et permettez–moi, Milord, de le dire, bien audessous de mon caractère; et quand même une fierté naturelle ne m'aurait défendu de jouer le rôle d'un secret agent en politique, — j'ai acquis assez d'expérience pour savoir que de pareils individus finissent toujours par être les dupes de ceux qui les emploient. Ma vie entière et ma situation présente prouvent assez que toutes mes actions ont été uniquement dévouées à mes principes. Aussi je n'ai point jugé nécessaire de réfuter l'assertion d'une lettre demi–officielle écrite de Corfou et insérée il y a à peu près vingt mois dans le John Bull, où l'on assure «que je suis en Angleterre à la tête d'un comité secret pour soutenir les menées d'un parti russe existant dans les Iles Ioniennes». La calomnie n'a point manqué de faire son chemin, et le soussecrétaire du département des colonies a dernièrement fait sentir que je m'étais rangé avec le parti des intrigants pour la Russie. Mes amis, entre autres Lord Dacre, ont entendu répéter les mêmes soupçons par des individus du parti opposé au Ministère. Ainsi, soit que je reste ici, ou que j'aille en Grèce, il devient maintenant indispensable pour moi de rejeter loin de mon nom une indignité pareille. Il est de mon devoir de prouver aux Anglais que leur hospitalité n'a point été accordée à un intrigant. — D'ailleurs si le Ministère continue d'entretenir cette idée, je demeurerai aux îles comme un homme condamné à être continuellement surveillé, et dont les paroles et les mouvements seraient interprétés par tous les complaisants de la police. Certainement dans un pays où l'on soupçonne l'existence de factions pour l'étranger, la police doit être très affairée, et particulièrement dans les circostances actuelles de la Grèce; et lorsque les soupçons sont fondés sur des bruits vagues, la police est mille fois plus à redouter. Car, Milord, je suis porté à craindre que l'on ait donné le nom de faction russe à tous les individus indistinctement qui croient avoir à se plaindre de l'administration actuelle. Permettez–moi de le répéter; — les plaintes d'un côté, les alarmes de l'autre, — les récriminations et les subterfuges réciproques, les insurrections et les sévérités dérivèrent d'abord du traité ambigu sur l'indépendance et la protection des Iles, et ensuite de la constitution singulière qui a été la conséquence d'un pareil traité. Le comte de Capo d'Istria qui ne partageant pas mon idée de réduire les Iles en colonie anglaise, eut recours à l'expédient de rédiger avec Lord Castlereagh tous les équivoques dont le traité est composé, s'est ensuite aperçu que sans avoir assuré à son pays aucune espèce d'indépendance, il l'avait privé de la surveillance que le Parlement de la Grande Bretagne exerce sur les colonies. Je n'ignore pas qu'il a tenté de réparer sa faute en faisant des remontrances au Gouvernement Anglais — et je lui ai donné en cette occasion toute l'assistance qui était en mon pouvoir, parce que je voyais qu'il agissait plus en citoyen qu'en diplomate, — et il n'a tenu avec moi que le langage d'un homme qui aurait désiré plus de liberté pour son pays, mais qui se serait bien gardé de le soustraire à la protection britannique. Je n'eu[s] jamais la moindre raison de croire que toutes ses actions dans cette affaire ne fussent exactement d'accord avec ses paroles. Si on lui attribue d'autres démarches; s'il avait comme on l'a dit des intérêts de famille, et s'il était l'âme secrète d'une opposition au gouvernement dans les Iles, ce sont des choses qui me sont absolument inconnues, et auxquelles je ne saurais ajouter aucune foi sans des preuves. Quoi qu'il en soit, si je me suis trompé dans le but et dans les moyens, mon but a été celui d'un homme qui aime son pays, et mes moyens ont toujours été de nature à être avoués à tout le monde. Si j'ai tâché de sauver ou du moins de soulager les Pargiotes, — si je n'ai jugé utile ni à la tranquillité des Iles ni à la dignité de la nation anglaise, la constitution que l'on y a donné[e], — si au contraire j'ai toujours souhaité que les Iles fussent plutôt des colonies britanniques, — si je n'ai point approuvé l'administration dispendieuse que l'on y a établie, et les formes militaires que l'on a cru nécessaire d'y adopter — je puis avoir eu — soit tort — soit raison. — Mais mon opposition a été ouverte et honorable; car j'ai constamment refusé de me prêter en Angleterre aux vues du parti qui ne paraissait se servir des griefs des Iles que pour profiter des occasions pour attaquer le Ministère. — Enfin, Milord, ma conduite et mes paroles ont été constamment conséquentes; car dans cette lettre et dans le livre qui l'accompagne vous remarquerez les principes et les idées que vous m'avez entendu professer depuis le soir que j'eus l'honneur de vous être présenté chez Mr. Knight.

Ainsi, Milord, j'espère de m'être justifié d'avoir publié des écrits anonymes, et d'avoir intrigué en politique; et je finirai en vous demandant pardon du mauvais français et de la longueur de cette lettre.

Madame, — L'extrait d'une lettre qu'on m'attribue dans Le Star de Dublin du 28 Fevrier, et que l'on a reimprimé dans d'autres papiers, est une imposture. Je la mepriserais, comme j'ai fait de tant d'autres qui n'en voulaient qu'a moi seul. Mais puisque dans cette occasion l'on abuse de mon nom pour vous attaquer, les egards pour la verité et la justice, et surtout pour votre sexe m'imposent de declarer, «que je n'ai point ecrit ni une telle lettre, ni jamais aucun mal que l'on pourrait citer contre vous». Et si vous croyez qu'il vaille la peine de devoiler l'imposture, vous etes, Madame, en liberté de faire de cette declaration, tout usage qu'il vous plaira.
Daignez, Madame, me croire
Votre très obeissant serviteur etc.
Regent's Park, Thursday, March 4, 1824.

Madam, — The extract of a letter attributed to me in the Star, of Dublin, 28th February, and which has been reprinted in other Papers, is an Imposture! I should despise it, as I have done so many others if it aimed at me only — but as, upon this occasion, my name has been used to attack you, the respect I owe to truth, to justice, and, above all, to your sex, obliges me to declare that I have never written the aqbove mentioned letter, nor one injurious word that could be cited against you. Should you think it worth while to notice this imposition, you are, Madam, at perfect liberty to make whatever use you please of this declaration.
Deign, Madam, to believe me
Your very obedient servant etc.

Questi ventinove scellini sono quanto ho potuto raccogliere, con perdita di quasi tutta la giornata di uno dei miei copisti, vendendo trentadue tomi di libri che mi costarono da più di dodici lire e mi erano necessari appunto in questo momento. Vi prego dunque perchè un'altra necessità tanto insistente non arrivi da un'ora all'altra, di farmi avere il nostro conterello, da che io non ho tenuto sempre registro; e fra i giorni 16 e 20 del mese corrente vi manderò quel più che vi devo e sei lire per il maestro di musica; e di ciò vi prego d'avvertirlo, tanto che non si rammarichi e si disperi.

Monsieur — Je vous remercie infiniment de l'obligeante lettre que vous avez pris la peine de m'adresser, au sujet d'un paragraphe dans le «Star» du 28 fev.r ou l'on s'est servi de votre nom pour repandre une calomnie aussi ridicule que meprisable — Quant à moi, Monsieur, croyez, je vous prie, que je n'ai jamais pu vous avoir attribuée pour un seul instant, une si grosse et mechante bettise. Lorsque quelque un me l'a repeté (que je n'ai jamais vu «Le Star») j'etais bien persuadé qu'une pareille calomnie venait, ou de vos ennemis, ou des miens, et que le tout etait fabriqué à Londres; — mais tant cela m'a paru absurde, qu'au lieu d'en prendre la moindre notice, je l'avais intierement oublié jusque au moment de l'arrivée de votre lettre! —

Si cependant il est vrai que cette imposture soit re–imprimé dans d'autres journaux plus respectables et plus repandus que le Star, peut–etre feriez vous bien Monsieur par un mot dans le Morning Chronicle de relever l'imposture — si non pour votre compte, au moins pour les egards que vous avez toujours temoigné pour la verité et la justice —
Agreez Monsieur je vous prie l'assurance de mon estime, et croyez que je suis.
Votre obeissante servant etc.

P.S. — Si notre excellent ami le comte Porro est à Londre, maintenant seriez vous si bon de lui dire que si je n'ai pas repondu a sa derniere lettre c'est que j'ai perdu son adresse — et que je lui prie de me l'envoyer.
Mardi Mars 9ieme

Je rouvre ma lettre pour ajouter que plusieurs de mes amis sont d'opinion que je dois profiter de la permission de Mons.r Foscolo pour nier meme dans les journaux de Dublin l'imposture du Star. Si je céde à leur conseil sera plus par respect pour leur opinion que pour aucun sentiment personel.

Sir, — I cannot help expressing my surprize at the contempt you have exercised towards me in suffering your acceptance to be returne noted after the account running twelve months at ready money price, and in not considering the note worthy of any attention respecting the Bill. I have always exercised the greatest sympathy with you and ready to serve you in any way in my power, I do hope you will exercise that feeling which the merits of the case deserve.
I am Sir Your very obed.t Servant etc.

Monsieur — Par la poste d'aujourdhui, je vous addresse le No du «Star» qui vient de paroître, où se trouve encore une autre fabrication faite en vôtre nom, et dressée contre la declaration que vous avez bien voulu écrire à Lady Morgan, declaration qu'elle (profitant de votre permission, et d'après les conseils de ses amis) a publié dans les journeaux Irlandois.

Comme cet article est appuyée par des temoignages, peut être aussi controuvés que le rest, l'affaire commence à vous regarder personellement, ce qui m'a determiné de renouveller auprès de vous un sujet, d'ailleurs de très peu d'importance. Il n'est pas à moi, Monsieur, à vous dicter la marche que vous devez suivre dans les circostances, d'autant plus que votre lettre a Lady Morgan doit convaincre tout honnête homme. Mais pour les intérêts de la societé c'est à desirer qu'une calomnie aussi atroce soit entièrement devoilée.
Faites moi la grace de m'ecrire un petit mot de reponse et de me croire
Avec l'estime la plus perfaite
Vôtre très devoué serviteur etc.

ps.p: Mons.r Zandotti, dont le nome est attaché comme a la verification de votre écriture, est Italien et maitre de langue. Pour les autres je n'en connois rien.

div1.p: Caro Scalvini, — mi trovo peggiormente ammalato, e senza potere nè sapere come tirare innanzi, tutto che si vanno accomodando le mie faccende, e ch'io possa riavere un po' di vita perchè ora davvero n'ho appena un fiato, e dal mio ricorrere a chi non vorrei v'è facile idearvi in che stato io mi sia. Credo che Ugoni fino al termine del contratto — 16 aprile — avrà da pagarmi L. 800. Nè io vorrei, quand'anche non avessi altra ancora di salute, chiedere nè ricevere il denaro da Ugoni. Bensì Arrivabene potrebbe, credo, anticiparmelo, — da che la somma è poca e la riscossione è sì prossima ed egli sarebbe rimborsato fra due o tre settimane. Voi, come avete usato per lungo tempo, riscuoterete da Ugoni e invece di pagare a me pagherete a Arrivabene. E anche senza questo mio bisogno avrei dovuto pregarvi di riscuotere, da che Andrea dovrà dividersi da me nè, d'altra parte, e lo scrivo seriamente, non so se vivrò sino al giorno della scadenza del pagamento d'Ugoni. Or Addio, Scalvini; fate ch'io abbia alcuna risposta.
L'amico vostro ecc.

It has occurred to me that if Ugo Foscolo is an enthousiastic admirer of the immortal bard, Dante, he has it in his power to render an essential service to the lover of Poetry and Italian, and to acquire fama and emolument, by the publication of an Italian paraphrase of the Commedia. — It is a mode of explaining that obscure but most original and sublime composition hitherto never attempted, and if executed by such a poetic mind as the author of Ortis and Ricciarda, and by such a perfect master of his language, as the translator of Sterne, it could not fail to give an elegant exposition of the Poet's meaning and to be most acceptable to many a native Italian, as well as foreigner, who is at present frightened as much from the study of Dante by the formidable array of notes and commentaries as by the obscurity of his style. The English student is powerfully assisted by Cary (far more so than the Frenchman is by Artaud) and if he has the courage to wade through Landino, Vellutello, Venturi and Lombardi he may certainly understand his Author; but this is a labour which few readers will submit to. — When I collate Cary with Dante I admire the skill and fidelity of the translator, but if I read a canto of Cary by itself I rise with as imperfect an idea of the train of Dante's thoughts as an unlearned Italian must do after a perusal of the original. — But if there was an Italian paraphrase, as faithful, easy, intelligible, and concise as Gilpin's exposition of St Pauls epistle to the Romans (but in a more elevated prose) every scholar and man of taste would read it in order to possess a clear conception of the plan sentiments and execution of the poem, and being left in no doubt as to the Poet's meaning he would soon become fully sensible of his peculiar and extraordinary beauties, and even his obscurities would have their charm.

I am convinced that there is no book, except the Bible, that might be made such a vehicle for conveying improvement to the mind as Dante I should be happy therefore to promote the study of him, and if I had talent or influence to command the paraphrase, I would beg Murray to print it in octavo, the paraphrase being on the righthand page, and (Lombardi's) the corresponding test, on the left: — with copious notes thrown together at the end of each Canto, without the test (as in Venturi) being perplexed by numerical references. — The notes to M.r W. S. Rose's Orlando (though too brief for Dante) will explain my meaning.

I sincerely wish that the elegant literary occupation which I have taken the liberty to suggest to Ugo Foscolo may be agreable to his taste; if it should be, the numerous and elegant assembly which attended his lectures last spring make him secure of every encouragement which is to be obtained from an ample subscription —

Sir — the state of my health alone has prevented me from acknowledging more immediately your letter which conversed to me the strange forgeries in the Dublin Star of 13th. The total ignorance of Italian betrayed by the writter of the letter attributed to me, — in language, style of address and even in the Geography of Italy (all the individuals named as of the South being noblemen of the North) make it be obvious that neither I nor any other Italian could have written it. As to those Le–Clere and Zandotti who are made to certify my handwritting are persons whom I never heard of. — A M.r Samuel Hall I am acquainted with; but having letters in my possession which sufficiently disprove the assertion of his having translated several works for me, I conceive that his name must have been forged as mine. Such contrivers of pretended autographs and false attestations ought to be permitted to be guilty of forgery and baseness as much as they please so long as their imposture is not dangerous only because it is utterly contemptible. Indeed I should have passed it unvaliced from the very beginning had it both not for the regard due to a Lady abused under my name. And it is for the [....]

As so the new Count Cagliostro who signes a document in support of the contests of my alleged autograph, he seems to be well worthy of his name. The imposture therefore is so passable that it can deceive nobody. However if you deem it worth while so make any farther notice of it, you may use of this letter that you think fit. For my own part I am of opinion that men who, whatever may be their purpose, resort to the contrivance of forge letters and false attestations with such an absurdity as so become riduculous, can never be dangerous; — and they ought in common justice to be allowed to gratify themselves with forgery and baseness and expose themselves to a contemptuous execration as well as they please.

Sir, — From the inclosed print I you will perceive that I am about to depend on exertions which, as I apprehend, are liable to disagree with the constitution of the Traveller's Club, — as it partakes of the nature of a public institution, and its hospitality cannot be exercised but according to the opinions which, whether just or otherwise, are most prevalent in Society. I am, however, bound to add that owing to a residence of nearly eight years in England, and my personal acquaintance with several of the members of the club, I have acquired such a Knowledge of the liberal mind of English Gentlemen and English Scholars, as not even to imagine that an exile who mainly resists a long series of political and domestic reverses could ever be degraded in their eyes. But as individual feelings are never to be suffered to encroach upon general regulations, my new situation requires that I should not avail myself any longer of the admission which your Committee have hitherto honoured me with. I hope, Sir, that you will consider this letter as the best acknowledgment I could make of your kindness to me, — and that the gentlemen of the Club may find in my conduct a proof of my gratitude for the many civilities I received at their hands.

Dear Sir, — The strange forgeries published by the Dublin Star of the 13th have been contradicted the very next day in the Dublin Morning Post by poor Landotti with a letter which you will read in the newspaper I send you, and which I beg you to return by the bearer, if possible, — as I have promised it to its owner. Should you not be at home, be so good to send it under an envelop to W. S. Rose Esq. 181 Regents Street, two or three doors from the corner of Burlington Street. I send you also the copy of a letter which after a conversation with sir Seve Onseley and Col. Leake I thought proper to write for the information of all persons concerned. — I am, dear Sir,
Your grateful and faithful servant etc.

ps.p: N.B. — Turn over.

div1.p: My d.r Sir — I return the Paper — The denial of Zandotti effectually let you at ease —

I want very much to speak to you on the other letter before it is delivered into the Committee — Could you breakfast with me tomorrow between 10 and 11? — To day I am out and all day — and tomorrow after one.
I am your truly ect.

dateline.date: 1. Wells Street. Jermyn Street Friday [9 April 1824].

div1.p: My Dear Sir, — I will have the pleasure to dine with you on Sunday next, — and I hope so find you better; I have been myself afflicted, and still I am, with the plague of the London East Wind; and you do right to keep your room. By tomorrow I will send you the printed proof of the prospectus for the Italian poets, in order to hear your opinion on it, and make the alterations which may be thought necessary. As to the sad concern in the hands of Mr. Renny I made him acquainted with the Builder by whom the original lease is to be made over as soon as a purchaser may be found. But to relieve myself from a part of my anxieties, I assured Mr. Rossi that in case no remedy should be found before the 20th day of this month, I shall be at full liberty to put to sale such part of my furniture as may be sufficient to cover the amount of his security; and I furnished him with the power required in such case by the law. I have been compelled to take this step without previously consulting with you, — partly in order not to trouble you at every moment — and partly, because Mr. Rossi began to press upon me as if he doubted of my honesty, — and moreover he has been directed by his lawyer to be furnished with the legal power of putting my goods to sale and pay himself lest he should be prevented by some other creditor; — and I did it the less unwillingly as Mr. Rossi in case of an execution, would be the greater looser, — and now by the step I have taken his interest at least is protected, and he will recover his money without delay; — and the others will be paid after the definitive disposal of the leases. — Forgive my long letter — and believe me your grateful and faithful etc.

Dear Sir, — I return you, with my thanks, the History (as called) of the ...., yet, although there is not in the narration either lucidus ordo, or animus censoris honesti, still the justification of the Long parliament is a very fair one, and I think that such a work was a desideratum in your political litterature. I always suspected master Hyde alias Lord Clarendon to be a big bit of a jesuit, and I am now convinced of it not so much by the partial reasonings of Mr. Goldwin's as by the quotations from the journals and dates of the two houses of Parliament.

I send you some copies of the prospectus as altered according to the direction of Mr. Murray, — but now, Mr. Murray who a few days ago proposed himself that he should undertake the concern as a publisher soon after sufficient names of subscribers were assured — he now tells me that as he does not deal in retail bookselling and does not keep accounts with gentlemen, but with booksellers only, he will be at a loss how to collect the money, and therefore he thinks he should perhaps decline the undertaking. — These however are his usual ways and I am neither astonished nor offended — not even disappointed since let come the subscribers and any bookseller will advance the money and be glad to be the publisher. So at least I am told by Mr. Nicols the printer. — As to my affairs which are most pressing, I expect to have before evening a decisive answer from Mess.r Taylor and Roscoe; — and at all events I have decidedly made up my mind that every thing should be settled and quite over before the end of next week. Therefore on Sunday I will travel so far as Digamma to have some talk with Mr. Rossi; and in case you have the kind intention to ask me to dine with you, I am afraid I may not be able to reach St. James's Square at seven o'clock, since I must return from Digamma long after sunset to avoid being either fonowed or observed. — Forgive my scraps. Your grateful devoted friend etc.

My Dear Sir, — I saw Mr. Taylor on account of the leases, and I am to call upon him with the builder. Mr. Taylor recommended me to meet you there; and now a note of his reaches me appointing one o'clock tomorrow. — This I cannot do without previously knowing whether you approve my being present. — Moreover they shew me your letter which would add to my gratitude, were not that your benevolence surpasses whatever gratitude a man's soul can feel; yet I apprehend that they applied to your letter a construction which possibly may not agree either with your intentions, or with my views of the matter in its present stage. I am very anxious therefore to see you before the conference with Mess.rs Taylor and Roscoe. I will call tomorrow a little after eleven which I suppose is your breakfast time. I could not earlier, as I must be with several persons on account of the new lectures; the list increases daily, and may fetch a large supply, — but I am not as yet certain whether the job will take place. I must, first of all, attend to the instant necessity; and be as it may, it shall be settled in the course of the week, — Mr. Rossi's lawyers have already a claim upon me of L. 30! So they said to Mr. Taylor.

Dear Sir — By the advice of Mess.rs Blake & Co Essex Street we have put a Person in Possession at your Villa — They thought it best so to do — as there are several Writs out against you — and I hope you will have further time to make some more favorable arrangements to preserve your Furniture being sold by Public sale — I called on M.r Foxhall and sent M.r Gregson to M.r Rainy neither had yet done any thing respecting Disposal I wish you had exerted yourself a little more before the Bills came due — sorry I am to say it for it has inconvenienced me very much — as no past statement has been ratified — your servants seem relieved by the step taken for it seems they were before all agitation —
Remain D.r Sir

Milady — J'esperais hier de pouvoir vous presenter mes respects ce matin; — mais je dois maintenant attendre chez moi des individus qu'il m'est indispensable de voir, et j'ignore si je serai libre avant l'heure que vous montez en voiture pour vos visites. En attendant que je puisse sortir j'envois les papiers dont je vous ai parlé dans mon billet de hier. Il y a la lettre que j'avais commencé pour Milord et pour vous; — mais elle été en mauvaise ecriture, — et en Anglais fort mauvais, et trop longue, et d'ailleurs elle ne contenait de choses rejouissantes; aussi je ne me suis pas empressé de la finir et de l'expedier. Toutefois, puisque Milord en lisant ce bruillon de lettre, trouvera et saura vous donner quelques reinsegnement sur mon etat, je vous l'envois. Croyez moi Madame pour la vie, votre reconnoissant et devoué etc.
(N.B. — Milady vous expliquera la date anterieure de cette lettre qui n'a jamais été achevée)

Mylord — There are periods in a man's life in which he must renounce even hope; and the situation, upon the whole, is not a very bad one, since the mind is delivered from many perplexities and anxieties, and perhaps a thorought resignation to the worst is the only straightforward way to tranquillity.

My voyage to Greece did meet with obstacles in every quarter. — Your Ministers do not refuse a passport, —— they can not, but consider me as an Jonian, — but now it appears that Lord Bathurst is strongly impressed against me, and those friends of mine, who started the matter with the most intimate acquaintances of his Lordship, warned me that on my going in the Islands I must be deaf or dumb, — and that I ran the danger of living under a military government sous la surveillance journaliere de la Police. On my hinting that I intended to establish at Zante a kind of professorship of Litterature, to teach my countrimen and relations what I could, it was peremptorily answered, “That I would spread the most jacobinical principles, — turn the heads of the young people, and prompt every body to disaffection and rebellion”. — I did not think worth the while to justify myself on the charge of jacobinism! but I recollected your advice on the expediency of contradicting the assertion, made in the way of innuendo in a letter of Lord Bathurst, that I was the author of anonymous papers against the Jonian government; — accordingly I sent to Lord Aberdeen a letter of which I inclose a copy for the information of your Lordship. — But you know your government; — they may be convinced but they will not be persuaded as to the real politics and character of an individual; they think it necessary to look at the opinion publicly entertained of any man that opposed them; and thus they think that were they to allow me to go to the Jonian Islands, and make any rational use I may think proper, of my liberty, they would thus countenance the party, — that is the majority of the inhabitants — adverse to the despotic sway of Sir Th. Maitland, which is now carried as usual, though in a more civil manner, by the new governor under the sway of the Torryest Lord Bathurst.

At the same time my attempt to reach with some prospect of tranquillity at least the continent of Greece, proved equally hopeless. The gentlemen of the Greek Commeette cannot help looking at me as a man devoted to Russian interest! M.r Hume received me in such a proud, and uncivil manner — we call it villania — as to tempt me to give him something like a box in the hear; — but the afflictions of poor Job taught me his resignation and patience, and thus I withstood the temptation. But I could not help fixing my eyes and keeping them steadily and contemptuously on his face, whilst he was overwhelming me with his short senatorial question; I answered only by still looking in his face, until he must have perceived that my costretta bile was ready to burst out, and he thought it prudent to cast down his eyes and keep silent; — I then turned my back, followed by Hobhouse, who had introduced me, and was awed, as it were, (indeed he seemed quite terrified) both at the imperatorial behaviour of Master Hume, and at my obstinate and scornful taciturnity. Hobhouse then entreated me to apply to M.r Bowring — with whom of course I refused to have any thing to do, as my business was with the Commeette and by no means with the Secretary. Thus the matter ended. I might even thus have reached Greece; but at a great peril, since in a revolutioned country where factions and contrary interests run very high I should be compelled to dread the very calumny which is only laughable and incredible in England. Moreover the clause proposed by M.r Peel for the Alien bill, insure now to me the full protection of the English law; — since by that clause any foreigner that remained here for seven years cannot be subject to the enactments of the Alien act, — and I am in England since the year 1816.

As to my actual subsistence and some provision for the impending old age and infirmities, — and threatening blindness — there is the rub. The last Essay of an article in which I employed two months of constant reading, and several weeks hard writting, convinced me that little, if any thing, is to be expected from similar exertions; at the same time I waste my powers — if any still remain to me — in writing on subjects, and in a manner both unpleasant and unworthy, and be at the mercy of Booksellers and Editors of Periodical Publications; for, of my article eagerly requested from me, and punctually delivered since last November On the Classical Turist in Italy, I heard nothing; and two numbers of the Quarterly have already made their appearence without the article; and from M.r Murray's silence on the subject I am now certain that M.r Gifford's litterary taste and political principles do not agree with my way of writing and thinking. Be it so. I resorted therefore to the expedient of giving lesson, but it does not succeed; — there is not even the appearance of any success; and like the wig of poor Yorick which was below and above all other wigs, and accordingly was set aside, even this humble attempt of mine fails. Lately I yelded to M.r Rose's advice who was very sanguine of the success of an Edition of Dante, and of other Italian poets. I therefore caused a prospectus to be printed with some hope that the undertaking would prove of some present and future advantage to me, and of some utility to the Italian scholars in England; — but now I do not what to anticipate. I live now in lodgings come Dio vuole in town; I left the Digamma at first on account of a fever which lasted two weeks, and I could not expect that D.r Holland should go so far, and with such bad roads; — and then I remained here to get rid of servants as much as I could, and to attend to my pupils, — who are two in all. Other matters soon after beset me, which cannot be explained without adding to the length and the sadness of this letter. Of one thing I am now fully and deeply convinced that I must speedily take some course to assure, at any price and by all means some lasting peace of mind; — for now I am afraid, my powers began to become miserably weakened. This I must watch, since [....].

My dear Sir, — I ought to thank you the more readily for your kind invitation as tomorrow is the giorno della santa Pasqua, and for us, catholic people, to dine alone is an ill omen. I inclose you the prospectus which I have altered, and I hope for the better, — and I intend to send it to my friends since my hopes hang wholly upon Dante, and Mr. Nichols, my printer assures me that as soon as a sufficient number of subscribers may be found, any bookseller will be glad to advance the money at the usual discount of 125 per 100, even without the insurance of my Life. Be so good as to give the other copies of the prospectus to any person you think proper. — You will find also inclosed the circular which I send for my several creditors to be delivered Mr. Rainy next Monday, — and if any expression is to be altered you will have the goodness to suggest it to me tomorrow. —— My Lawyer told me that an Agent House is more likely to satisfy tradesmen, whilst the interference of an attorney will probably give them the alarm. Should however, Mr. Rainy fail in his endeavors, and Mr. Rossi be prevailed upon to put off the sale of the furniture, some Lawyer may be then employed to settle matters some way or other on my behalf with the several Lawyers employed by the creditors. Mr. Rossi in the meanwhile, as you will see from his letter, has taken possession of the house to act according to the Law; a thing of which I was absolutely ignorant. Be it so; and should even all matters be settled for the present, and nothing or little to be expected from the edition and illustration of Dante, I have already made up my mind to sale both Leasehold and furniture by Auction for whatever they may fetch before the end of the present year, since they will produce enough for the payment of my debts, and the peace of my mind. — Pardon my English, my scrapes, and the trouble which I give you, but not without feeling a keen remorse and a warm gratitude —

My dear Sir, — In consequence of the Easter Holydays, our Committee here is not sitting, — but I take the liberty of informing you that your admission as a visitor, will certainly be renewed, and that in the meanwhile, I do hope you will not fail to attend whatever you may think proper —
You will quite understand this private communication, and have with me much Touch and Regard, —
I am my dear Sir Your very sincere and faithful ecc.
The Travellers.

div1.n: 2933. A un membro del governo greco (21 aprile 1824)

opener.salute: A UN MEMBRO DEL GOVERNO GRECO.

dateline.date: 102 Grt Titchfield Street Oxford Street April 21/24.

div1.p: Sir — After the communication I had with you last week I was surprised to receive a letter from Mess.rs Blake & C.o and can scarcely believe what I have read as you well know in what a dreadful situation you have plunged me in. You was to have taken of the Bills this month and I have got the parties that holds the Bills that is over due to keep them until the latter end of this month with a pledge that they would be paid by you on some work to be published. I know not what step to take to raise the Money as you know any expence on them must be paid by me with the Bills as there is now over due and one that comes in a few days. I am fearful of the parties hearing of it and in that case I have no choice of keeping myself out of a Prison occasioned by your not fulfilling your promise. Must beg to see you as early as possible to make some arrangement with you.
Yours etc. .... C. Davis.

Dear Sir, — The Creditors who attended the meeting are
Henderson
L. 6 3. 9 0. Weaver
2 1. Benham (including a subsequent Bill 8 L.)
1 1 0. Cood
2 0. 10. Ames
4 4. Taylor
1 4. Robinson
2 1.
They only agreed to wait on condition that the Houses should be advertised to be sold forthwith, and an agreement was to be drawn up, by which you are to make over the property in trust for sale.
I was in hopes you had seen M.r Rainey who had explained this to you.

Davis is a sheriff's officer. I am afraid it will be difficult to bring the holders of Stabbach's Bill into the arrangement but PERHAPS it may be accomplished (if you can avoid being arrested) as soon as the other Creditors have signed.
Remain
Dr Sir
Yours very obedt etc.

Dear Sir, — In the explanation given to me by Mr. Rainy after the meeting I clearly understood that the leases and furniture were not to be sold for less than twenty one hundred pounds — and that the creditors undertook not to proceed with the sale but after six weeks, in order to allow me time sufficient to satisfy them with some other means. But from your last note it would seem that no price is to be fixed as the minimum for the sale, and that the whole is to be disposed forthwith for whatever price it can fetch, provided the creditors registered in the schedule be paid of their respective claims. But were I to sign such agreement I would give up what costs more than L. 3600 only to pay debts amounting at L. 800; and moreover by such an agreement any of the creditors who should undertake to satisfy the other claimants would possess an actual right to sell or buy my property for whatever consideration however small. Let it therefore be clearly understood that the time and price of the sale ought to be explicitly stated in the agreement. I never intended to renounce my property to be dealt with by the creditors as they please; — but that it should be disposed of within three months at no less than the price to be distinctly stated in the agreement, — and the individual best entitled to fix the price undoubtedly is Mr. Rainy as an agent and surveyour. — In case the sale should not take place within three months, I do not satisfy the creditors by that time, they will have just the same rights against me that they have now. I wrote to Mr. Rainy to the same purpose. Moreover as long as I am not at liberty to move, I could not, unless it be on a Sunday, go home to take and send you the necessary documents. Your warnings not to stir and to beware being arrested lest our pains should be lost at once, are followed by me the more as all my creditors even those who pursue me are now well aware that I must call upon you some day or other. Thus I will never appear in that quarter of the town without the previous assurance that all claimants agree to come to some understanding. Your information that Davis is a Sheriff's officer astonished me, and his not having appeared at the meeting is a proof that he intends some mischief; — yet, as to him, I have reason to believe that I will be able to stop his proceedings without your interference. But the holders of the bills delivered to Stabback still beset with officers my house; Mr. Rossi knows that they call there almost every day, — and let me repeat again that if I am to remain liable to imprisonment by one creditor, it will be worse than useless for me to sign any agreement with the others, — and thus undergo the expenses of the transfer on trust, and give up my property. I had rather present myself before the Sheriff of my own accord, and give bail for all the claims, and thus I should gain the time necessary to exert myself and look about me in order to raise money before the day of an action. I could then also claim the balance of about L. 35. owed to me by Stabback for, as now things are going on it would seem that all my rights and protection of my interess are out of the question and that whilst I am to part with my property for the benefit of creditors to whom are owed L. 500, I must take my chance and protect myself as I can from the persecution of creditors who claim L. 300. — Be so good as to place this letter under Mr. Ainge's eyes, and in the same time I will send a copy of it to Mr. Rossi. In the meanwhile I shall consult with my friends, and you will hear from me again in the course of to–morrow.
I remain, Dear Sir, —

div1.n: 2937. A Taylor And Roscoe (19 o 26 aprile 1824)
div1.p: My Dear Sir, — I saw last night Mr. Hudson Gurney M.P. and he kindly offered to call upon you and confer with you about my sad and foolish affairs.

I saw likewise Mr. Rossi the holder of the bill of sale. He thinks that on account of the proceedings for my acceptances in favour of Stabback no general agreement can be brought to pass with the body of the creditors; and he added that as they cannot be benefited by leases of which I am not the apparent holder, my best plan would be to allow my furniture to be placed in some of Mr. Rossi's empty houses as a pledge until the time I could redeem it from him; — and in the meanwhile I must take the benefit of the insolvent act. I made answer that I had rather take the benefit of death; and that a public sale would prove more satisfactory to the creditors should they even lose by it the whole amount of their claims. Therefore he left me with telling that he will furnish me with a speedy notice of the day in which he shall put to sale as much of the furniture and books as may cover his own claim for L. 250. I wrote at the same time to Mr. Gregson to send you the bill of the sum I owe to Mess.rs Blake White & Ainge for what they have done for me.

Lastly I saw Mr. Davis the builder; he is NOT a Sheriff's officer; far from it, he behaved with me in a manner as to leave me satisfied, that if he overcharged his bills as a tradesman, he has not been unworthy of the confidence I placed upon him as a man. He was so earnest to accommodate me that on being applied by Mr. Rossi to attend the meeting of the creditors he made answer that, “to give me time upon unreasonable terms was NOT his intention”; and as he perceived that they intended to press and hurry the sale, he declined to appear at the meeting, lest he should be beset with questions to which he might not have thought prudent to answer. He assured me that as to my qualifications either to hold or grant a title of leasehold property, he will take care that I should not run any danger, at least on his account; that he will grant himself the most satisfactory leases free from any sort of difficulties, and should I be not able to satisfy his claims ere the sale takes place, he will be contented to wait until that time. I feel grateful to him for this offer the more as I know he is distressed for ready money. I will send this letter through him as he may give you some information about the matter, — and in case he does not find you at home he will leave his address and wait upon you at your convenience.

As to what may be more advisable to do, allow me to refer to our conversation of last Friday, and my last letter. — But I ought to have added that in case the purchaser's money is not ready, I will be satisfied with the sum necessary to pay my creditors, — and as to the remaining portion I will wait for twelve months, and even leave it in the purchaser's hands upon mortgage of the same leasehold. —— Mr. Gregson with the charges of my debt to Mess.rs Black, White and Ainge will send you also a paper with the particulars about the disposal of the houses, and the names of my creditors with their respective claims.
Believe me yo [....]

My Dear Sir, — The inclosed copy of a letter of mine to Mr. Taylor will acquaint you with my interview with Rossi, and Davis, — but I saw also at Digamma two other creditors whom I requested to call, and who informed me that poor Mr. Rossi through real friendship for me, and a fear equally real lest he should be the looser in the transaction has nearly brought about my total ruin.
Rossi in what he said acted by the impulsion of his feeling heart, — and in what he has done he followed the directions of his lawyer.

As to what he said, he declared to some creditors that they have cheated me; that he will take care to deliver my property from their grasp; that as they cannot touch the leases of which a foreigner cannot be the apparent holder, the bill of sale in his hands will protect the furniture; — that he will advise me to take all benefit of the insolvent act; as to go abroad until matter be settled, and so forth; and to sum all, he declared that were the most part of my creditors to be disappointed of the whole amount of their present claims they should remain still the gainers considering the money they have already received from me. You will see in my letter to Mr. Taylor that Rossi yesterday actually proposed to me the expedient of the insolvent act! — but I will add for your information that Rossi said to me that such an expedient has been recomended by Mr. Chambers the Banker as the only way both to relieve myself and to chastise these rascals.

Whether Mr. Chambers gave such an advise, I have not yet ascertained; if he did I wonder at it; for not only he knows me, but I received last saturday an invitation to his house; — men of business, I must own, are unaccountable men to me!

Be as it may the follies uttered by Rossi incensed and alarmed some of the creditors. They went about inquiring as to my good or bad qualification either to hold or grant any deed — as to my actual possession of any lease — and whether I have paid the ground–rent and taxes, — and whether I am not a rogue, — and some of them think that I am already run away, while others are afraid that I am in the eve of claiming the benefit as an insolvent. Hence the obstinacy of some of them in their pursuit, — and last night I was hunted and followed from Digamma to Totthenam court road, where my long tours, and the providential rain with the darkness helped me to shelter myself among some hackney coaches, — I entered one of them, — and went to the house of Mr. Scalvini, quite safe.

Now, as to what Rossi has done by the direction of his lawyers — first he got the bill of sale — next his lawyers put there a man at my expence of course of six shellings a day — then they send two upholsters to estimate the whole furniture en mass — and lastly a regular appriser appeared and remained there for the whole of a day to evaluate every thing in detail. But the heavy expences to which they put me are quite premature, — for no execution was to be apprehended unless an arrest and a subsequent judgement takes place, and the instrument in the hands of Rossi protected his interest at all events; the execution his lawyers have put might have been delayed for some weeks, and only resorted to a few days before any judgement; while now they added to my pecuniary distresses, and to the suspicions of the other creditors. — Davis however, and two or three others asserted my honour as much as they could, — and I owe it to their exertion if I am not pursued by the whole host of the London Sheriff's officers.

Whether the plan proposed to me by Rossi to transport the furniture to one of his own houses, is a suggestion of his lawyers, I cannot say; — you will see my answer to it in the copy of the letter to Mr. Taylor, — and upon that answer Mr. Rossi declared that his lawyers will give me notice of the day in which the furniture shall be put to sale.

Now adieu for I have only paper to add that on my return here I found a large list of subscribers to the lectures at Mrs. Littleton, — ma è un calice amaro! still I must drink it. — I send you confidentially the confidential letter of the secretary of the Travellers. Yours etc.

Sir —— It was not my intention to use any harsh measures against you. It is the parties that holds the Bills that insists on my paying them and that immediately I have no objection to accept of your proposition of the Bills only you must know the amount is more than what you mention but that I can settle with you and shall be glad to meet you to arrange it with you.
Yours etc. C. Davis.

ps.p: Let me hear from you as early as possible.

div1.p: My dear Sir — Pardon me; the necessity of troubling you again grieves me deeply; — but were I to renounce your advice I would remain the prey of Lawyers and tradesmen, and of my own mind which really is distracted almost to madness.

Pray do read with some attention the inclosure 1 and 2 which are the letters from the attorney employed on my behalf, and in the inclosure no. 3 you will find my answer. Either I am greatly mistaken, or from these papers you will perceive that matters in the hands of the Lawyers grew worse, and that the meeting of the creditors, which at first did promise to allow me some peace and liberty at least for a few weeks, became a mean for my utter destruction.

Soon after the meeting was over M.r Rainy told me “that I must resign to give up the two leases and furniture for two thousand guineas or pounds at LEAST. I made answer that should a litterary undertaking of mine prove unsuccessful, I would resign even to that sum”; and upon this M.r Rainy assured me that the creditors will not hurry the sale, and that they will delay it for six weeks, and even three months. But now M.r Rainy says that the time and price ought to be left to the equitable consideration of the creditors. Thus it seems pretty clear that the whole is to be sold as soon as it fetch enough to satisfy the creditors, — and I doubt not that were I to consent to such terms, a joint speculation would be speedily contrived by certain individuals to possess themselves with my property for no more than the money sufficient to get ready of the claims on the property. But the worst of it is, that while M.r Rossi's Lawyers, who are also my own, insist that I should give up to them my titles and transfer the property on trust, they do not undertake in the least to protect me from the legal proceedings pursued by the two creditors which did not appear at the meeting. I employed M.r Rossi's Lawyers because they are respectable persons, and as he has the first and most sacred claims on account on his security, and he presided the meeting, I consented to leave the management of the concern in their hands for his full satisfaction, and also because they have been pointed out by him for the bill of sale. I doubt not but they are honourable men; — but they are men and Lawyers; they think more of M.r Rossi their constant client, than of me who am a ruined fellow; they must also take care that their bill for whatever they are doing on my behalf should not remain unpaid; I easily foresaw that no sooner I employed a Lawyer that he would naturally become one of my creditors; and indeed from the beginning to the end of this said concern of the cottages I scarcely had to deal with a person that did not take the utmost advantage of me. Certainly the intelligence quite new to me that Davis my very builder is nothing less than a Sheriff's officer ought to convince me that during more than two years I foolishly meddled with people from whom I could not expect but destruction.

Now, if I can expect any safety it is from Time alone; for between now and the middle of june it will be fully ascertained whether the Edition of Dante will answer. Should I succeed to find a sufficient number of subscriptions, Murray proposed himself to advance the money; — should it prove otherwise, I will then resign to return to the mother earth as naked as I was born. My only expedient, to gain six weeks or two months of time, is to present myself to a Sheriff, and offer bails for the satisfaction of those creditors that want to insure their claims by proceedings. I am informed, (how far correctly, I do not know), that from the moment of the bail to the judgement of all actions for debt, there is in general the interval of two months; — during which time the subscribers may forth come, and the houses may be sold on better terms than if I were to give them up to the creditor to be disposed of for whatever sum they can get. I am also told that the expences of giving six bails are by far less than those required to make over a deed on trust and to prepare new leases; and you will perceive that the Lawyers insist for the new leases even before any agreement should be signed by some creditors not to take proceedings; — whilst others do actually proceed against me and will not hear of any delay. Still as the step of giving myself up to the Sheriffs is a bold one, I will not venture to take it without having upon it your opinion. And should you have time to see me either this evening or to morrow I will wait upon you. —— Pardon me again, and believe me.
Your–very grateful — etc.

Sir — I received yours and you may be assured that no one of the holders of the Bill will put you to any inconvenience as there is no proceedings either against you or me at this time nor I hope will not as I have already paid some expences on the former Bills not being renewed by you in time. Should wish to see you as soon as convenient.
Yours etc. C. Davis.

Dear Sir, — As the creditors are willing that M.r Rainey shall sell the promises, he will, of course, take care to make the most of them. But you will be consulted before a sale takes place, and it is impossible to say what the property will produce.
