Ed io ho pur ponderato con esatte bilance il To be and not to be di Amleto, e potrei forse aggiungere molti versi men belli, ma insieme molte più idee egualmente vere e calzanti; e la questione si riduce per me a conoscere quali sono le facoltà intellettuali che uno possede — e quanto e come può usarne; e se pur ne possede alcune non ordinarie, — e se può giovarsene utilmente e altamente, — ei deve stare al To be; ma quand'ei le avesse smarrite, o non sapesse nè perchè, nè a che impiegarle allora —
Denique Democritum postquam matura vetustas
Admonuit memores motus languescere mentis
Sponte sua leto caput obvius obtulit ipse
e da che vedete ch'io pur mi giovo delle mie facoltà, potrete felicemente congetturare che io non mi sento ancor nell'intelletto l'imbecillità per la quale Democrito ha fatto da savio a gittarsi dentro un torrente. Vero è ch'io invece di piantare e far crescere querce che facciano ombra alla posterità, e s'acquistino gratitudine e riverenza, io pianto, e raccolgo cannuccie per chi le compera ad accendere il fuoco, — o ad appiccarvi le banderuole; — ma il coltivarle e smerciarle mi può in pochi anni provvedere quel poco che basti a lasciarmi libero ad attendere a occupazioni men mercenarie, e più consonanti con l'indole mia, e con gli studj della passata età mia. — Ma addio, perchè Porro manda a dire ch'ei sta su le mosse, — e benchè vorrei pure narrarvi assai cose di me, m'è pur forza di dirvi Addio; — bensì Porro che sa quasi ogni cosa, e benchè parli molto, non parla sempre a traverso, ed è raccontatore felice, vi dirà più ch'io non potrei scrivendo; e perch'egli inoltre ha in corpo o tutta o certamente gran parte della buon'anima di Panglosse, il suo racconto de' fatti miei vi rallegrerà; — ma v'attristerà fors'anche, e voi avreste torto dopo sì lunghi esperimenti di affliggervi, se vi dirà d'una nuova recentissima malignità Italiana uscita di Padova, dove un Professore avendo saputo che le lettere del Petrarca inedite ed autografe (possedute da Lord Holland e pubblicate da me con un fac simile nel libretto intorno al Petrarca) s'erano smarrite, ed ignorando che furono poi ritrovate, si giovò della impossibilità in cui egli mi credeva di produrre gli originali, e pubblicò un opuscolo nel quale accusa Lord Holland e me d'Impostura. Lord Holland mi scrive ch'ei vuole ad ogni modo rispondere — quanto a me credo ch'io opporrò al Professore Padovano il silenzio col quale ho risposto a calunnie peggiori; — pur se mai gli rispondessi, risponderò a tutti i calunniatori Italiani presenti passati e futuri una volta per sempre; ed il Professore farà le veci dell'Irco sopra del quale erano addossati tutti i peccati del popolo Ebreo. — Ora addio, ma devo ancora darvi novella del vostro libro di Miscellanee prestato per mezzo mio a Sir Francis Burdett; gli scrissi e gli riscrissi, ma non è in città, — e mi assicurò che appena tornato lo troverà fra' suoi libri, e lo manderà senz'altri ritardi; — e in quest'occasione riseppi da un antichissimo famigliare — gentiluomo — del famoso Baronetto assai cose non credute nè credibili; e nondimeno date per verissime, — perchè mi hanno raccontato ch'egli è avarissimo — gretto — anzi misero — anzi per naturale spilorceria è talvolta il ladre de' Francesi alla quale parola que' pochissimi che lo hanno esaminato dentro le scene associano un po' d'idee accessorie della stessa parola in Italiano; — ma io che non l'ho veduto se non su la scena, non voglio credere nè potrei in coscienza — nè dirò mai quello che intesi se non fra fidatissimi, — e finor fuorchè a voi nol dissi ad anima che viva, e voi mezzo credendo e mezzo non credendo vi riserverete, se mai ve n'importasse, ad appurare un dì o l'altro la verità, ed a serbarlo per la Storia aneddota. Bensì quello che mi fu detto, vero o non vero, mi giova d'avviso a non perdere d'occhio il vostro libro che riavrete di certo — Ora Addio davvero e dal fondo dell'anima mia. Penso spesso a voi, e m'affliggo, e vi ammiro — Addio Leggete questi miei gieroglifici come potrete
Tutto vostro ecc.

Absence and accident prevented my acknowledging the receipt of your letter and publication transmitted to me by Lady Eliz.th Fielding. I am new reminded of my negligence, for which I beg leave to apologize, by the arrival of two other copies one for myself and the other for M.r Ugo Foscolo. I have forwarded the last to its direction.
Accept, Sir, in the first place my thanks for the attention shewn me by this communication and for the civil manner in which you have mentioned my name in the course of your work.

Having thus acknowledged your politeness, I hope you will not deem me deficient in that quality if I venture in justice to Mr Foscolo to set you right in two particulars where an imperfect knowledge of the facts seems to have led you to very erroneous conclusions.

The first relates to the manner in which the facsimiles of Petrarch's letters found their way into Mr Foscolo's valuable essay on that poet. It is true that he printed them from MSS purporting to be original letters in the handwriting of Petrarch, in my possession. But in your private letter to me, you seem to apprehend from that circumstance that Mr Foscolo is responsible for their authenticity that he either procured them for me or persuaded me that they were genuine, and that if not genuine they must have been recently forged by others to impose upon him and me, or by him to impose upon the publick. All this is quite incorrect. The MSS have been in my possession more than twenty years, I, and others more competent to form a judgment on such matters than myself have always considered them as authentick letters of Petrarch, long before Mr Foscolo saw them, and long before I was acquainted with that very learned and eminent man. I purchased them in October 1803 together with some original letters of Sannigarius and Pontanus, at Madrid of Dn Ysidro del Olmo, a gentleman of respectable character who had spent many years in collecting MSS and who assured me that he had long possessed and valued as originals the three letters of Petrarch, one in Latin and two in Italian which he then sold to me and from which Mr Foscolo printed the facsimiles. Dn Ysidro I should add sold me many others MSS which are undoubted originals and his collection and conversation proved him to be a man of some judgment and research in such matters. It follows from this statement that if there has been any deception between Mr Foscolo and myself, I must have deceived Mr Foscolo, not Mr Foscolo me, for I shewed him the letters with a strong assurance of my conviction (a conviction still unshaken) that they were in the handwriting of Petrarch. If they are spurious, they must have been forged long before Mr Foscolo could have thought of writing essays on Petrarch; they must have been forged without any view to publication for to my knowledge they have been preserved by two possessors of them many years unpublished and they must have been forged in a country where few persons conver–sant with early Italian literature resided and where there was no ready sale of such specimens of your early classical writers.

The other point relates to the fate of the MSS since they were communicated to Mr Foscolo you are pleased to assert in your pamphlet (p. 39) that the letters exist no longer and you ground your assertion on an incident with the particulars of which you are manifestly unacquainted and concerning which you never enquired either of Mr Foscolo or myself. The real state of the case on which you are so imperfectly informed and from which you have drawn such wrong inferences was as follows.

Mr Foscolo soon after borrowing the MSS and printing the facsimiles from them changed his lodgings in London. In the removal of his effects they were mislaid. He felt the loss more than the value of the papers could justify and infinitely more than I could have wished who was in a great measure consoled by the reflection that his publication and facsimiles had secured to the Commonwealth of letters any little advantage that could be derived from the original.

In his anxiety he printed that advertisement from which you, Sir, have drawn so erroneous and, I must add, so hasty a conclusion. Had you done him or me the honour of enquiring about the ultimate fate of the MSS before you asserted in print that they did not exist, and insinuated from that assumed fact that M' Foscolo knew they would not bear inspection, we should have apprized you that they were shortly afterwards found between the leaves of a folio book and restored to me and I should have added that you or any persons deputed by you were at full liberty to examine them. They are now before me and whether they be the genuine letters of Petrarch or not, I can safely affirm upon my honour that they are the same that I purchased as such in October 1803.

I am, Sir, fully disposed to give you credit for being led into these mistakes by false appearances but in critical as well as judicial enquiries it has long been an established maxim that it is unsafe not to say rash to trust entirely to circumstantial evidence especially when better can with a little diligence be obtained.

How far such a canon of criticism or any part of it would invalidate your argument on the date of the letters and the place of residence of Jacopo Colonna at any given day near 500 years ago I do not pretend to determine, your reasoning I must acknowledge is to my mind very inconclusive, and do not think me uncivil if I frankly add that your Authority on such a question carries with it less weight in consequence of the readiness with which you have fallen into error about the circumstances and fate of these very Manuscripts since I have known them.

You will I am sure be good enough to excuse me for writing to you on a subject which required precision in my own language and you will be just enough to allow me in a question involving the literary character of Mr Foscolo to communicate my correspondence to that Gentleman with full permission to shew or to publish it.
I am, Sir, your obedient humble Servant etc.

Dear Foscolo — I send you a copy of my letter to the Padua Abbé and you are at liberty to shew, or make any other use of it that you think proper. As I was the best witness to the facts I was bound to bear my testimony to the correctness and propriety of your conduct throughout all the transactions which passed between us about the manuscripts of Petrarch's letters and which this halfinformed writer either ignorantly or wilfully distorts into insinuations against you. Indeed I am not altogether sorry at the publication of the Italian pamphlet — It gives you a fair opportunity of stating to the publick that the Manuscripts are found and it affords one to me of bearing my testimony of gratitude to you for the pains you took about them in the first instance and the interest you felt and shewed for the recovery of them when supposed to be lost — Let me add that it is no small gratification in a matter connected with literary history to see my name coupled with yours —
I am ever truly etc.

Mon cher Monsieur. — J'ai tardé a vous repondre dans l'espoir que mes amis m'auroient fourni des papiers et des anecdotes concernant Lord Byron; — quelques un en effet m'en ont promis, mais j'ai dû, après leur promesses, me montrer satisfait de leur escuses, et de leur raison qui n'admettent point de reponse puisque elles sont fondés sur l'axiome qu'il ne faut jamais perdre l'occasion de gagner honnetement ce qu'il faut pour vivre; et à l'axiome ils appliquent des calculs d'arithmetique. Le fait est que tous les libraires croyent ici de redoubler leur richesses en employant une portion pour faire ecrivailler sur Lord Byron, et justifier la verité historique et la finction romanesque — ou romantique, si vous le voulez mieux — par des pieces authentiques ou apocryphes —— n'importe; aussi ceux qui croyoient leur tresor inutiles, les emploient pour en faire des brochures, des articles periodique, et des volumes, — et même les personnes qui n'ont gueres la necessité de gagner de l'argent par des ecrivailleries — c'est un mot de Montaigne s'il vous plait — sont poussés par le demon de la Vanité; — vous savez que presque tout le monde ici, ou ecrit et imprime pour vivre, — ou bien, vit pour ecrire et se faire imprimer; ainsi, mon cher Monsieur, malgré tout mon desir et mes efforts et mes esperances de vous servir, et faire par là quelque amende honorable de mon long silence, — je ne puis pas y reussir. Car je n'ai jamais été en directe correspondence avec Lord Byron; tout ce qu'il ecrivait à mon egard il le inserait dans ses lettres à ses amis, et particulierement dans celles à M.r Murray, — qui lui communiquait tout ce que j'avais a lui repondre. Et quant à mon opinion sur son Genie, son caractere, et ses ouvrages je l'avais deja ecrite en peu de page que vous lirez bientôt dans le European Review (une nouvelle entreprise d'ouvrage periodique que l'on a commencé depuis peu avec le Capital de Vingt Mille livres sterlings!); et il y a quelques uns de vos ecrivains le plus estimables qu'y contribuent des articles. Je ne pourrai par consequence vous envoyer copie de un ecrit que j'avais remis entre les mains des Editeurs de l' European Review , avant de recevoir votre lettre; ils auroient raison de se plaindre; et, ce qui pis est, je ne saurais comment m'excuser devant mes propres yeux. Cet article serait deja paru sans le delais de l'artiste qui n'a pas encore achevé une Medaille de Lord Byron; — des que la Medaille paraitra je vous en ferai parvenir une gravure sans delai en la donnant a votre ami qui veut bien se charger de cette lettre; et s'il aura une occasion moins dispendieuse que la poste je lui donnerai aussi pour vous la Medaille en metal. Maintenant Adieu, mon cher Monsieur, — plaignez moi de ce que je n'ai pas reussi de complaire a vos desir, — et j'en suis d'autant plus affligé depuis votre accueil aimable a Milord et lady Dacre qui ne font que repeter vos eloges.
Adieu — Votre devoué etc.

Sir, — I forwarded you, according to our understanding, thorough the two penny post seven pages of my English Manuscript for a trial, requesting you to re–write or correct it, and send it to me as soon as possible by the same conveyance. — The paper (of which the pages now with you are only the beginning) must be delivered ready for the press by tomorrow in the evening — Monday 27th without fail. I have it prepared since last Wednesday when I wrote to you; — but it requires the revisal of a writter thorough acquainted with English compaction. Should be able to call to day at Digamma Cottage, the revisal and necessary alteration could be made in a little more than an hour, as the article is a very short one, — and we may also make some arrangements for the future, as I have another paper also written in English which require some correction, and a french Manuscript to be translated. — But in case you are otherwise engaged, and I must renounce the pleasure of your visit in the course of to day, be so good as to give the seven pages (now in your hands) to my Messanger who is difected to wait for your answer; as I am obliged to send the whole of the article to the Editors within twenty four hours. —
Believe me Sir —
Your very sincerely obliged etc.

Dear Sir — The bearer Mr. George Robinson I think would be able to undertake the second copying of your manuscripts — You will of course make the same arrangement with him in every way that you would with a stranger, not considering my recommendation or his relationship — being my cousin — I can answer for his integrity and have no doubt he will use every endeavour to give satisfaction. He has hitherto been in Merchants houses for improvement in Portugal and France — but has now been a long time without meeting with an eligible situation therefore if he can be useful to you he will be getting something — and employment — which is at all times preferable to not getting any thing.
I remain Dear Sir Yours very sincerely etc.

div1.n: 2987. A Thomas Roscoe O Edgar Taylor

opener.salute: A THOMAS ROSCOE o EDGAR TAYLOR.

div1.p: Sir, — I have had the honour of receiving this morning early your letter of yesterday, and accordingly before answering I went to provide myself with proper Bail and make the best defence in my power as the instructions you received from M.r Benham are not altogether consonant with his understanding with me. He is one of the tradesmen who have already received large accounts, for what they have done for me, and who having my principles and my readiness to discharge my just debt as far my late losses enabled me, consented to allow me the time necessary to settle my affairs. M.r Benham did agree towards the end of July to receive from me L. 30 in addition of L. 50, I paid him last year, — and to wait for the balance of L. 70 and odds — The L. 30 I promised to pay him at the end of August; — and as he sent his Shopman for this sum in the middle of that month, I repeated him that it was to be paid at the end, and told him to call at that time. No person did call and I conceived that M.r Benham was not in want of money and as besetted by other tradesmen far more needful than M.r Benham, and who get little profit from what they did for me, I could not help distributing to them the L. 30 reserved for M.r Benham. However if he consents to comply with his former agreement the L. 30 which I offered will be ready in the course of next week but in such case he must plainly state the epochs in which I shall pay him by instalments. Should he not agree to this proposal, I am ready to meet all proceedings, with the certainty that I should be at a great expence, — but I will have the double advantage of gaining time, to pay in preference the creditor who behaved with more consideration, and to make known through a trial by a Jury to the English public my own conduct and that of the others. —
I am Sir —

With the papers and documents relating to the affairs debit and credit delivered to his lawyers M.r Foscolo has lately forwarded to them certain letters written by M.r Chiefala's in which this gentleman claims the sum of L. 6.–0. 0, — and offers to take in payment either books or any other thing whatsoever. But M.r Chiefala ought to be informed that there exists some other letters in M.r Chiefala's own handwriting, and from which it appears that M.r Chiefala undertook to negotiate for M.r Foscolo some bill of exchange in foreign parts, and that the sum now claimed or to whatever more it might have amounted was to be paid out of the money raised on the bill, — and in fact from one of M.r Chiefala's own letters it appears that M.r Chiefala offered to advance to M.r Foscolo such sum as M.r Chiefala could afford until the transaction of the bills was brought to a conclusion. This transaction however having dropped, and M.r Foscolo's affairs being now in the hand of Lawyers, M.r Chiefala cannot but be considered as any other creditor, and therefore he must prove his claim, and wait for the discharge to the time which will be agreed upon by the Majority of the Creditors; but neither books or goods are to be given to any creditor in particular as there is and each as well as disponible property to cover more than double the actual liabilities of M.r Foscolo; and even in case the property was not sufficient, it must be regularly disposed of and divided among the creditors according to the course prescribed both by the custom and the Law of the Country . — M.r Foscolo's Lawyers however would have cleared examined and settled at once the comparatively immaterial demand of M.r Chiefala, were not that from M.r Chiefalà letters it appears that the L. 6, are demanded out of some secret reason into which they have no business to enquire into. — Nevertheless they conceived that they were bound to make inquires not only into the nature of the claim, but also on the character of the claimant, in order to protect the reputation as well as the interest of their client; and it is with pain that they have discovered that M.r Chiefalà having introduced himself to M.r Foscolo under the reppresentation of an unused and persecuted man, and having thus extracted from him a letter for an eminent Lawyer, and a promise to take interest in M.r Chiefalas concern, whilst it turned out by the evidence of honourable men, and by official communication that M.r Foscolo has been imposed upon on the real reason of the banishment of M.r Chiefalà from his native country; — and although M.r Foscolo may wish that the small sum demanded by M.r Chiefala should be discharged by his Lawyers, still the character of the claimant makes it incumbent upon them not to admit the claim but upon satisfactory evidence; and they deem it clear duty to advise M.r Foscolo to place in the schedule of the money due to him a sum equivalent to the time he has lost and troubles he has employed for M.r Chiefala's affairs; for as M.r Foscolo support himself chiefly by his exention he ought not to be employed by any body without a fair and proper consideration for his time and trouble. They will not conclude without adding that as from the letters of M.r Chiefalà he does not appear very measured in his language, and that die uses hints and expressions unbecoming a gentleman, M.r Foscolo's Lawyers warn M.r Chiefala that in case he does not behave properly, they are informed of any malicious insinuation either written or spoken by him, they shall indict him for libel before the proper Court, and let M.r Chiefala take the consequences of his conduct.

Monsieur, — lorsqu'il vous plaira de faire passer à Monsieur Jullien la medaille et la gravure de Lord Byron, je vous prie de m'en donner avis, non pas 64 George Street Portman Square, mais 25 Devonshire place, Kennington Oval — où je demeure maintenant.
La plupart des familles chez les quelles je donnais des leçon ayant quitté la ville, j'ai pris, par raison d'economie, le parti d'en faire autant.

Si mes services pourroient vous être bons à quelque chose soit pour copier, traduire etc. etc., en m'ecrivant à l'adresse ci dessus je me rendrois immediatement à vos ordre, charmé de pouvoir employer d'une manière lucrative le tems qui me reste.
L'eloge de soi même est toujours déplacé, il suffirà peut être de dire que j'ai reçu une assez bonne education.
Dans l'espoir que les propositions pourront être agrées j'ai l'honneur de me dire.
Votre très humble servant etc.

La vostra lettera non è che un tessuto d'inconseguenze: e prima di tutto, rispondermi per la mano di un altro, appunto quando dovevate rispettare secreti, agire non è da uomo che vantasi di buona Fede. Amico se foste ed informato di tutto, invece di accogliermi freddamente l'altra volta, voi mi avreste subito preso a parte e caldamente detto «'Etaúôa, µìi Keñ6e vóq) Iva eiôoµev fxµ(p(o» Che il Lavoro (piuttosto che la Buona Fede) abbia fatto perdonare in voi cose poche lodevoli, non ne dubito; ma lodarvi pure di Frugalità, ciò mi fa crepare dal ridere! poichè a meno che non la facciate consistere nel mangiare soltanto rape, che cosa è un Digamma, Secretarij, *** Ecc. Ecc. Ecc.? L'essere, una Accusa, pubblicamente punita, non è una ragione ch'ella sia vera; né dall'essere nascostamente addossata, ne segue ch'ella sia falsa: questo non è sempre il senso della Calunnia. Prove sarebbero, sì, Lettere, Documenti, Testimonianze; ma dove è tutto questo Puff? Ecco perchè la Sentenza Greca eravi a proposito citata. Non credere però ch'io mai avrei pensato a ficcarvi nella Seggiola di un Judice, se il caso della Domenica non avveniva. Come sapete voi ch'io risentito non mi sono dell'injuria? sono «***» forse io? ma basta: siete ignorante di tutto! Mette poi, all'ultimo, il colmo alle vostre inconseguenze la fine della vostra lettera. E qua, se per i sacri nomi di «Leggi della Società, opinione del mondo» voi intendete di rendere omaggio a un Microcosmo di PseudoFilelleni, non si parla più: voi avete persa la testa; ma se voi vi volgete verso la Società e il mondo, propriamente detti, «nolóv os šnog (púysv šprog bôóvro>v»! voi; parlare ora di obedire alle leggi dell'una, all'opinione dell'altro, quando e le leggi della Società e l'opinione del mondo voi vi siete sempre millantato di vilipendere?

Mio ottimo amico. — Da più che una settimana io ho lasciato Wells street, e le sue streghe; e credo necessario l'avvisarvi che ho portato meco i tre volumi delle Memoirs of Edmund Ludlow —
Già nell'aprir d'un rustico Sileno
Meraviglie vedea l'antica etade
e a me pure questa mia nuova casa mostrò cosa che mi fece maravigliare — la Marianna — Essa ben ha bottega — nè io la veggo mai — e il primo piano è affittato ad una famiglia inglese con servitù propria —; e tuttavia io non so se rimarrò, perchè non mi sento affatto in pace con me medesimo — Ma era malaticcio, e svogliato di correre molte vie per appartamenti, e presi il primo che mi occorse: bello in vero, lieto, tre stanze, e per una sola lira la settimana e finora mi hanno servito con amore e con onestà: virtù straniere alle arpie di Wells St. Scusate se non vi ho ancora portato il volume delle Metamorfosi. Desidero di cuore vostre notizie, e se mi scriverete qualche riga, ve ne sarò gratissimo —
Il vostro amico. Ecc.

You have probably forgotten My Dear Sir that there is such a Being in the world, as Her who is now about to recall herself to your remembrance, by the strange, and it may be somewhat abrupt measure, of requesting a favour at your hands. — And yet if Ugo Foscolo be the same Ugo Foscolo I had the pleasure of seeing so often at my House in Gloucester place in 1817 I feel assured He will not only forgive my request but (if in his power) will comply with it. —

It is for one of your unhappy Countrymen that I solicit a word of recommendation from you. One of those unfortunate men who have suffered in the good and great cause of liberty — Signor Radici has become known to my Husband, and myself lately, and his own agreable and cultivated manners, and conversation, as well as the character, we have received of Him, from a most respectable Family who are here at present, and with whom He lives in habits of daily intercourse have interested us deeply in his favour.

Signor Radici is now endeavoring to obtain the vacancy in the Dublin University of Professor of the Spanish, and Italian Languages. And a Letter from you in his behalf, as being competent to fill this situation is what He seems most ardently to desire —
Though not personally known to you, He said you may perhaps have heard of him through other as not wholly unworthy the favor He solicits of you through me. —

Now will you and can you My Dear Sir do this good and kind Action? I trust it may be so — and at all events it gives me an opportunity of expressing my remembrance of our former friendly intercourse, and my hope that should we ever be thrown in each others way, it may be renewed —
Mr. Bury will have great pleasure in receiving an old friend of mine, and you will find us both equally glad to have the advantage and pleasure of cultivating your society. —
I remain Dear Sir
with every good wish
yours sincerely etc.

Sir — I am directed by the President and Council of the Athenaion to transmit you a Prospectus of the Institution, and at the same time to request to know, if it could be agreable to you to give a Course of Lectures of the above Institution — There will be a Meeting hold at the house of the Institution, on Friday evening next at 7 o' Clock, for a Rehearsal of the Professors, where your presence is much desired. I am Sir
Your most Obed humble Serv. B. P. Capper Assist Sey.

Milady — I am still the same man, — and since the moment you left England I never lost sight of you; my silence with you was the consequence of a rule — never to write to any friend abroad, — which I kept the more sistematically as whenever I made the slightest exception I was compelled to repent, since the very suspicion that an individual is my correspondent subject him to be sorrounded with spies. However I often reckoned the months and the years since the epoch of our acquaintance; your situation is changed; the age, the countenances, the name of several children then around you are already changed; I am changed too, I passed from the bold thirtyseventh, to the pensif forty fifth, nay I am near the past days of it; and during so long a space of human life I have been overenterprising, overfeeling, oversuffering, worn by solitude work and exile, wondering both at the goodness of some men, and the perversity of others, either for or against me, and the only useful lesson and habit are «never to complain» — Indeed your opinion of my being the same man is rather wrong; for, when I was blessed, — and a blessing it [...]

Carissimo Foscolo. — La conoscenza che mostrate di avere della mia infingardaggine, mi avrà scusato presso di voi di una così lunga dilazione a rispondervi. Ed ora pure non so bene che mi scrivere, tanta è la perplessità nella quale mi ha posto la vostra lettera. Perchè se il lavoro a cui gentilmente m'invitate dà a voi desiderio di uscire della vita, anzi che speranza di uscire della povertà, che sarebbe di me, che naturalmente non potrei avere alcun conforto da una tale speranza, e che assai probabilmente verrei in quel desiderio? — Però lascio ora stare tale argomento e mi ristringo a ringraziarvi della cura che vi siete data d'indicarmi la grammatica del Buttmann — e a pregarvi di scusare la mia stolidezza di avere, scrivendo a voi, chiamato arpie le donne di Wells Str. — Voi non foste mai nella mia necessità di pranzare in casa, e però non potevate conoscerle: e tolga il cielo che io volessi menomamente mirare a farvi il più leggero rimprovero per essermi venuto da voi il consiglio di entrare in quella casa — E ad ulteriore espiazione dirò, che Dio volesse ch'io vi fossi rimasto più a lungo, anzi che venire in questa. Ma spero di uscirne Lunedì, se non trovano cavilli, e di venire a vivervi vicino nel mio vecchio alloggio di Lisson Grove, dove infine io ho tirato innanzi i miei tristi giorni di esilio meglio che in qualunque altro. Intanto addio mio ottimo amico.
Vostro affezionatissimo ecc.

My dear Sir — I want extremely to have some conversation and make some final arrangement with you about the first, and indeed all the four volumes of Dante. The dissertations are ready copied — but in revising them I took perhaps too much interest in the work, and made improvements and additions by which while the edition is bettered in a literary point of view, it may become more embarassing for the printing. I should have called upon you were [it] not for the absolute necessity of sticking to the work which at first was easily made, but to perfect it proves by far more troublesome than I conceived. However all [the] first volume is prepared, and I keep it by me only to make with a cool mind on the manuscript the necessary alterations of style of dates and quotations which although trifling would prove very expensive if made on the proof sheets. But what hangs more on my mind is the length of the various readings and their notes which however are indispensable to justify the many alterations and general system they must be elucidated and proved to a demonstration. But many of my notes may be shortened and their purport placed in the dissertations at the end of volume; — even the whole of the various readings and notes may be placed at the end. Of this I have already written to you, when sent the first nine cantos as since that time I did not hear from you I am at loss what plan to pursue. I am the more anxious to settle about this first volume the more as I must devote now a few days to find some remedy to my sad affairs. Do not believe that if I could I would not call; — but the obstacles to risk myself to a walk for me will amount almost to impossibility as long as I have not completely done.
Your's Faithfully etc.

Caro Scalvini, — Perdonatemi, se intendendo d'albergarvi fra colombe, vi ho messo in mano alle arpie, e ringraziate il cielo d'esserne uscito; ma non abbiate molta speranza di non essere divorato da nuove arpie nelle case di Londra — e d'ogni città e contrada dove sarete forestiero. Or siate ringraziato, Scalvini mio, d'avere pigliato con voi i tre volumi di Ludlow, tanto più che non sono miei; e dacchè sono salvi presso di voi, non m'affretterò a mandarli a pigliare, se non quando avrò incontro. All'amico vostro grecista scriverete, ciò che fors'egli sa, come oltre alla grammatica celebrata di cui vi scrissi, ne è uscita un'altra in Germania, e credo che l'abbiano già tradotta e pubblicata in Londra, scritta dal prussiano Buttmann; e benchè sia meno elaborata di quella del Matthias, è nondimeno creduta men difficile a spiegarsi alla gioventù, dacchè il Matthias pare che abbia scritto piuttosto per gli eruditissimi nella lingua. — Io comincio da due giorni a risentirmi della bile, del mal di capo e della febbretta che mi tormentò in agosto; nondimeno lavoro, lavoro e lavorerò sino a che io sarò uscito o della povertà, o della vita. E questo mi piacerebbe, perchè le fatiche mie sarebbero accorciate, e l'onore maggiore; quando i libri, — specialmente di questa fatta, — muoiono più presto della memoria d'un pover'uomo morto sotto un assiduo lavoro. — Così ad ogni modo mi sento più amico di me; ed occupato ed estenuato scrivendo e pedanteggiando fra due copisti, non sento i bisogni e i pensieri
che nascon d'ozio e di lascivia umana.
E di tutto questo vo chiacchierando per dar piena risposta alle parole della vostra lettera: — non mi sento affatto in pace con me medesimo. —— E voi sapete ch'io predico sempre a me ed a voi sul testo che voi m'avete mostrato nelle massime di Rochefoucauld. — La paresse est une passion dévorante. Or io con tutto il cuore vorrei che m'aiutaste a lavorare in questa edizione di Classici, con molta utilità, a quanto credo, e della vostra salute, e dell'ingegno, e della borsa. Ma da che ve ne ho parlato altre volte, non voglio ora insistere. Bastami che sappiate, che quando vorrete trovare occupazione, e il vantaggio che se ne può ricavare, e compagnia ed amicizia, voi n'avrete sempre dal vostro ecc.

Sir. — I am directed by M.r Foscolo to acknowledge your letter, and at the same time to inform you that the prospectus which you mention as inclosed in the letter, was not in it, — and M.r Foscolo will feel grateful to the President and Council if they will oblige him with the names of the lecturers, — as his occupations and health possibly may not allow him to be attended on Friday evening at the meeting which annunces us your letter is to be held at the large of the convening.

My dear Sir, — The third Epoch is sketched, as I have already stated in my former letter, and the Italian Bride could be ready in less than two days, but I have not in my power to employ the copists, not even for two hours, in any other concern but the only one of Dante's illustrations for M.r Pickering; but to forward it he has supplied me with a third amanuensis who is one of his relations. As to Lord Byron, I am glad of having more thought than written about his article, since what you intend me about the Quarterly Review induced me to take this morning some enquiries, and I learned that Lord Byron himself is abused on account of his interest for the Greeks, — and thus two purpose may be obtained with one paper, namely the character of the poet and patriot — and the refutation of the malignant journal against the poor Greeks; — but since I interrupted my intercourse with M.r Murray, and declared my resolution never to contribute again for that periodical publication, its late numbers were not sent to me, which I attribute rather to the great distance of my house, than to any wish of petty retaliation. As it is, I have not the Quarterly, and in case you could send me it I will look at the article in question, and you shall have the volume returned without any delay. — I am extremely sorry of not being able to supply you with the articles as soon as you apply for them, and at the time, I intended, and promised — but I cannot overcome the two almighty powers that rule mankind, — Nature and Necessity. I cannot exhaust my brain, my eyes, and my hand for more than fifteen hours each day, and yet it is only during the night that I must find leisure to read in my bed books which must be consulted, but being obliged to write all the day, I dare not look at them but during the moments that I steal from my rest. And all that, my dear Sir, whilst my peace, my liberty, and my honour are at stake; for on the beginning of November I must either pay, or go to prison, and in the meanwhile I am labouring under afflictions, difficulties, and humiliations of every description. I should not, I sure have submitted to such labour, more not for some hope of getting rid of my health and life in the most manly way possible; thus nothing will ever induce me to rest from working even beyond my strenght; but not beyond the limits of time. I trouble you with my long letter as usual, as it is Sunday; the copists of course will not work, and I perform as I can my duties towards my corrispondents, — although heaven knows many letters remain unanswered and unnoticed. To you, however, my letters are longer than perhaps they ought, but I find some relief in telling to you every thing, the more as your last letter asks for more articles; and you, have some right to expect that «The second Epoch of Lord Byron» should be forwarded as soon as possible; the only thing I could do to make up for the delay is to furnish you with the two papers already well translated, and fit for the press without any further revisal on my part. But as to any new articles, the melancholy preamble of this letter of mine will convince you that I could not take new engagements without exposing myself to new anxieties for their performance; what could humanly be done for the punctuality necessary to a periodical work it has been contrived by me, as no sooner as I recovered from my illness I never ceased to work for the European Review during forty days without the least interruption; and the manuscripts already with you are the best evidence of my assertion. However no more than one of the five articles forwarded has been remised by me for the press namely the first Epoch which is forthcoming with the forth number. Now, in this way, I will hardly receive the money I have paid to the copists during the forty days. The uncertainty of the time when the other Articles may be published and paid, is of great moment to me whilst I go on, and live from hand to mouth every week in such a manner that were I asked to account for, I really could not explain; but when difficulties grow into impossibilities the project of conquering them is worse than folly. I must therefore look for my daily subsistence, as the first four volumes of the Italian Poets are already mortgaged for the payment of my debts for this house, and whilst I cannot work at them without weekly expence for copists, I cannot expect a farthing from them. Therefore, my dear Sir, unless some arrangement be made, in order that I s[h]ould not wait for remuneration until[l] the publication of my Articles I have no alternative, I must resign my employment for the European Review, and be a workman some where else. I do not pretend to be exempted from the general regulation, or to dictate as it more terms and laws to the proprietors; but as I must receive laws and terms from necessity I could not act otherwise. At the rate of three Articles for each number as they are set down in my plan and your answers to it, I calculate that they will fetch upon average from twenty four to thirty pounds every month, I should therefore expect to receive five pounds weekly, and settle definitively our accounts quarterly, and there receive the balance; and I would at the same time agree and submit to a fine in case my articles were not furnished precisely on the very day appointed and agreed upon possibly the plan of the contract, and the views of the proprietors may not be consistent with the execution of what I propose. And should this be the case I shall by no means complain of their decision, as I hope you will not complain of my resorting to some other occupation, in which the obligation of giving my work ready on a certain day should be counterbalanced by the obligation on the part of my employers to pay regularly a portion at least of wages, and in such way that I should not be prevented from working by actual want. I am aware that periodical, and consequently regular payments are implied in the engagement of discharging the claim of the contributors as soon as the monthly number is published; — but there are often delays in the publication, and moreover many a paper remains unpublished for several months to afford room for other more, either necessary to the variety more calculated for the general interest of the moment. Yet I should not have made any of these reflexions were I not compelled by my circumstances, and my personal regard and friendship with you would have prevented me from coming to explanations, which at the same time are far from being consonant with my feelings; but my silence would be of no use to you; and if my contribution may prove serviceable, I ought for your interest as well as mine to point the way which it could enable me to work in my present situation —
Anima d'Italia — Al più gran Uomo della terra, i di cui scritti m'incatenano alla virtù, vengo dimandare ciò, ch'io perirei prima d'inchinarmi davanti a chi lo credo indegno.

A solo scopo di sostenere la vita, io mi diedi alle scienze esatte, quando fui chiamato in un Collegio per insegnare l'Aritmetica e Calligrafia. L'ardente brama ch'io ebbi sempre per le lettere faceva sì, che coglieva i pochi momenti di ricreazione per leggere ora il nostro Dante, ora Alfieri, ed ora Lei. Cosa havvi ch'io in questi tre aurei Autori io non abbia ammirato? Soventi sentiva la mano divina di Virgilio che mi conduceva dagli inferni sino alle stelle: ora vedeva Saulle invaso, ed ora (lasci, o Grande, che lo dica) sentiva quella passione ch'Ella sentiva ne' colli Euganei, e piansi il suo esiglio! Quindi All'ombra d'un cipresso divorava i versi onore d'Italia. E quelle verità che sparge all'apertura dell'Università di Pavia? E Socrate risorto che instruisce il giovane accademico? Io non finirei; e quantunque seguitassi Ella non potrebbe tacciarmi d'adulatore, mentre è bastante grande per conoscere se medesimo. Ma io educato da questi Celesti alla virtù, come vivere nella nostra Italia? Ho venticinque anni, Signore, e sono venticinque anni che vivo una grama vita, non trovando neppure una persona che si confaccia col mio cuore.

Dopo la piccola rivoluzione in Piemonte tre o quattro anni sono, venne un editto ove, dando l'insegnamento nelle mani de' Frati, e Preti, si proibiscono i Secolari d'insegnare ne' Collegi. Insegnai qualche anno Calligrafia in mia casa; quindi senza dimandare impieghi, partii, sono ormai quattro mesi, lasciando la povera mia madre in pianto. Il fine di questa partenza era di venire a visitare l'Ill.ma sua Persona e quindi imbarcarmi per l'America. Ma o sia ch'io non fossi bene istrutto; o non vi siano leggi troppo bene intese pei Passaporti, il fatto si è che dovetti spendere in viaggi quasi tutto il poco mio danaro senza alcun frutto. Ora mi trovo a Ginevra attendendo che mi diano la permissione d'insegnare l'italiano nelle case particolari; ma quando me l'avranno data staro senza speranza, mentre mi dissero essere difficile l'avere scuolari in questa nazione, che per l'insegnamento de' suoi figli ha di già tutto stabilito.

Starò piutosto qui colla speranza di avere una cara risposta dalla Celebre sua Persona in cui si degni annunciarmi un qualche posto costì ove possa almeno procacciarmi un tozzo di pane senza avvilirmi. Ho scritto una Tragedia, prima mia fatica, che amerei, prima di darla alle stampe, di avere la sua approvazione. Mi sento chiamato alle lettere; ma se non lo fossi, ho due braccia per affaticare, e per poco ch'io abbia costì da' miei travagli, primo sarò sempre contento perchè vicino di Lei; secondo perchè vivo frugalmente.
Ho l'onore di protestarmi
Suo sincero Servo ecc.

Dear Sir — Mr. White has not, neither have I made the least disclosure to your gardener this you may rely upon. And I am persuaded he DOES NOT know where you are — I think he knows only the first address where you was for a week — Unless he has watched Miss Hamilton to your present dwelling which I do not think likely — at all events keep as much in the house as possible — lest you are seen and take the chance — I will do any thing to further your wishes that I am able. Remain
with much respect yours etc.
Sir; — I cannot comply with the advice of seeing Mr. Benham I and since you have applied to me by a former letter, feel justified to declare to you my definitive resolution.
It is by principle that as soon as legal hostilities are resorted to against me, I never suffer that matters should be settled, but through legal gentlemen on my behalf.

It is likewise by principle that I openly declare the means and grounds of my defence. — Let it therefore be clearly understood, that should your client consent to the proposal made on my behalf by my lawyers these gentlemen are fully empowered to conclude the agreement in the most proper and legal manner.

Should your client on the contrary persist in his demand of a portion of the money being paid down, I shall avail myself for my defence of the very Law that enables him to prosecute me, and my very small property will be gone, — but should the claim of your client be involved in my ruin, my conscience and character will remain clear.
Have therefore the goodness to acquaint your client with the purport of this letter which I forward open to you through the gentlemen acting on my behalf.

Lastly it is by principle that I give them instruction to disclose the state of my affairs, since any creditor is in my opinion undoubtely entitled to be made acquainted with the real situation and means of his debtor.

I paid since last June L. 450 and the most part of it through M.rs Taylor and Roscoe on account of several balances owed to different tradesmen for this house, and there remain now about L. 450, still due to them.

I was enabled to pay the former L. 450, by an advance of L. 250 made to me by a Publisher in consideration of an agree ment of L. 1100 to be paid to me by instalments on the delivery of each of the volumes of a certain work advertised in almost all the daily as well as periodical publications. — But as the case of the non–performance of the agreement on my part was to be considered, the more as I may die, or be compelled to charge my library into a prison, a warrant of Attorney to dispose of my property was delivered to the Publisher as a security not only for the money advanced but also for the capital embarked by him in an undertaking of some magnitude. —

These transactions are known to my Lawyers; and my Publisher will prove that no consideration of comforts and health prevented me from devoting myself to an unrellenting labour; and that if no volume as yet has been published it is chiefly owed to the arrest at the suit of Mr. Benham and the natural consequences of it, since the even most friendly amongst the other claimants being on the watch resorted likewise to threats, to expostulations, and to daily callings which by robing me of great deal of time actually distressed my mind. —

It is true that your client was to receive thirty pounds on account, but as I formerly sented to you, far from calling to hear what I could do, or alledge, he resorted to legal proceedings, he claimed at once the whole amount including other items upon which as yet, for ought I know, no definitive settlement has been made, and then resorted to the very legal means which prevent me from discharging my just debts.

Accordingly since my first steps towards a prison will be the destruction of all my arrangements in favour of myself and my creditors, it is but fair that I should contrive to deliver myself for any such troubles during the rest of my life as witness to prove that if I have not been able to pay the most threatening of, I gave up even my weekly subsistence for the benefit of the most needy and distressed among them —— and that in the latter part of last year men divided among my creditors L. 250 lent by a gentleman — and your client did then receive L. 50 whilst at the expiration of six months the loan turned out to be a gambling transaction, and I paid the principal and L. 78 for the accomodation besides all legal interest. I should ruin my very creditors and my character were I, for the sake of the most threatening among them resort once the more to such expedients; and I should at the same time put in jeopardy the very small property which has been given as a security for the large capital embarked by my publisher. —

Let therefore my threatening creditors take their chance —and as for all others as long as they rely upon my honour even in my declared insolvency I am confident that my industry willsoon enable me to listen to the dictates of my feelings and conscience the more as I have taken all the steps necessary that the unavoidable publicity of the affair should not injure my character in the least. Accordingly I keep a copy of this letters and it is for this very reason that I went through to many details. Still I must apologize for its length; — yet it saves us all from the trouble of additional negotiations, and as soon as I receive the answer of my lawyers, I shall surrender in prison —
I am Sir

Dear Sir — The 6.h 7. 8. and 9.h Cantos of the Inferno has come safely to hand, and I observe that the variants are very long — At the same time I do not wish to abridge or curtail any part that is important to the wish or to the Editor's reputation — I have not the least objection to give the public full value for their money — and my only difficulty is to guard against printers impositions — whatever impressions you may have received from what has passed as to size — was intended more for the sake of uniformity and elegance — than for any additional cost that might be incurred —
I remain, dear Sir
Yrs sincerely etc.

ps.p: N.B. — I do not wish to have the references altered if you do not approve of the suggestion, altho' Heyne's Virgil and Dante you sent have the references in the same way, yet it does not prove that theirs is the most useful and best mode of referring.
Heyne's Virgil — has variants and also critical notes therefore figures — above the line could not refer to both.

Dante — has the words repeated — as well as the figure of the line — the notes are explanating and not various readings, — therefore a scholar would seldom require them, but no scholar can form or know what various readings an Author may have, which has not hitherto been collected, therefore I am of opinion that the reference should be immediate that is from text to variants.
The above with deference
very truly yrs etc.

div1.p: Sir — I am glad to inform you that your furniture and effects sold far beyond what I valued them at to your furniture and effects in your Cottage brought about L. 400 being L. 100 more than I valued them at — I not only attended both days of sale and bad on articles which greatly increased their price for you but I also attended on the days of delivery to see that no enjury should be done to promises. —
Here are several people applying to me to take or buy the Cottages but I wish to see you first. — Capt.n James who formerly wished to buy is also applying — Have put Bills to sell or let —
I am Sir
Your Ob. Ser. etc.

Sono arrabbiatissima. Con chi? Nol so nè men'io: non già con voi certamente, cortese amico, che mi avete con tanta gentilezza favorito delle stampe canoviane. Non dovrei esserlo nè manco col signor Vendramin, il quale fece, alquanto però alla foggia di Panglos, tutto, dic'egli, per il meglio. Or eccovi la dolente storia. Fino dal mese di Agosto il S.r Vendramin dice di avere date quelle stampe al Sig.r Neumann secretario dell'Ambasciatore Austriaco in Londra, pregandolo di mandarle al Conte Strasoldo Governatore di Milano dal quale io poi doveva riceverle. Giunto appena, giorni sono il S.r Vendramin, gli chiedo conto delle mie stampe, e ne ho per risposta un meravigliarsi grandemente, che io non le avessi già ricevute. Mi promise di scrivere tosto a Londra, e qualche giorno dopo mi assicuro di avere anco scritto al S.r Neumann, per averne contezza, e ricercarlo se forse non fossero scordate in qualche cantuccio del suo scrittojo. E siccome avrebbe potuto essere accaduta la stessa dimenticanza al Conte Strasoldo, così io gli scrissi, e n'ebbi per risposta, non avere egli nulla mai ricevuto. Ora dunque, amico dilettissimo, abbiate cortesia di fare, o di far fare qualche ricerca presso il S.r secretario.

Saprete che non ho veduto l'Inglese che mi avete indirizzato: me ne increbbe doppiamente e per avere perduto l'occasione di compiacervi, usandogli qualche cortesia, e quella di compiacere a me stessa trattenendomi di voi. Scrivetemi pure quanto più spesso potete col mezzo di questi esseri erranti che trottano spesso per l'Europa sbadatamente, come noi per la piazza di S. Marco. Amatemi sempre ed aggradite i saluti di Giuseppino.
Addio bello e sublime ingegno, addio.

dateline.date: 102 Grt Titchfield St. Oxford Street Decem.r 30th 1824.

div1.p: Sir — I have this morning received from M.r Pickering the two Bills I left with him some time since. Had I have been in possession of them before the Bills became due you do not know the trouble and expence you would have saved me, at which I am surprised at from your little expecting you would have so neglected me after the treatment you always said you received from me and more particularly your not answering one of my Letters as by that I (of course) was obliged to apply to M.r Pickering and M.r Taylor a thing you must know — I never would have done had I have received a Letter from you to have satisfied my mind as to what course I was to steer — You have told M.r P. you had written a long letter to me that is not true as the last letter I had from you was the one sent on the 20.h of November by the Gardener when I received the Check for L. 40 — being for Rent and that a short one — you well know — in the way you was treated about your Letters before not to trust to only one to put your Letters in the Post, as I am fearful they have never been put in or I should have received it — I was at the Cottage to day and have left a Book Paper and Notes with M.r P. for you. You know there is a quarters rent due and for which I shall be much in want of and I trust when you receive the Cash in January you will under all circumstances remit me the Rent and at the same time I must forget and forgive and hope you will favour with a few lines with the return of the enclosed Bill of L. 104. 12. 10 cancelled and will send the others as soon as I have them in my possession that shall be done as you return the enclose Bill —

Yours obedient etc.
Bill
L. 36. 5. 9 Porterage
7. 6v Stamp and discount at 2 Months
8. 8
L. 37. 1.11

D. Sir — I wrote you some days ago and having had several interviews with M.r Neil for M.rs Wishord respecting the sale of your two Cottages as they now stand I have at last being able to get a written offer from him of Forteen hundred pounds for the two Cottages which I think you should accept but the answer is wanted by Monday and the money will be paid instantly — write immediately
I am D. Sir
Yours Ob. Serv. etc.

[...] moreover the smaller house produces for five years ensuing a rent of L. 65, he is more than willing to leave me again in the same alternative either to pay the ballance for the two 90 year leases, or to keep the larger house only for 21 years, that he might sall them both, and perhaps, when sold he would make to me some compensation for the L. 200 lately received, — and thus matters stand again precisely as in the time of our first conversation.

10. I will not deny that it was since this very conversation that I took the two long leases, and however the reasons I stated above may be good, still my friends may accuse me of not having acquainted them day by day, and step by step of whatever I was doing in a concern in which they endevoured to assist me. This, if true, would prove me guilty of want of confidence, but not impeach my veracity; still as in this case the want of confidence would have been attended with want of gratitude, I am bound to justify my conduct. I have been informed a long time ago that no sooner my friends have been acquainted with my difficulties, they kindly intended to extricate me from them, — and I was also told of a plan going about of which however I knew only the outlines, and in which I did not place a great confidence; still I was bade to hope. But while circumstances opposed their kind intentions, my difficulties naturally increased, and become more entangled by the very expedients I was forced to resort to; — and while I was fighting with the attorneys of some of my creditors, and dreading proceedings and imprisonment, my situation was embittered by humiliations, perhaps deserved, but which could not but plunge the knife in the very wounds for which I expected some remedy. I disclosed all my concerns, given the accounts of my debts, the names and titles of my creditors to more than one person who by offering their assistance had a right to request and obtain a candid statement; so I have been talked over, and by persons, and in places which you would not believe, as an object for charity. Yet since a man under pecuniary obligations is not even at Liberty of dying, I felt myself bound first to submit to every mortification until my creditors be satisfied; and to take at the same time all the steps I could devise to satisfy them and restore myself to Liberty and honour. But I did not feel justified to apply again to my friends, and call less to those whose kindness I had already experienced, whose late endeavours had been fruitless, and whose feeling would have distressed again. Then indeed I should have been guilty of a confidence akin to impudence, and of a gratitude looking for more assistance. I remember that in my long letter in Dicember, I told you that my being in the extremity could only prevail on me to trouble you, precisely because you are my friend; — and if I wrote you my last note with the printed account, it was only because I saw the ruin at my door, — nor should I have made that account but for the necessity of answering the question of Lord John on the subject, and I thought I could not send it without sending also a copy to you.

11. As to your advice to put all the affair in the hands of a Lawyer, I was ready to comply with, though none of the three mentioned by you would have been the proper person. As, however Lord Dacre had strictly warned me to be cautious with Lawyers, I wrote him (without, however, making the slightest allusion to you or your last letter) — and while I was writing this justification of mine, I received his Lordship answer ! — 'That any publicity upon points of such nicety is far from advantageous — that I may consider it as an axiom, in english existence, that nothing is so dangerous, so ruinous, and destructive as being in the hands of Lawyers. No one need be acquainted with the difficulties which may exist in your title to your leasehold property but the person who shall claim under it. It does, I must own, seem to me most extraordinary, that your difficulties as to the title should so stick to you. If I were not an impoverished Landowner, I should not hesitate to advance the L. 1300 so soon as the lease was made by the Builder to trustees to hold for your use, subject, always, to the charge of the advance”. — According to this opinion of Lord Dacre there is no need but of Trustees who could advance, or cause to be advanced the money. Whether the houses are so valuable as to deserve to be either mortaged for L. 1300, or sold for L. 1800, this is another question which is not to be decided by Lawyers, but with evaluation of proper surveyors.
Adieu —

Scalvini caro, fratello e figliuolo mio — Il prete vostro Bresciano se sa di greco, troverà molti che si compiaceranno a discorrerne; ma pochi, se pure taluni, da' quali potrà guadagnare emolumenti per via di lezioni. Non v'è ragazzo per non dire bambino al quale nelle pubbliche scuole, e poi ne' collegi, e per ultimo nelle università non s'insegni l'alpha e l'omega a dovere, — in guisa che m'incontro spesso in alcuni sbarbatelli che ti parlano di Tucidide e di Demostene, scrittori difficilissimi, quanto e forse meglio che non ne dissertava quella buon'anima di Butturini. E perchè in Inghilterra per essere ammessi in una delle Università bisogna sapere poco o molto di Greco, nè tutti i padri amano o degnano di lasciare andare i loro figliuoli ragazzi nelle pubbliche scuole molti si pigliano un maestro grecista in casa, — segnatamente i nobili e facoltosi, — e sì fatti maestri casarecci chiamansi Tutori, e spesse volte per la protezione de' loro alunni si buscano vescovadi, e grasse prebende; — però, sperando, moltissimi si danno alla professione di Tutori; e parecchi, benchè valentuomini, si rimangono senza pane: vedete voi dunque se un maestro forestiero di greco potrebbe sperare di procacciarsene; e peggio che peggio perchè il greco d'un Italiano sarebbe lingua planetaria per orecchi Inglesi avvezzi a modellare, strozzare, scarnare le parole d'ogni altra lingua secondo la loro pronunzia fischiante di articolazioni, e nimicissima di modulazioni; — senzachè sino dall'età di Arrigo VIII (quel famoso boja delle sue belle mogli) un prelato suo favorito per nome Gardener, essendo divenuto cancelliere dell'Università di Oxford, prescrisse per tutto il Regno una regola di pronunziare la lingua greca — assurdissima regola, ma serbatasi per tradizione fino a' dì nostri, e venerata appunto perchè la è propria delle Università Inglesi, e antichissima. Quanto alla grammatica Greca, se l'amico vostro si fida di comporne una tutta nuova ne' principj, e lucida nell'esposizione, e men intricata delle altre nel metodo, egli certo potrebbe attenderne onore, e utile; — e s'ei la pubblicasse in Latino, ei n'avrebbe più onore da principio, — e l'utilità vera — parlo di danari — gli ridonderebbe a poco a poco dalla traduzione in Inglese che dovrebbe essere pubblicata simultaneamente; — perchè s'ei la stampa in qualunque altra lingua, ed altri la traduce e la vende a un librajo, i guadagni tutti spetterebbero per legge all'autore ed editore della traduzione Inglese. Inoltre se l'amico vostro si delibera di stampare l'opera sua, fate ch'ei sappia che dov'ei la pubblicasse fuor d'Inghilterra, ogni uomo avrebbe diritto di ristamparla qui, e farne suo pro, senza lasciare all'Autore nè pure il povero diritto di rammaricarsene: e però a volersi serbare la proprietà su l'opera sua in Inghilterra ei deve pubblicarne la prima edizione in Inghilterra. — Quanto al suo pensiero di pubblicare la grammatica in Francese, o con una versione francese a fronte, scongiuratelo ch'ei se ne guardi; — perchè, sia vero o bugia, certo è che gl'Inglesi accusano i Francesi di essere solenni guastamestieri ove si tratti di cose classiche; e sì fatto pregiudizio nuocerebbe anche ad Isocrate Ateniese se risuscitando scrivesse di lingua greca in Francese. Restami a nominarvi la grammatica greca migliore; — nè io so che ve n'abbia alcuna che meriti il titolo di buona fuorchè la sola d'un Tedesco, che ha nome Matthias, e sarebbe ottima opera elementare se fosse più breve. Tal qual è fu adottata da poco in qua anche dalle università Inglesi; — ben so di certo che fu stampata qui e ristampata e venduta e ristampata; — tanta necessità ognuno sente di grammatica greca — lavoro difficilissimo a farsi perché la lingua era liberissima, capricciosa, diversa come i varj popoli che la parlavano, e i capi bizzarri che la scrivevano. Però se il prete vostro pubblicasse qui una grammatica meno voluminosa, ed egualmente utile di quella di Matthias, farebbe danari, — ma con agio e tempo; perchè sì fatti libri scolastici se sono buoni si vendono continuamente ma non mai prestamente. Or addio Scalvini mio carissimo, buonissimo, dolcissimo, e (pur troppo!) oziosissimo. Addio dal cuore.
Tutto vostro ecc.

Caro Scalvini, — Faccio dire alla porta che io sono fuori per iscansarmi da lunghe visite inglesi; ma voi siete sempre il benvenuto e stassera avrete qui il vostro caffè alla bresciana. Il Marchesi vi è venuto dianzi e benchè ei non fosse nel numero di quelli che non dovevano entrare, gli fu detto la bugia, pero scrissi a lui un bigliettino simile a questo. — Addio.
L'amico vostro ecc.

Caro Mammi — Del danaro che m'avrete fatto il piacere di riscuotere sopra la cambialetta che Andrea (il mio scrittore) ebbe l'incarico di portare da voi, non v'incresca di pagare L. 3 al latore mandato dal S.r Mazzoni mercante di Figline Gerald. La cambialetta è dovuta Domenica prossima; — ma secondo l'uso del paese si ha diritto di presentarla Sabbato.
Addio di cuore
Tutto vostro ecc.

Milord, — Perchè a me sempre importa di palesare di quali lettori io più brami il giudizio, io continuo ad intitolare al nome vostro i miei scritti. Ben vorrei poter continuare a dedicarvi poesie; da che quanto è più malagevole a tollerare la trista realtà delle umane cose, e il rimutarle è impossibile, tanto è più savio espediente a scansarle sviando in mondi immaginarj la mente.
Sed neque nos agere haec, patriai tempore iniquo.
Possumus aequo animo: nec Memmi clara propago
Talibus in rebus communi deesse saluti.
N.B. — «Questi versi di Lucrezio lib. I. 41. sgg. se fossero ben tradotti da Chreech o da altri, li citerei più volentieri in Inglese —».

Perch'io mi sentirei colpevole d'ingratitudine verso l'Inghilterra che sì ospitalmente m'accoglie, e d'inumanità verso la Grecia ove nacqui, s'io tacessi i fatti utili a rivendicare la fede della vostra Nazione; utili a consolare i Pargioti nella loro grave calamità. Però mi giovo della verità degli avvenimenti la quale è proprietà di tutti i tempi e paesi; bensì per non trapassare l'ufficio di narratore o i diritti di forestiero, m'astengo dal manifestare le conclusioni che io reputerei più eque insieme e più esatte su la prudenza politica, e su la giustizia del governo che stimò inevitabile la cessione di Parga. E tanto più dubito del mio proprio parere, quanto più dalle altrui controversie ch'io riferisco nella mia narrazione, m'avveggo come i medesimi fatti han fino ad or suggerito non sol congetture ma ragioni e sentenze irreconciliabilmente diverse. — Bensì tutti quelli che malgrado la discrepanza della loro politica professione, stimano in voi la perseveranza ne' principj, la moderazione nel sostenerli, e la generosità dell'intento, e che come voi mirano più alla perpetua utilità della loro patria, che agli interessi momentanei del loro partito, non giudicheranno molto diversamente da voi.
Devotissimo ecc. —
N.B. — «Fatemi il piacere di porre in fine della lettera i complimenti della soscrizione in Inglese».

My Dear Sir — Your acceptance offered by you, and accepted by me as a probable mean to extricate myself from my present difficulties, does not answer the purpose; and I cannot feel justified in keeping it; you will therefore find it here enclosed; — and I am fully confident that as soon as the numbers of the European Review are published you will forward to me each time the amount of the pages printed every months; — you may easily conceive that I mean only the manuscripts in your hands, — and for which I calculate for my actual monthly subsistance, until I can see what will become of me; — and indeed until then it would be impossible for me either to [...] I undertake or to perform any task with a fair probability of not disappointing myself and my friends. —
Believe me dear Sir yours very sincerely etc.

Caro Foscolo — Mi pare, ripensando al vostro progetto che il solo modo in cui 'l potrebbe riuscire, sarebbe di contar sopra di questo solamente come una via di guadagnarvi il vitto attuale e di ricorrere a qualche altro metodo per mettere a parte qualche somma, che vi servisse in caso di bisogno; e se, a quest'effetto vorreste eseguire l'antico mio progetto di pubblicar Dante ossia altra opera classica Italiana by subscription, siate sicuro che io farei ogni mio sforzo di secondarlo quando voi conveniste della cosa. E ciò, perchè io credo che una somma considerevole si potrebbe mettere insieme col mezzo di subscriptions. Se egli è vero che voi avete qui de' nemici, vi siete fatto pure degli amici. Ora bisogna che io faccia lo scandaglio (per così dire) di questa loro benevolenza. Molti vi vorrebbero assistere fino a un certo segno ma pochissimi anderebbero anzi nessuno anderebbe, al di là di quel certo segno. Questi o non potrebbero somministrarvi qualche soccorso importante (caso voi voleste riceverne) o non vorrebbero: dicendo (come io ho sentito dire in più occasioni) a che pro' buttar via i denari che non gli faranno qualche bene essenziale, e mi saranno di grave perdita? Ora il progetto, che io vi consiglio di intavolare non va soggetto a queste obbiezioni; poichè si tratterà di molte piccole somme, e 'l totale sarebbe capace d'esservi d'un utile a non rivocare in dubbio. Poi non v'ha niente in questo progetto che potesse offendere la vostra proper pride, inteso che Pope e molti altri hanno fatto la medesima cosa. Parlate con Hallam, ossia con chi volete di questo, ma per amor di Dio cacciatevi di testa l'idea che si possa guadagnar dippiù di 200 lire per anno, faccendo da Maestro. Forse che io non abbia ben calcolato i profitti di codesto mestiere; ma chi, tranne Zotti e Pananti, faccendolo, hanno potuto metter qualcosa a parte? Vi veggo contar sopra di ciò che non può fruttarvi quel che ve ne siete aspettato, e vi vedrei mille volte più volentieri tornare in Zante, che faccendo la vita che temo che farete quando voi non pensaste ad altri mezzi da guadagnare il vitto.
In fretta e furia
Il vostro ecc.

Mon cher Monsieur. — Demain de bon matin je dois me trouver à mon cottage. Quelques creanciers mettront à l'encher le courrant de la semaine prochaine mes meubles; et s'il n'y aura pas assez d'acheteurs de meubles l'on vendra mes livres et mes manuscrits. Coment en Dimanche l'on ne risque pas d'être arreté je passerai toute entiere la journée de demain a mon cottage peutêtre pour la dernère fois, et je tacherai de preserver, s'il est possible, au moins une partie de mes manuscrits. — Si vous etes dans l'intention de me voir demain, et que le tems soit beau, venez je vous en prie jusque a mon hermitage, et vous pouvez le voir avant qu'il soit indignement gaspillé. —— Ce n'est que un promenade de 15 minutes en voiture, et de 40 tout au plus en marchant. Voilà la route — Portman Square — Baker Street — Upper Baker Street — Park Road, et avant de arriver au bout de Park Road vous lirez a gauche South Bank en lettres cubitales sur le coin d'une allée. — Entrez dans cette allée, et avant de arriver a la fin vous verrez a droit une maison carrée et basse entourée d'un muraille dont la porte a de chaque coté la tete d'un espece de Lion et entre les deux têtes le mots Digamma cottage. Au reste une fois que vous êtes a Park Road tout le monde vous vous indiquera South Bank, ou tout le monde aussi saura vous indiquer Digamma Cottage. Venez–y, je vous en prie, et ne m'accusez pas de ce que je ne vous attend pas ici. Je suis forcé de vous manquer de parole. Adieu.
Votre devoué etc.

Caro Scolare — Viva Evviva Labensky, — Anglice labensky for ever! puisque le brodequins vont a merveille; et malgré mon regret de vous en priver, et leur meretricious ornements assez messeants a ma philosophie et a mon age, je les garde, je les porte deja, et je sens mes pieds frais et à leur aise; — Hony soit qui mal y pense, et je porterai les brodequins, et Labensky for ever! j'espere qu'il vous en arrivera une provision, et s'il n'y aura pas les bigarrures qui feront mettre en doute ma gravité philosophique, tant mieux; — quoique je crois que je n'aurai pas de besoin d'autres brodequins jusque a l'été prochain. Helas! en octobre au plus tard il faudra bien que je me resigne au gros souliers, et au bas de Caire. Adieu. Samedi, ou lundi au plus tard vous aurez un autre volume de Brantome. Tout a vous de toute mon ame etc.

Mon cher Monsieur, — Ce matin l'on livrait votre billet chez moi après que j'etais sorti pour vous demander quelques instants d'entretien, — quoique j'ignore si j'aurai pu vous dire ce que j'ose à peine vous ecrire. Mais je pense maintenant je parle et je me conduit d'apres les ordres aveugles de la necessité, — et c'est d'après les coups de la necessité que je suis forcé de vous prier de m'aider a soutenir ma situation actuelle avec ce qui peut me revenir des leçons que je vous ai deja donné — et non pas d'une maniere à vous en faire tirer beaucoup de profit: aussi je vous ecrit avec le coeur affligé de affliction et de honte, — et j'espere que en me pardonnant vous etes en même tems convaincu que l'extremité seule, dans laquelle je me trouve, a pu m'entrainer à cette démarche. — Agreez en même tems mes remercimens pour votre billet, — ayez soin de votre santé, et quant à la soirée je la laisse en vôtre choix; veuillez bien donner un mot de reponse à mon copiste qui est le porteur de la lettre. Vous trouverez ci joint un prospectus pour les classics italiens et l'histoire de la poesie. — Pardonnez moi je vous en conjure, et croyez moi votre devoué etc.

Mon cher Monsieur — J'ai reçu votre lettre hier au soir tandis que l'on m'appliquait des ventouses et j'ai été forcé de retarder jusque à ce matin des remercimens qui sont d'autent plus sincers et plus vifs que vôtre secours vient de me tirer de la plus triste parmis tant de tristes situations dont mon eventful life a été environnée dans ce bas monde. Mais jusque a present la humiliation et la honte ne se meloient gueres dans mes afflictions; aussi je trouvais assez de courage et d'esprit pour les surmonter. Mais des que l'on doit agir en rougissant il n'y a pas de coeur ni de tête qu'y tiennent; et j'ai perdu l'un et l'autre. Aussi hier je dois vous avoir ecrit de maniere à vous induire en erreur, et votre naturel genereux a donné à mes paroles, — surtout concernant le prospectus — une interpretation qui etait très–eloigné de mon idée. Les cinq volumes du poeme et des illustrations historiques de Dante suivront avant la fin du 1825, — mais quant aux autres je n'espére pas, du moins dans ce moment assez d'acheteurs pour recevoir d'avance le prix de la collection entiere. Permettez moi donc de garder le prix des cinq volumes de Dante, — et de vous considerer pour le restant comme mon creancier. Nous retrouverons une portion de ma dêtte par des leçons; et pour ce qui pourra rester je serai dans le cas de vous en rembourser sans me gêner aussitôt que j'aurai le grand bonheur de me defaire de ma maison. Ne m'envoyez point, je vous en conjure, le reste du montant de la collection; — la liberalité et la promptitude avec lesquelles vous êtes venu à mon secours m'assurent plus d'un mois de tranquillité, et j'espere pouvoir trouver jusque alors d'autres resources, et arranger definitivement mes affaires. En recevant plus d'argent j'augmenterais ma dette, — mais quand même vous me donneriez une fortune vous ne pourriez pas augmenter les obligations et la reconnoissance de mon coeur qui vous est et vous sera devoué —
Dum memor ipse mei dum spiritus hos reget artus.
Et avec ce vers de Virgile je vous dis adieu jusque à Mercredi soir.
Votre devoué et reconnoissant etc.

closer.salute:
A Monsieur
Monsieur Xavier Labensky Hay Hill

div1.p: Mon cher Monsieur — Je vous remercie de votre souvenir, — et je vous en remercie du fond de mon coeur. Je conçois que la saison doit nécessairement occuper une grande partie de votre tems — vous ne pouvez gueres vous en dispenser; — les bals et les fêtes et les concerts que d'autres courent par inclination, doivent être suivi par êtat lorsque l'on est dans votre situation; mais je suis faché que soyez obligé d'en payer l'ecot avec votre santé. Prennez soin de vous en prie — je vous en prie même par egoisme, car votre conversation m'est devenu necessaire. Mes affaires sont toujours ou elles en etoient; avec l'exception que j'ai obtenu quelques jours de delai; aussi je pourrai passer la semaine suivante toute entiere avec mes livres dans le cottage; j'irais y coucher demain soir; — et si dimanche le tems est favorable j'espere de vous voir. En tout cas lorsque vous comptez de prendre votre lesson ecrivez moi un mot par le two penny post toujours R:w Ilass Digamma Cottage Southbank Regents Park — je pourrai pendant la semaine prochaine vous recevoir ici Well Street, puisque je suis obligé de payer le logi jusqu'au 22 du mois; — aussi je puis en livrer quelque parti —
Adieu de tout mon coeur
Tout a vous etc.

div1.head: [ADDENDA]

dateline.date: South Bank, Dimanche matin — [primi di marzo 1822].

div1.p: Vous trouverez, Milady, ci–joint le Manuscrit de M.r Price, et mon opinion selon ma conscience. — Vous trouverez aussi une longue très–longue plus que très–longue lettre et qui malgré l'infinité de sa longueur, elle n'est pas encore finie; — aussi quoique commencée depuis quelque tems, je l'ai gardé toujours avec l'intention de la copier et la rendre moins longue et plus lisible. Mais puisque je n'en ai rien fait, et que vous viendrai demain en ville je l'envois à Chesterfield Street, non pour vous condamner à lire tant de pages, — mais pour vous prouver que je les ecrivais pour vous. J'esperais de dîner aujourd'hui chez le Général, et de vous rencontrer; — mais Madame vôtre belle soeur m'a ensuite prevenu que vous n'arriverez avec Milord avant demain; — ainsi je passerai une partie de ma journée avec un prête aveugle, parent de votre adorateur Lord Glembervie, et le seul voisin avec lequel je puisse parler. — J'ai été jusque à present si occupé, ou pour mieux dire, opprimé de autres choses, qu'il m'a été impossible de donner mes soins à l'Edition de Petrarque. — J'ai neanmoins envoyé vos vers les imprimés et les inedits à la presse, et je crois que vous aurez les éproeuves à corriger vers le milieu de la semaine; — ensuite la belle Edition pourra paraitre en peu de jours. — Ayez la bonté, Madame, de donner a Milord le papier ci–joint à fin qu'il voie le resultat d'une affaire dont je l'ai informé, et qui m'a tracassé pendant deux mois et demi, — mon Irlandais ayant fait son possible pour augmenter les obstacles, les delais, et les calomnies contre moi. — Maintenant que les Arbitres ont decidé contre lui, l'on me dit qu'il menace d'envoyer aussi un cartel à l'ami même qu'il a choisi pour son propre Arbitre — Adieu, Madame, — veuillez bien me croire toujours votre devoué de toute son ame et pendant toute sa vie — Ecc.

[...] in Venezia, Verona, e Padova, che pur ve ne sono, Editori di opere periodiche, ma de' quali non ho mai saputo nè pure i nomi. E perchè il S.r Crowe non potrà stare a lunga dimora in tante città d'Italia ch'ei deve pur visitare, quanto più le vostre gentilezze saranno pronte, tanto più le parranno cortesi, e riesciranno utilissime, — ed io ve ne sarò riconoscentissimo, nè voi nè gli amici vostri starete a rischio veruno da che il mio raccomandato non è scrittore di parte politica, e gli studj suoi non hanno altro intento che la pura ed innocente letteratura. Addio da tutta l'anima; — E i miei ossequii al Conte Velo il vecchio ch'io saluto
«Così, come per fama uom s'innamora»
Addio — L'amico vostro — ecc.
