Mon cher Monsieur. — Voici une lettre pour votre Ami Dupin. — Ayez la bonté de lui dire que je vous l'envois ouverte à fin de vous debarasser des avanies des douaniers. Je lui parle de mon projet de un Journal de Litterature Etrangere ici; et je vous prie de lui laisser lire les Memorandums que j'ai barbouillé pour les articles dont je vous ai prié. — Acceptez mes remerciments pour vos nouveaux presents. Vous m'avez comblé de faveurs, et je ne vous ai pas même donné du fer pour votre or. Ainsi je suis plus ladre que Diomede. — Mais je tacherai de rêtablir mon caractere en fait de generosité, ou du moins de reconnaissance. En attendant Adieu de tout mon coeur, et bon voyage. — Adieu. J'ai oublié de écrire dans mon Memorandum sur les portraits que celui qui le vend à meilleur marché est un Italien nommé Valardi, — mais que néanmoins il faut marchander avec lui, parcque quoique bon chretien à l'Eglise, il est dans sa boutique le plus juif du monde.
Adieu de tout mon coeur, et tout de bon.
Tout a vous. Ecc.

div1.head: MEMORANDUMS.
div1.p: Les articles devroient être de deux especes. — Premiere Espece —. des Articles ou plustot des Essais de la façon de l'Edinburgh et des Quarterly Review, — ou des Mémoires de l'Accademie Française. Le sujet y doit être epuisé, et l'on pourra etendre l'article à trente pages de 8vo de petit caracteres. Il faudra toujours prendre pour texte un ouvrage nouveau, comme pour le passer en revue; mais si l'ouvrage n'en vaut gueres la peine, on pourra prendre congé de son auteur après deux ou trois pages de revue, — et l'ecrivain de l'article doit traiter le même sujet avec plus d'ordre et de profondeur — Mais il ne pourra jamais s'ecarter du sujet. L'on conseile surtout de ne jamais donner des raisonnements sans des faits, — ni des faits sans de raisonnements: — les fait doivent être detaillé autant que l'espace de 20 ou de 30 page le permet, — mais les raisonnement doivent etre rapidement enoncés, plustôt en forme de conclusions que de principes. L'ecrivain pourra donner un Essort libre a ses opinions. Les sujets Politiques traités historiquement seront toujours a preférer; et surtout depuis 1749, jusque a nos jours; — l'on raccomande à l'ecrivain de parsemer son article de anecdotes et de traits remarquants de la vie et du caractere des hommes publics. Enfin l'on doit se garder de tout ce qui pourrait sentir la déclamation et la rage de parti. Les Articles seront traduit en Angleterre, et ils auront necessairement a subir quelques alterations dans la forme pour les adapter au gout du public Anglais; mais l'on ne touchera pas ni aux faits ni aux opinions des ecrivains. Pour chaque feuille de 16 pages in 87o que l'on publiera en anglais de ces Article l'on remettra la somme de 200 francs a l'ecrivain en France — Seconde espece. —— Les Articles doivent être plus legers, et ne depasser jamais six ou sept pages. L'on preferait des court examens critique sur les ouvrages; et des anecdotes sur la vie des ecrivains celebres de la France; mais surtout des poetes anciens anterieurs au regne de Henry IV. Il faudra dans ce cas inserer dans l'article les pieces ou le moins connus, ou les plus estimables de ces poetes. — Pour le reste on prie tout ecrivain de ces petits articles de se tenir aux directions que l'on a donné pour le long. Les ecrivains de ces petits articles recevront pour chaque 16 page d'imprimée en Octavo dans les ouvrages periodiques de Londre la somme de 150 Franks.

Voglia il Cielo, mio caro amico, che non abbiate ricevuto un'altra lettera senza data, ma col mio nome e che vi scrissi. Sebbene io conservi per voi lo stesso animo schietto e amicale, pure, troppo credula alle invidiose lingue che per la vostra parzialità nel ricordarvi di me co' vostri doni letterarj, seppero più e più volte lacerarmi nella parte la più delicata, qual è il decoro, e per sommo mio dolore farmi comparire voi stesso autore di siffatte iniquità, confesso il vero, troppo credula, lo ripeto, vi scrissi poche righe scortesi.

Non le abbiate per accette, perchè io le revoco, abbiate però la bontà di non scrivermi per ora, e nel caso che mi scriviate, non mi mandate mai lettere per persone particolari, ma servitevi della Posta per il qual mezzo resta fra noi soli il piacere di scambievole amicizia che vi manterrò eterna, essendomi gratissima la memoria delle dolcissime ore passate in vostra compagnia.

Addio; a miglior tempo vi dirò tante cose che ora non posso per molte ragioni. State sano, conservate la vostra salute come il vostro ingegno per il ben vostro e per l'utilità degli altri. Vi rinnovo le mie proteste di gratitudine, d'amicizia e di desiderio d'esservi utile a qualche cosa. Addio. Sono la vostra

Madam, — You will receive from M.r Hobhouse a small parcel for one of your young ladies, and a small round table for your own use whenever any of the young ladies oblige you to pass a sleepless night at a ball, and consequently to want on the next morning your breakfast near your best side; I send it with more pleasure at Whitton Park as it was made under my direction at my cottage when I acted as a builder a gardner an upholster and cabinet maker. Believe me, Madam, your's Ladiship's devoted servant ecc.

[....] Les sculpteurs les plus célèbres avouent que ses modelles egalent les chefs–d'oeuvres des grands maîtres en bas–reliefs, et les critiques les plus dégoutés regardent les traductions de ce que cette Dame a fait de un grand nombre des poèsies de Petrarque comme inimitables et digne de l'original. Elle a aussi composé des tragédies qui sans avoir encore obtenu l'approbation des spectateurs font neanmoins les charmes de tous les lecteurs. Ainsi Lord et Lady Dacre meritent d'être connus de vous, et de vous connoitre; et j'espere qu'à Leur retour en Angleterre il me porteront de vôtre part l'assurance que vous m'avez pardonnez mon long silence. Pardonnez aussi mon mauvais francais, et veuillez me ecrire,
Votre devoué etc.

Dear M.r Bentley — Having called on M.r Murray and missed him, and Mr. Murray having called on me and missed me, I have just written to him requesting him to send to you whatever directions may seem to him most proper with regard to the large paper copies, — I hope to be able on Saturday next, and certainly on Monday, to send you the proofs of the second Essay. I am, Dear Sir, Your's Sincerely Obliged ecc.

Dear Sir — I am aware I ought to apologize for my importunity — but I cannot leave town without having previously arranged so as the Edition be completed without my further assistance; — Be, therefore so good as to send me the last proofs as soon as they are done, — and I will soon after call upon you in order to give you the pages preceding the work, and direct your men how they ought to be printed — I have send the last proofs the “third Essay” by the two penny post, and hope you have received it — and it may be freely printed.
Every Your's ecc.
Carissimo — Stassera dovrò sedere a tavola con Inglesi; se vi farete compagnia con S.ta Rosa gli darete i guanti ch'io credendo vostri ho portato jeri a casa vostra —
Vive Vale — Ugo —

A me rincresce, mio caro amico — me ne rincresce assaissimo — d'avere sperato di vedervi, et dextram jungere dextrae, ed è pur gran tempo ch'io non odo novelle di voi; — Parto domattina (Sabbato); nè voi tornerete prima di Lunedì; — se mai verrete in Londra fatevi insegnare la Strada di S.t John's Wood, e quando sarete agli Alpha Cottage dimandate di un viale su la sponda del Canale, e chiamasi South Bank, dove se chiederete di me, i vicini vi indicheranno la casuccia mia. Anzi perché non possiate sbagliare eccovi il mio indizio: — S.t John's Wood — South Bank — Digamma Cottage. Addio dal cuore — ecc.

Madam —— you will think me very much in fault in having delayed to thank you, and I must plead guilty — nor I will alledge my ill health as an excuse, but my ignorance of the English language for I had taken it into my head to write to you and for you the thanks that I owe particularly to yourself. Receive then, Madam, my warmest thanks, and believe me it gives me sincere pleasure to hear that your health is almost reestablished — and at the same time I hope you will accept a kind of canledstick bronzed by my own artist; — and cast with the intention of being offered to you —
I am Madam
Your most obedient and grateful ecc.

argument.p: Mr Foscolo's Propositions to be submitted to the Arbitrators appointed to decide on the dispute between him and Dr Williams

div2.p: The Decision by Two Arbitrators has been assented to by Dr Williams after a Letter written by Mr Campbell to the said Dr Williams, of which the following is a Literal Extract:

«I am authorised by Mr Foscolo to repeat in writing the Answer to Your Message, which he delivered verbally to your friend — Namely, that before an Affair of Honour could be spoken of the business as a Money–business, must be sifted, either by Legal Judges as you have threatened to lake him to Law, or by Arbitrators as you have proffered Arbitrators. He said to Your Messenger and he authorises me to repeat, that if You can prove before a Judge or an Arbitrator, the slightest injustice or dishonourableness either in act or intention on His pact towards You, He will give You the satisfaction of a Gentleman. But he believes the injustice or dishonourableness of intention to be on your part; and until you shall disprove this to be the case before a Judge or an Arbitrator, he holds it unworthy of Himself to have an affair of Honour with You».

These being the preliminaries to which both parties have agreed, the Arbitrators ought to decide both on the price of the Translations, and the respective Injustice or dishonourableness of either party during the whole course of the Transaction. As for the price of the Translation Mr Foscolo leaves it to the choice of the Translator whether the decision of the Arbitrators be grounded on the Agreement between him and the Author, or on the quantity of the originals of the Author which are still in the possession of the Translator.

If the basis of the decision be the Agreement, namely «That the Translator is entitled to receive the fourth part of the sum derived from the writings of the Author, then ought Mr Murray to be called in as a witness, because the Article translated by Dr Williams, was made for the Quarterly Review; and in such case the decision ought to be grounded not so much on the quantity and quality of the translation, as on the sum allotted to it by the Publishers of the Article.

If on the other hand the Arbitrators ground their decision on the quantity of the Original, they are requested to consider not only the quantity but also the worth of translation, and consequently the use which any Author might make of it, and the advantage any publisher might derive from it. — And in order that the Arbitrators might make a correct calculation of the quantity of the Manuscript, part of the said Manuscript may be printed with the types, lines, and sizes of the pages of the Quarterly Review, and Mr Foscolo will pay the Printer's bill. —

As for the more or less Justice and honourableness of the Author or the Translator during the course of the whole transaction; The Arbitrators must have before them, the whole of the Correspondence between both parties, as well as the Letters written by their respective friends on the subject: and the parties and friends ought to pledge themselves to state on their honour, the facts which they know concerning this Transaction. If the Arbitrators cannot agree, either on the price or in their judgement on the behaviour of the respective parties, they will name a third person to perform the office of Arbitrator, with them. Their decision shall be considered by the parties as peremptory, and be submitted to without any right of further appeal.

Mr Foscolo has chosen for Arbitrator Mr Reading — a Gentleman connected with a periodical publication, and possessing a full knowledge of the prices given for Translations: And accordingly Mr Foscolo will deliver to him a copy of these Propositions.
Ugo Foscolo.

In regard to the matter at issue between Mr Foscolo and Dr Williams we find that the latter had engaged to translate, correct and prepare for press, the manuscript articles of Mr Foscolo, at the rate of 25 for cent. The quantity completed according to this engagement is 30 pages, the percentage upon which, due to Dr Williams, is L. 15. 15. 0. It is evident that payment of this sum could not, in justice, be claimed until the matter translated shall be printed and published; Mr Foscolo, however, waiwes his ground of right, and insists upon acquitting forth with what shall be decreed by the arbiters to be due to Dr Williams.

We find the said sum of L. 15. 15. 0. liable: — First, to a deduction of 5 L. advanced by Mr Foscolo, in consideration of the pecuniary necessities urged by Dr Williams in letters which have been submitted to us, and 2.ndly to a charge for lodgings, engaged for Dr Williams by Mr Foscolo; in case Dr Williams does not arrange for the same within twelve days from the date of this award. We further adjudge that the overplus of translation, made by Dr Williams, beyond the matter thus disposed of shall be paid for at the stipulated rate of 25 for cent after such translation, as so much of such translation, as Mr Foscolo may use, has been printed.

A claim of 4 L. has been peremptorily insisted upon by Dr Williams, as due to him from Mr Foscolo, for services previously to the 25 for cent engagement; but Dr Williams not having come forward to substantiate the same, although two days have elapsed since he was called upon and promised so to do, we have dismissed all consideration of it.

Finally we find that the sum of 30 L. upon which the differences between the parties arose, was prematurely demanded by Dr Williams in an ill judged and unjustifiable manner. With respect to Mr Foscolo, we are of opinion that his conduct towards Dr Williams has been, throughout their mutual transactions, considerate and perfectly honorable.
Signed
C. Reading
Edward Baldwin
Arbiters
Dated this 28th day of March 1822.

div2.n: II. Progetto per una rivista di letteratura europea

argument.p: Plan for a Periodical Work on Foreign Literature

div2.p: The Periodical work on Foreign Literature to be written in English, and published under the title of «Quarterly Review of Foreign Literature». The size, paper, and number of pages equal to the Quarterly or the Edinburgh Review. To preserve some distinction, with some oeconomical advantage, the type may be a degree larger; the price the same.

All new works in French, German, Italian, Spanisti, Russian, and modern Greek, deserving particular notice, shall be reviewed, and advantage taken of new Editions of old Foreign Authors, in order to trace, at different times in the journal, the most interesting periods of the Literary history of Foreign nations. Large extracts from works, not yet published, and ancient Manuscripts shall be procured by the Editor, and occasionally inserted, so that in the course of a few years the Journal may also offer a collection of Literary curiosities. A particular attention should be paid to the fine Arts.

Under the title of Foreign Literature a portion of English Literature and manners shall also be comprehended; — as, all accounts of Foreign countries by English Travellers, and Travels of Foreigners in England; — all English Translations — all Historical works, and even Tragedies, Novels, and works of Imagination of which the scene of action is placed out of England; and whenever Foreign and English authors treat the same subjects, their works shall be compared; — lastly, all English Political writings and diplomatic public documents, which can concern the connexion of England with other Governments.

Classical Learning shall also occasionally find place in the Journal, and the opportunities for writing on this subject will be afforded by editions of the Greek and Roman authors published on the Continent, and compared with the Classics edited by the British Universities.

Besides a series of articles the Journal shall contain at the end of, each number an Index of all new works published in every part of the world, each work accompanied by anecdotes and criticism more or less brief according to its importance. Such a periodical Index, although often attempted, has never been properly executed, nor can it be effected but by a regular correspondence both with extensive Booksellers, and eminent Literary Men on the Continent. They will find it their interest to forward early notices, and even to send a great quantity of their new Books in exchange for the Journal in which their Publications are spoken of. This Index will naturally be very abundant of matter, and must be printed in very small characters.

Some of the contributors shall be Foreign and others English. Foreigners are indispensable for whatever concerns matter of fact on their own Literature and country, and chiefly on the performances and reputation of their living Authors. Works reviewed and interesting papers written by the most distinguished Literary characters of every Country will be early procured, as the writers will be stimulated by two powerful motives; that of the gratification of freely expressing and publishing their opinions, safe from the grasp of the police, — and that of receiving a larger remuneration than they can expect from the Publishers of their own Country.

English contributors are indispensable, to give a national stamp to the Journal and adapt the Essays to the taste of the English reader, as many in England are well acquainted with different branches of Foreign Literature, and some of them may materially assist the Editor in the style of the Articles.

No article furnished by any English writer shall be admitted until previously approved of by the Editor, and the Author consents to make the alterations the Editor may deem necessary. As to the Foreigners, those from whom contributions have been requested are already informed that their articles will necessarily undergo many alterations, both on account of the translations, and the taste of a different public. The facts shall be always left untouched, but if accompanied by reflections not consonant with the feelings of the English Nation, and the purpose of the Journal, such reflections shall be omitted.

As the Literary connections of the Editor both in England and on the Continent, enable him to prepare all the necessary materials, any assistance on this score from the Publisher, although desirable, will not be insisted on.

As to the pecuniary remuneration, that of the English Contributors should be fixed by the Publisher, according to the reputation of the Author and the merits of the paper, and paid by him without any interference of the Editor.

The remuneration to Foreigners should not be less than L. 10 nor more than L. 12 per sheet, including the expences for translations, which from the absolute necessity of their being excellent will cost from L. 3 to L. 4 per sheet. Thus Foreign Authors would clear from L. 7 to L. 8 per sheet, a sum nearly double [than] that received by a first rate Author in Paris.

The remittances to the Foreign Author shall be made by the Publisher and the remuneration to the Translators paid through the hands of the Editor, in order to enable him to keep those Gentlemen under his immediate direction and controul, to make them alter and correct their manuscripts under his own observations as often as he deems necessary. Translators in general seldom give their whole thoughts to the work, and are often of a disposition rather difficult to manage.

The copy–right of the Journal shall belong in equal portions to the Editor and the Publisher; — the one furnishing his labour, the other his capital; both using their utmost exertions for the establishment and success of the concern. The Profits therefore shall be equally divided between both. Each of them shall have the right to dispose of his share, but not until he has given a preference to his partner in the option of purchasing it.

Three restrictions however ought to be agreed upon. 1st in case the Journal cover the expences, neither the Editor or the Publisher can relinquish the concern until after two years of experience that no profits of real consequence are to be made. — 2nd that if, on the contrary, the success of the Journal be rapid, the Editor must not give up the Editorship or dispose of his share of the copy–right until after four years, unless by permission and agreeement of the Publisher. — 3rd But if, after the first year, the sale of the Journal does not cover the expences, the Publisher and the Editor are at liberty to make those arrangements which may be best suited to their respective interests.

The Editor that he may attend exclusively to the work, should receive during the first and if necessary during the second year L. 400 per ann. paid quarterly on the publication of each number. — This however should not be considered as a standing salary, but as an advance to be deducted from the share of the Editor, as soon as the division of the Profits takes place.

For any particular Articles the Editor may write, the remuneration should be taken from the general expence, at the same rate as for the articles of the best English contributors. But the Editor will not always insert his own papers, and at all events will never insert more than one in each number, or in case he does, he shall be paid for one only. Nor will he receive remuneration for any portion of pages he may add to the articles of other contributors.

Out of the general expences should be paid also L. 120 per ann. to a kind of literary Clerk acquainted with Foreign languages, possessing a fair penmanship, to facilitate the literary correspondence with contributors, to have immediate communications with the Publisher and the Printer, to correct the proofs, and transcribe manuscripts. This Gentleman ought to be left to the choice of the Editor. But if the Publisher thinks that some individual already employed by him may act instead of a regular clerk, then the standing salary of L. 120 will be unnecessary.

To prevent the common complaint of the unperiodical publication is of periodical works, and the still greater disadvantage of hurrying writers and printers, the first number should not be published until the second is also printed, with the exception of the Index of new works which should be done as late as possible, see sec. 5. — Thus having half a year in advance, each number may be perfected by a mature revisal. This is the more necessary to a work that contains many translations, the language of which requires to be carefully polished, in order that the elegance of style may atone for the want of the original spirit, which it is often beyond the power of the most skilful translator to preserve.

The undertaking if thus conducted cannot fail to prosper. But besides the Capital and connexions of the Publisher, and the reputation and literary experience of the Editor — a reciprocal confidence is absolutely necessary. The Publisher and Editor should never interfere with each other in their respective exertions. — The Editor placing an unlimited confidence on the oeconomical administration of the Publisher and the Publisher on the Abilities of the Editor, each will respect to a scruple the jurisdiction of the other. If the one ever conceives that the other is not strictly performing his part of the agreement, an open explanation will be the only remedy, provided it be done without delay, especially without any participation of others. And any misunderstanding that may arise between the Publisher and the Editor must be the most important secret of the whole concern.

As to the political tendency of the Journal the writer of this plan thinks that the Editor of a Periodical work of this nature should look at all nations only in a historical point of view, and with as much impartiality as if they were not his contemporaries. — At all events as he intends to assume professedly and in his own name the Editorship of the Journal, and thus to become responsible to the Reader and the Laws for whatever may be deemed obnoxious, he thinks proper here to declare, — that he will not before the public be guilty of any direliction of his known political principles, nor guilty before the laws of opposing the Government of a Country where he sought refuge, and found hospitality. No man in power shall be flattered, no individual abused, no book censured nor praised, and no party feeling nor interest supported in the Journal.

p.hi: An Extract from the letter to M.r Hallam

div2.p: In sincerity I declared in the plan, «that the Editor of such a periodical work, as that I propose, should look at all nations only in a historical point of view, and as if they were not his contemporaries». I But history and impartiality must always lead, though slowly, to some conclusions; and the mind cannot help endeavouring to draw from facts some general maxims; — now I believe that from a survey of the Literature of all nations, will certainly arise and imperceptibly establish itself the whiggish conclusion — viz — that although the quantity and forms of the intellectual stock differ in each Nation still their literary acquirements are all derived from the same origin, and are in substance the same, and will consequently end in obtaining the same result of assimilating the opinions, manners and sentiments of all European nations; so that, each of them, though at different stages, meeting more or less impediment in their way, are all proceeding in the same direction, and, in all probability, constitutional governments will be established throughout Europe. This conclusion indeed, must spring from facts only as the Editor in order to meet readers of opposite views and opinions in Politics should avoid even the appearance of any political purpose or system; still it will be a whiggish conclusion which cannot fail to alarm the Tories of every nation, particularly those who to spread and support their principles, contribute to the Quarterly. —

div2.p: A MEMORIAL to be registered of AN INDENTURE of Lease bearing date the twentieth day of April in the year of our Lord One thousand eight hundred and twenty two and made between Walpole Eyre of Montagu Place in the parish of Saint Mary le bone in the County of Middlesex Gentleman of the first part James Burton of Mary le bone Park in the said Parish architect of the second part and Charles Davis of Great Tichfield Street in the said parish of Saint Mary le Bone Bricklayer of the third part whereby the said Walpole Eyre on the nomination of the said James Burton and in consideration of the Rents and Covenants thereinafter reserved and in consideration of the expence which the said Charles Davis had been at in erecting the messuage and Premises thereby demised and in pursuance of all and every power the said Walpole Eyre there to enabling Did appoint demise and lease unto the said Charles Davis All that piece or parcel of Ground situate and being on the North West side of a certain newly made Road called South Bank leading from the North East Side of Saint Johns Wood Grove in the said Parish of Saint Mary le Bone and County aforesaid together with the messuage or dwelling house and buildings lately erected and built thereon by the said Charles Davis and which premises are part of the Saint Johns Wood Estate and are with the contents abuttals and boundaries thereof delineated in the plan drawn in the margin thereof be the same more or less with the appurtenances thereto belonging and all which premises are abutted on the North West Side thereof by Ground being part of the slope of the Regents Canal and intended to be let to the Regents Canal Company TO HOLD the same unto the said Charles Davis his Executors Administrators and Assigns from Midsummer day One thousand Eight hundred and thirteen for the term of ninety nine years Yielding and Paying therefore yearly and every year and in that proportion for any lesser time than a year unto Henry Bolton Charles Pole and Claude George Thornton in the said Indenture mentioned and their Heirs or unto the person or persons for the time being entitled to the said demised Premises in remainder or reversion immediately expectant upon the determination of the said term from Michaelmas day then last past the yearly Rent of Twenty five pounds payable quarterly during the said Term which said Indenture of Lease as to the execution thereof by the said Walpole Eyre James Burton and Charles Davis is witnessed by Charles Freeth Clerk to the said Walpole Eyre and as to the re–exution thereof by the said Charles Davis for the purpose of registration is witnessed by Henry Parker and George Waugh the Younger Clerks to Messrs. Bromley of Grays Inn in the said County of Middlesex Gentlemen and his hereby required to be registered by the said Charles Davis.
AS WITNESS his hand and seal
CHARLES DAVIS
Sealed and delivered in the presence of HENRY PARKER Clerks to Messrs Bromley GEO WAUGH JUNR. Grays Inn.

p.hi: Articles of Agreement made & entered into this 12 day of February one thousand eight hundred & twenty two Between Charles Davis of 102 Grt Titchfield Street in the County of Middlesex Bricklayer of the one part and Ugo Foscolo of 16 Wigmore St. in the said County Gentleman of the other part.

div2.p: First the said Charles Davis in consideration of the Agreement hereinafter contained on the part of the said Ugo Foscolo and of the Rent herein after mentioned, hereby agrees to erect and finish fit for Habitation by Michaelmas day next ensuing or as soon thereafter as possible a Cottage forty feet square or thereabouts on a piece of Ground or Land situated on the South Bank St Johns Wood in the parish of Saint Marylebone in the said County of Middlesex between the two Houses now taken & in the possession of the said Ugo Foscolo & which said piece of Ground contains in front about one hundred & sixteen feet or thereabouts as the same is now, inclosed & fenced in and in depth in a line, with the adjoining gardens such Cottage to be after the plan of the Cottage now taken by the said Ugo Foscolo except as to the size & to be two rooms instead of three at the back of [the] house next the Canal with one extra water Closet & Dressing room where the China Closet is in the other House. The basement story to be laid out in a similar manner to the one now taken ex[c]ept the same shall contain three Sleeping Rooms instead of one. And the said Charles Davis hereby further agrees to grant a Lease of the said Cottage and Garden for the term of twenty one years determinable nevertheless on six months previous notice at the end of the first seven and fourteen years at the clear yearly Rent of Eig[h]ty seven pounds payable quarterly. And the said Ugo Foscolo for the considerations aforesaid hereby agrees to accept and take a lease of the said Cottage and Ground for the said term of twenty one years determinable as herein before mentioned from Michaelmas day next ensuing at the yearly Rent of Eighty seven pounds & also to pay and bear the Sewers Rates and all other Taxes and Charges of every description such Lease to contain all further usual Covenants on the part of the Lessee and as are contained in the Original Leases of the Houses in that neighbourhood and also to pay for such Lease and Counterpart which is to be prepared by the Solicitor of the said Charles Davis. And the said Ugo Foscolo hereby further agrees so soon as he shall have or be entitled to the possession of the said premises to lay out & plant with fruit & other trees and Shrubs the Ground belonging to the same premises as a Garden with fit and proper Gravel walks. And for the due performance of this Agreement the said Ugo Foscolo doth hereby bind himself to the said Charles Davis the penal sum of Three hundred pounds to [be] recovered as liquidated damages. In witnes whereof the said parties have hereunto set their hands the day and year first above written.
Charles Davis
Ugo Foscolo
Signed and delivered in presence of Wm G. Graham W. Smith

p.hi: Memorandum of Agreement made this Day Feb.y 12 1822 between Charles Davis of No 102 Grt Titchfield Street Oxford St. Bricklayer of the one part and Ugo Foscolo Esq.r, of No 16 Wigmore St. Cavendish Square Gentleman of the other part both of the parish of St. Marylebone in the County of Middlesex.

div2.p: The said C. Davis agrees to Let & the said Ugo Foscolo Esq.' agrees to take the Cottage next to the one already taken situated in South Bank St. Johns wood in the same parish & County for twelve months for the Sum of L. 40 — as agreed in a temporary way until the one is built and finished as agreed on. The two bed rooms only to be papered. Possession of this Cottage to be given up as soon as the said New one is finished & the said Ugo Foscolo Esq.r removes into his new Residence or within 1 month after, without any Deduction. And it is further agreed the Cottage taken for 3 years shall expire after the first 12 months of the said term — at the opinion of said Ugo Foscolo Esq.r on his removing to his Cottage going to the built and giving me possession.
C. Davis
Ugo Foscolo

p.hi: Memorandum of an agreement entered into this twelfth day of February in the Year one thousand eight hundred and twenty three between Ugo Foscolo of Degamma Cottage South Bank St. John's Wood in the parish of Marylebone in the County of Middlesex gentleman of the one part and John Banim of the City of Fli/kinny in the Kingdom of Ireland gentleman now residing at South Bank aforesaid of the other part.

div2.p: The said Ugo Foscolo agrees to let and the said John Banim agrees to take a certain Cottage with Garden attached thereto situate and in South Bank Saint John's Wood aforesaid called Cappa Cottage and adjoining Degamma Cottage on the Lisson Grove side thereof for the term of five years to be computed from the twenty fifth day of March next at the yarly rent of sixty five pounds to be paid quarterly, all taxes soever rates and other rates what soever (ground rent only excepted) to be paid by the said John Banim to the said Ugo Foscolo or to any person or persons specified by him as the holder or holders of the original lease and the said John Banim also engages never to disturb the said Ugo Foscolo in the possession of the two rooms originally belonging to Cappa Cottage but now annexed to the Flower Garden of Degamma Cottage nor of that part of the Garden that belonged to Cappa Cottage but now annexed to Degamma Cottage the said Ugo Foscolo to have the full and undisturbed enjoyment there of and right of entry on the home. The said Ugo Foscolo hereby agrees to build within six months from the date hereof a front wall with two gates entering from the road and a side wall unto the said Cappa Cottage and of the height of the wall of Degamma Cottage and the said Ugo Foscolo also agrees to cause the Garden of the said Cappa Cottage to be neatly laid out and planted with fruit trees shrubs and flowers in such a manner as he shall think fit and the said John Banim engages to keep it in good order and conditions, lastly said John Banim engages not to open nor cause to be opened any shop in said premises nor to let the said Cottage furnished or unfurnished nor in any wise part with the possession thereof without the consent of the said Ugo Foscolo and which consent may be obtained by satisfactory references as to respectability of the new tenant; And the said Ugo Foscolo agrees to procure a lease to be granted to the said John Banim for the said term of the five years on the conditions aforesaid such lease to contain all the covenants of the original lease to the said Ugo Foscolo or any person in trust for him, except the covenant of insuring the said John Banim not to be at liberty to require the said Ugo Foscolo to show any title to property to be comprises in such lease so to be granted but a lease from the said Ugo Foscolo or from any person who shall be a Trustee for him shall in all respects be sufficient.
Ugo Foscolo
John Banim
Witnesses Lewis John Green

Two detached houses on the west side of South Bank Regents Park, looking on the canal and enjoying an open view on all sides are held on a lease of about 90 years by a foreign single Gentleman. The largest of these two cottages called Digamma Cottage was built under his own eyes and according to his directions; the smaller house called Cappa Cottage was purchased by him from the builder. The two houses, although sixty feet or more, from each other, may communicate through a garden by a door contrived for the purpose. Two sides of Cappa Cottage is enclosed by oak fencing; these sides of Digamma Cottage by a wall from six to seven feet high, and of 130 feet long in front. The extent of the gardens of the two cottages is more than three nuarters of an acre; the largest part of it belonging to Digamma Cottage is divided into four parts: Front Garden; Flower Garden; Kitchen Garden, and pleasure Grounds; and planted with the choicest fruit and ornamental trees, and flowering shrubs of every kind, some of which are very rare. But as in case of any arrangement the premises would be examined a minute description is unnecessary. It may however be added that the property will improve as it is yet a new neighbourhood, and the plantation very recent; — it will also remain a respectable neighbourhood, as by the original leases no shop is allowed to be opened nor any trade to be carried on in the houses of South Bank. —
The smaller of the two cottages is now let at L. 65 yearly rent; the holder of the lease resides himself in the larger. —

The two houses including the walls, plantations and fixtures cost to the holder of the lease upwards of L. 2000, and, if it be required, it will be proved by bills and receipts that the garden alone of Digamma Cottage cost not less than L. 200. —

There is besides in Digamma Cottage as much furniture as two appraisers would bona fide value at L. 1500 — the bills for whom may be shown, and the different tradesmen from whom it has been purchased, refered to and it will be found that much more has been paid for it. —
The two houses pay an annual ground rent of L. 36. —

The taxes cannot be precisely stated as the houses have not been yet assessed, but from the assessments of the neighbouring houses, the taxes for both houses cannot exceed L. 140, neither of their having more than twelve windows, and the parish of Marylebonne not being overloaded with four rates —
The holder of the lease offers the three following propositions. —
First proposition. —

To give up the original lease of 90 years for the sum of L. 2000, provided he be retained himself as a tenant during his life, under condition that at his death not only the two houses but also the furniture of Digamma Cottage become the property of the holder of the original lease. He will therefore pay yearly to the holders of the original lease L. 36 that they may be sure of the payement of the ground rent — and moreover L. 100 for the rent of the houses. — Thus the capital of L. 2500 would be sank for an indefinite time, and produce only the 4 per cent interest, but the value of the furniture and the chance of a short life of the occupier, are to be taken into consideration; and he has no objection to reside in Digamma Cottage as a tenant of a furnished house; to [...] an inventory of the furniture as belonging to the landlord; and to pay jus to landlord yearly L. 40 more for the taxes; — always provided that he be the resident of the Digamma Cottage during the whole of his life, without any farther increasing of rent, — and provided also that the landlord prefaces every six months the documents necessary to show that the ground rent and taxes had been regularly paid — The gentleman is past forty, unmarried, without family or family connections in England; — and the improvements which he will not fail to make in a house built by himself for his own use during his life, together with those, which will naturally be produced by the growth of the sourronding gardens and groves in the neighbourhood, will make it a desirable residence for a family, expecially as there is an iilterior communication between the two cottages, and ground sufficient to build a stable and coach house.

p.hi: Dated 15th Aug.t 1823 — Ugo Foscolo Esq.re to Charles Rossi Esq.re Power of Attorney to receive Rents and for general Purposes.

div2.p: To all Persons to whom these presents shall come and concern I — Ugo Foscolo of South Bank Regent's Park in the Parish of St Mary–le–bone in the County of Middlesex Esq.s — send greeting. Whereas I am about to go and continue some time abroad and am therefore desirous that the rents of my houses should be received and that my said houses and other my real and personal estate whatsoever and wheresoever and other my affairs should during my absence be managed conducted and transacted by Charles Rossi of Lisson Grove North in the Parish of St Mary–le–bone aforesaid Esquire. Now therefore for effectuating the Purposes aforesaid Know ye that I the said Ugo Foscolo do hereby make constitute and appoint the said Charles Rossi my true and lawful Attorney for me and in my name from time to time to collect and receive the rents arrears of rent issues and profits of all and every or any of my said Houses and other Hereditaments in South Bank aforesaid or elsewhere And also to let and manage the same or any part thereof and other my real and personal Estate whatsoever and wheresoever And for me and in my name to make sign seal and deliver any Lease or Leases — Agreement or Agreements Contract or Contracts or other lawful Deeds or Instruments whatsoever for that — purpose as he my said Attorney shall think proper. And to receive collect and get in all and every sum and sums of money and other hereditaments due owing and to become due and owing to me on any account whatsoever And upon non payment of the said rents or monies or any part thereof respectively to distrain for use and exercise all lawful ways and means for the recovery thereof respectively And also to commence any action or actions suit or suits in any Court of Law or Equity for the recovery of any sum or sums of Money Debt master or thing whatsoever which is or shall be owing or belonging to me or any person In trust for me and the same Action suit or suits to prosecute and follow up and to discontinue or become nonsuited therein or otherwise to act as to my said Attorney shall seem meet. — And also to state settle audit and adjust all accounts depending or to depend between me and any person or persons whosoever and to receive or pay the Balance thereof as the case shall happen And upon the recept or recovery of all or any such rents Arrears of Rent Purchase Monies Debts sum or sums of money or things as aforesaid or upon settling and adjusting such Accounts respectively to give good effectual receipts acquittances Releases and other Discharges for me and in my name or otherwise as to my said Attorney shall seem meet. And also by and out of such monies as shall from time to time come to the hands of my said Attorney to pay any just debts that shall or may be owing from me to any person or persons whosoever or such part thereof as my said Attorney shall think proper or to apply the same for the keeping down or discharging all or any Interest due to or to grow due on any Mortgage or other Security given or here after to be given by me — And also for me and in my name or otherwise in my behalf to manage order and direct any Alterations or Repairs of Buildings or hereditaments and all and singular other my concerns whatsoever And from time to time to continue or to appoint hire and retain or discharge any Receiver Agent or other persons that is are or shall by my said Attorney be thought necessary to be employed or discharged from my service in for about or concerning the premises for the purposes aforesaid or any other purpose whatsoever for such time and under such Agreement and with such Salaries as my said Attorney shall think proper and to pay the same out of the Monies which shall come to his hands And I do hereby further authorize and empower my said Attorney to do perform and execute all and every other act Deed matter or thing whatsoever which shall be necessary or proper to be done in or about my concerns Affairs and Business as fully and effectually to all intents and purposes as I might or could do if personally present and did the same hereby ratifying and confirming and agreeing to ratify and confirm all or whatsoever my said Attorney shall lawfully do or cause to be done in or about the premises by virtue of these presents In witness whereof I have here unto set my hand and seal this fifteenth day of August — in the year of our Lord One Thousand eight Hundred and Twenty three.
Ugo Foscolo —

Signed sealed and delivered in the presence of W.m Ainge
14 Essex Street

Accordo d'un patto fra il Signor Ugo Foscolo, e i Signori Filippo Ugoni e Giovita Scalvini; — il Signor Ugo Foscolo obbligandosi di dare a pigione a' Signori Ugoni e Scalvini la casa di sua pertinenza situata in South Bank, nominata Green cottage, co' mobili e masserizie registrate nell'annesso inventario, per lo spazio di tre mesi dal giorno d'oggi Sedici Ottobre 1823, e i Signori Ugoni e Scalvini si obbligano di pagare ciascheduno una Lira sterlina per settimana, di avere cura de' mobili e masserizie, e restituirle ciascheduno per la sua rata porzione; — riserbandosi nondimeno in questo patto al Signor Scalvini il diritto di lasciare a suo beneplacito anche prima del termine del trimestre la parte della casa ch'egli abita, e riservandosi al Signor Ugoni il diritto di scegliersi fino al termine del trimestre un compagno che abiti le stanze che fossero lasciate dal Signor Scalvini, e in questo caso il Signor Ugoni pagherà Lire due, e la casa gli sarà devoluta interamente. Ma in caso che il Signor Ugoni non trovasse compagno, continuerà a pagare una sola Lira, ed occuperà tutta la casa dalle stanze in fuori occupate dal Signor Scalvini, le quali con la rata porzione de' loro mobili e masserizie dovranno rimanere disoccupate. Finalmente caso che non si venisse a nuovo contratto, il Signor Foscolo avrà diritto di affiggere l'Appigionasi quindici giorni prima del termine del trimestre e di far vedere la casa a chi aspirasse di pigliarla a pigione avvertendone previamente i Signori Ugoni e Scalvini, o il Signor Ugoni, se allora l'abitasse egli solo. —

Appendice, in data 29 Ottobre 1823. — Stando tutti i termini del soprascritto contratto osservabili fino al giorno 16 Gennaio 1824, il Signor Ugo Foscolo si obbliga di dare a pigione al Signor Filippo Ugoni da esso giorno 16 Gennaro fino al giorno 16 Aprile 1824 la casa tutta intera co' mobili e masserizie secondo l'inventario, e il Signor Filippo Ugoni si obbliga di pagare durante esso trimestre lire due sterline per settimana.
Ugo Foscolo
Filippo Ugoni
Giovita Scalvini

p.hi: Ugo Foscolo Esq.re to Cha.s Rossi Esq.re Bill of Sale of Household Furniture etc.

div2.p: This Indenture made the sixteenth day of December in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and twenty three Between Ugo Foscolo of South Bank Regents Park in the parish of Saint Mary le Bone in the County of Middlesex Esquire of the one part and Charles Rossi of Lisson Grove North in the Parish of Saint Marylebone aforesaid Esquire of the other part Whereas the said Charles Rossi at the request and for the accomodation of the said Ugo Foscolo hath thro' the medium of his Bankers advanced divers sums of money to and for the use of the said Ugo Foscolo and become Surety and Guarantee for him for the payment of certain Bills of Exchange given for debts contracted by the said Ugo Foscolo to the extent of Two hundred and Twenty seven pounds nine shillings and six pence and as a Security to the said Charles Rossi for as well the repayment of the monies so advanced with lawful Interest as also of all such othersums of money as the said Charles Rossi shall hereafter advance or pay for or to or on the account of or by the Order of the said Ugo Foscolo with like Interest the said Ugo Foscolo hath agreed to enter into the Covenant hereinafter contained and to execute unto the said Charles Rossi a bargain and sale of all his Furniture Plate Books and other Articles and Things hereinafter mentioned Now this Indenture Witnesseth that in consideration of the Premises the said Ugo Foscolo Doth hereby for himself his Heirs Executors and Administrators Covenant Promise and Agree to and with the said Charles Rossi his Executors and Administrators that he the said Ugo Foscolo his Heirs Executors and Administrators shall and will from time to time hereafter when thereunto required by the said Charles Rossi his executors or administrators well and truly pay or cause to be paid to the said Charles Rossi his executors or administrators the several sums of money advanced by him to or for the use of the said Ugo Foscolo on Note Bill or otherwise and also all and every such sums and sum of money as the said Charles Rossi his Executors or Administrators shall at any time or times hereafter advance and pay by reason or in consequence of his having indorsed any Promissory Note or Notes of the said Ugo Foscolo or accepted indorsed or otherwise guaranteed the payment of any Bill or Bills of Exchange or debt of the said Ugo Foscolo and all and every other sum and sums of money which the said Charles Rossi his executors or administrators shall at any time or times hereafter advance or pay unto or for the use or to the order or to the account of the said Ugo Foscolo with lawful Interest for all and every such sum and sums of money after the rate of five pounds per cent per annum to be computed from the time or respective times of paying or advancing the same And this Indenture further witnesseth that for the considerations aforesaid And in consideration of five shillings of lawful money of Great Britain to the said Ugo Foscolo in hand paid by the said Charles Rossi at or before the sealing and delivery of these Presents the receipt whereof is hereby acknowledged He the said Ugo Foscolo Hath granted bargained sold assigned transferred and set over And by these Presents Doth grant bargain sell assign transfer and set over unto the said Charles Rossi his Executors and Administrators All and singular the Households Furniture Goods Plate Linen China Printed Books and other Articles and Things mentioned and specified in the Schedule hereunder written And all other the Furniture Plate Linen China Books Articles and Things in and about the House and Premises of the said Ugo Foscolo called Digamma Cottage Regents Park And also all the right title Property interest claim and demand whatsoever of the said Ugo Foscolo into and out of the Premises respectively To have and to hold the said Household Furniture Goods Plate Linen China Printed Books and other Articles and Things hereby granted bargained sold assigned transferred and set over or intended so to be unto the said Charles Rossi his Executors Administrators and assigns for his and their own use absolutely And it is hereby agreed and declared that the said Charles Rossi his Executors and Administrators shall stand possessed of the said Household Furniture Goods Plate Linen China Printed Books and other Articles and things so bargained sold and assigned as aforesaid as a Fund or Security for payment to him and them of the sum or sums of money which he the said Charles Rossi hath so advanced as aforesaid or which he his executors or administrators shall at any time or times hereafter advance or pay unto or for the use or to the order or to the account of the said Ugo Foscolo with Interest for the same after the rate of and to be computed from the time or respective times of paying or advancing the same And that it shall be lawful for the said Charles Rossi his Executors or Administrators at any time or times hereafter at his or their own discretion and without being answerable or in anywise accountable for the exercise of such discretion and without any further or other direction or authority of from or by the said Ugo Foscolo his executors or administrators to sell and dispose of all or any of the said Household Furniture Plates Books and other Articles and things hereby granted bargained and sold or expressed or intended so to be either by Public Sale or Auction or by Private Contract or otherwise and in such manner as he the said Charles Rossi his Executors or Administrators shall think proper And by with and out of the monies to arise by such Sale or Sales as aforesaid in the first place pay and satisfy the costs changes and expences of preparing for and makirig or otherwise attending such Sale or Sales as aforesaid And in the next place pay and satisfy himself and themselves all and every the Sum and Sums of Money which shall be then due and owing to him the said Charles Rossi his Executors or Administrators from and by the said Ugo Foscolo his Executors or Administrators with Interest for the same after the rate aforesaid from the time a respective times of paying or advancing the same respectively And also shall by with and out of the Monies to be produced by such Sale or Sales as aforesaid pay and satisfy all Bills of Exchange and Promissory Notes so as aforesaid accepted or indorsed or to be accepted or indorsed or otherwise guaranteed by the said Charles Rossi and then remaining unpaid when and as the same shall respectively become due and payable And also shall pay the surplus [if any] of the Money to be produced by such Sale or Sales as aforesaid unto the said Ugo Foscolo his Executors or Administrators And subject and without prejudice as aforesaid It is hereby Agreed and Declared between and by the said Parties hereto that the said Charles Rossi his Executors and Administrators shall stand possessed of the said Furniture Plate Books and other Articles and Things or such of them as shall not be disposed of for the purposes aforesaid In trust for the said Ugo Foscolo his Executors Administrators and Assigns Provisoes always And it is hereby Agreed that the total amount of the Monies secured or to be ultimately recoverable upon or by virtue of these Presents shall not exceed the sum of Three hundred pounds of lawful Money of Great Britain And it is hereby Agreed and Declared between and by the said Parties hereto that the receipt or receipts of the said Charles Rossi his Executors or Administrators shall be an effectual release and discharge of the Monies which shall arise by the sale of the said Household Furniture Goods Plate Linen China Books and other Articles or Things or any of them or which shall otherwise come to their or his hands or hand by virtue of or under these Presents And the Person or Persons paying such sum or sums of money shall not be bound to see to the application nor be in any wise answerable or accountable for the loss misapplication or nonapplication of the Monies which shall in such receipt or receipts be expressed to be received nor shall any Purchaser or Purchasers of all or any of the said Household Furniture Goods Plate Linen China Printed Books and other Articles or things be bound or required to ascertain or enquire into the necessity or propriety of any Sale or Sales which shall be made by the said Charles Rossi his Executors or Administrators And the said Ugo Foscolo doth hereby for himself his Heirs Executors and Administrators further Covenant and Agree to and with the said Charles Rossi his Executors and Administrators that it shall be lawful for the said Charles Rossi his Executors Administrators and Assigns at all times hereafter to have hold use occupy possess and enjoy the said Household Furniture Goods Plate Linen China Printed Books and other Articles and Things hereby granted bargained sold or expressed or intended so to be without any let suit hindrance disturbance claim or demand whatsoever of from or by the said Ugo Foscolo his Executors Administrators or Assigns or of from or by any other person or persons whomsoever And more over that he the said Ugo Foscolo his Executors and Administrators shall and will from time to time and at all times hereafter as his and their own cost and charge upon every reasonable request of the said Charles Rossi his Executors Administrators or Assigns make do and execute or cause to be made done and executed all such further and other acts deeds matters and things for the further better and more absolutely assigning and assuring unto the said Charles Rossi his Executors and Administrators and for vesting in him and them the said Household Furniture Plate Books and other Articles or Things for his and their own use and benefit as by the said Charles Rossi his Executors Administrators or Assigns or his or their Counsel in the Law shall be reasonably advised or devised and required And the said Ugo Foscolo doth hereby for himself his Heirs Executors and Administrators Covenant Promise and Agree to and with the said Charles Rossi his Executors or Administrators and Assigns that he the said Ugo Foscolo his Executors or Administrators shall and will from time to time or as any time or times during the continuance of the Security hereby made or expressed or intended so to be at his and their own Costs and Charges and upon every or any reasonable request of the said Charles Rossi his Executors Administrators or Assigns well and sufficiently insure and keep insured the said Household Furniture Goods Plate Linen China Printed Books and other Articles and Things hereby assigned or expressed or intended so to be from loss or damage by fire in or for the sum of Four hundred pounds at the least in some Established Public Office of Insurance from fire in London or Westminster and shall and will immediately after such Insurance produce and deposit with the said Charles Rossi his Executors Administrators or Assigns the Instrument or Policy of every such Insurance. And it is hereby Agreed and Declared that in case the said Ugo Foscolo his Executors Administrators or Assigns shall at any time or times hereafter upon such request as aforesaid neglect or refuse to make or keep on. foot such Insurance as aforesaid it shall be lawful for the said Charles Rossi his Executors Administrators or Assigns from time to time to Insure or continue Insured the said Household Furniture Goods Plate Linen China Prints Books and other Articles or Things or any of them from loss or damage by fire as aforesaid or in such other manner as he or they shall think fit and to reimburse himself and themselves all Monies advanced for or on account of such Insurance under the Trusts of these Presents with Interest as aforesaid In witness whereof the said Parties to these Presents have hereunto set their hands and seals the day and year first above written.
Signed Sealed and Delivered and possession of the Furniture and other things mentioned in the Schedule by the delivering of a Chair in the name of the whole being taken, in the presence of
Ugo Foscolo

Kitchen — Patent–Range with Oven and Boiler — fender — Venetian blinds — Table — Large Bath — Chairs and kitchen Utensils.

Ugo Foscolo

div2.n: IV. Contratto col copista Andrea Schorno

argument.p: Prospetto del contratto da estendersi in dublo sopra carta bollata, conforme le condizioni propostemi dal Signor F. nella Domenica, 9 Maggio, 1824.

div2.p: 1o. Avendomi dato libertà di scegliere lo spazio di tempo che volessi impegnarmi, calcolando da' cinque, sei o più mesi, così io scelsi il corrente anno.
2. Io e Sarah ci sposeremo come esatto dal Signor F., e questo dopo finita la pubblicazione de' bandi che principiano oggi, e devon essere ripetuti per le prossime due Domeniche.

3. Io continuando di stare nel servizio del Signor F. come copista delle sue cose litterarie, m'obbligo pure di tenere in ordine la libbreria, e carte, e di tener la libbreria sempre netta di polvere, e di portare lettere, libri e piccoli pacchetti ove fossero diretti per questa città, — e fuori di questa città, ossia in luoghi più lontani con qualche abbuono, — e questo, principiando alle otto della mattina, io farei a qualunque ora sì di giorno che di notte.
4. Io mi obbligo di tenere i conti sia di cose domestiche, sia per altre cose senza eccezione, o come occorresse o piacesse al Signor F.

5. Il tempo fisso del copiare sarebbe dalle 8 ore della mattina sino alle 6 della sera — con la libertà del cibarsi, — cioè di fare colazione, e di pranzare — Questo tempo è lo stesso che quello di prima, cioè dalle 8 alle 12 della mattina, e dalle 2 alle 8 della sera, ed è più adattato in qualunque riguardo — lavorandosi senza interruzione le 10 ore e non perdendosi quelle dalle 12 alle due come prima; ed è anche migliore per la salute; — e siccome vi saranno sempre qualche piccole cose per li bisogni della mia famiglia, io, essendo in libertà dopo le sei della sera, avrò tempo di attenderci senza dover trascurare la minima cosa in quanto al mio obbligo. Ben inteso però che per lo spaccio di lettere ecc. come più sopra detto, io sarò sempre pronto dopo le sei della sera come dalle 8 della mattina in poi a qualunque ora sia di giorno sia di notte.
5. Le Domeniche, e delle feste il giorno delle Natali e quello della Pasqua affatto in libertà. Questo è un mio obbligo, e più quando maritato.
6. Quella notte prima del giorno che il Signor F. darà le sue letture, io mi obbligo di passarla tutta lavorando, e di alzarmi a quell'ora che occorresse o piacesse al Signor F.
7. Sarah, allora mia moglie, continuerà sotto il titolo di cook and house–keeper, — obbligandomi io pure di assisterle ove il Signor F. lo stimasse di qualche utilità o di suo aggradimento.
1. Il Signor F. darà a noi due le due stanze fornite, da Sarah prima occupate; inoltre lume e fuoco necessario.
2. Il Signor F. ci passerà L. 1 sterlina per settimana e ogni trimestre L. 7 1/2 rata del nostro inteso annuo salario di L. 30 sterline.

3. Il Signor F. darà la libertà a Sarah di lavare in casa le nostre cose, — o ci aumenterà il nostro inteso annuo salario (di L. 30 sterline) di L. 15 sterline, che secondo i calcoli più esatti la lavatura fuori ci verrebbe a costare, e che atteso la tenuità de' compensi a noi, sarebbe una spesa da sconcertarci affatto.

4. Non essendo certo che il Signor F., nè io, voglia rinnovare il contratto, il Signor F. mi darà piena libertà d'andare provvedendomi d'altra situazione per tutto lo spazio che io mi trovo nel servizio suo. —

N.B. Se il Signor F., aggradendo a questi patti che certo in ogni riguardo sono i più vantaggiosi per lui che in vita sua avrà fatto, vuol dar col giorno di domani principio al contratto, molto anche per riguardo alle mie circostanze, saro obbligato a lui, e in caso che non gli piacesse io non farò difficoltà d'incomminciarlo col l.o di Giunio prossimo.
Scritto, Domenica mattina, 16 Maggio.

Altra Nota — Circa il giardino nessun impegno. Ma io cercherò di mostrare anche in questo caso, che non mi dispiace di rendermi viemaggiormente benveduto in qualunque rispetto, e questo, o di fare questo con spontaneo calore o con più o meno interesse, m'incoraggierà l'anima del contratto, come questo al presente è la miglior cosa per impristinarmi piacevolmente nella mia vita avvenire. —

The undersigned namely Mr. Ugo Foscolo and Mr. Andrew Schorno, do agree in the presence of Mr. Giovita Scalvini to fulfill the compact as follows first Mr. Andrew Schorno does agree and promise to serve as a copyist Mr. Foscolo, and likewise to keep in order Mr. Foscolo's papers, accounts, and books, and help and serve him in whatever may be considered as for literary and arithmetical purpose, namely forwarding letters and settling bills —; and further Mr. Schorno does promise to serve Mr. Foscolo in the capacity said, and for the said purposes, for a whole twelve–month, namely from the first January to the last day of December of the year 1824, next ensuing — from the eight o'clock to twelve o'clock of each morning, and from two to eight o'clock of the afternoon — Sunday except in which day he shall be at liberty from twelve o'clock in the noon, to the next morning — and Mr. Foscolo in consideration of Mr. Schorno's service does agree and promise to pay Mr. Schorno L. 0.15.0 each week until the first day of February, and L. 0.18.0 each week from the first day of February to the last of May, and L. 1.0.0. from the first day of June to the last day of December, — and moreover to accomodate him with the same room and furniture which Mr. Schorno now occupies, and with light and fire necessary — without any other obligation whatever on the part either of Mr. Ugo Foscolo or of Mr. Andrew Schorno. —

ps.p: Witness, Giovita Scalvini

div2.n: V. Accordo arbitrale della controversia Walker–Prati

argument.p: Memorandum of the Award of the Arbiters in the affair in dispute between Mess.rs Alexander Walker, and Joachim de Prati

div2.p: The underseigned having met by virtue of the power given to them to act as arbiters by the parties who bowed themselves to abide by the Award of the said Arbiters, — the Arbiters having met and conferred several times on the subject and attentively examined the items of the respective accounts of the parties and the correspondence between them with other authentic documents, and moreover the said Arbiters, according to their powers, having referred farther the affair to Eyre Evans Crowe Esq. for his casting vote on some prints at issue, they have all unanimously decided 1.st — That the whole amount of L. 27 claimed by M.r de Prati cannot be granted to be a just claim for the whole of that sum; 2.nd — That on the other hand M.r Walker is liable to M.r Prati his executions of behalf of M.r Walker's litterary undertaking to the payment of the sum of L. 11.10.0. — and M.r Walker having already paid to M.' Prati the sum of L. 5.0.0., the remaining ballance of L. 6.10.0 is to be paid for[th]with by [...]

p.hi: Memorandum of the decision on the matters in dispute between Alexander Walker Esq.r and M.r Joachim de Prati LL.D. both parties having respectively bound themselves to abide by the award of Ugo Foscolo Esq.r and George Wallis Esq.' on the decision of a third person in case the two arbiters deemed it necessary to refer it farther.

div2.p: Accordingly Mess.rs Foscolo and Wallis having taken into consideration all the documents and the items and exceptions of the respective accounts, they did agree that some doubtful points concerning the customary practice and prices in the transactions between contributors of original papers translators editors and publishers of periodical Works, should be refered to Eyre Evan Crowe Esq.r This gentleman having satisfactority explained all the doubts submited to his opinion, the three arbiters agreed definitively to decide as follows.

First: That the sum of L. 27, charged by M.r Prati in the bill delivered by him to M.r Walker cannot be allowed without some material deductions, and that the remuneration claimed by M.r Wallis on the part of M.r Prati over and above the L. 27 aforesaid on account of certain translations partly printed and partly still in manuscript, ought to be likewise reduced to the scale of the prices usual in literary concerns.

Second: That although M.r Prati's demands cannot be granted to their full extent still his exertions to forward M.T Walker's literary undertakings are justly entitled to a fair remuneration the more as M.r Prati has ceased to have any interest in the said undertakings. The arbiters therefore allow to M.r Prati the sum of L. 11.10.0 for the discharge both of all the admissible items in the bill delivered to M.r Walker and of the subsequent demand in account of the aforesaid translations partly printed and partly manuscript; and as M.r Prati has formerly received the sum of L. 5.0.0 on account by M.' Walker, M.r Walker is requested to pay forwith the ballance of L. 6.10.0 and thus complete the allowed sum of L. 11.10.0.

Third: That the two manuscripts charged by M.r Prati and which have been deposited with the arbiter acting for M.r Walker, should be immediately delivered to the arbiter acting for M.r Prati. Accordingly the delivery of the said manuscripts has been executed in the presence of the third arbiter.

A DUEL BETWEEN TWO LITERARY CHARACTERS. — On Wednesday morning a meeting took place between U–o F–o, a foreigner, the author of some modern standard Italian Works, who was banished his country by Napoleon for his independent principles, and —G–m, Esq. the Editor of a weekly publication of considerable eminence. The parties exchanged shots without injury, and the affair was then amicably terminated. We understand a fair lady was the cause of the quarrel. — Bell's Dispatch.

We copied into the HERALD of Monday, from Bell's Weekly Dispatch, a paragraph relating to a duel, the particulars of which were incorrectly stated. We are requested to state that Mr. F. merely received his adversary's fire, and addressing himself to the persons present, said something to the effect that he should not deign to return it; and that, upon this, the matter ended, but without the least approach to, or attempt at any amicable understanding between the parties.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE MORNING HERALD.

SIR — A very foolish paragraph has been copied into your columns from a Sunday paper respecting a meeting between «two literary gentlemen» on Wednesday last. That paragraph contained this, amongst other falsehoods, «after an exchange of shots, the affair was amicably terminated». It is equally untrue that any «fair lady» was the cause of the dispute. This correction is due to one of the parties, at least, who regrets that any publicity should have been given to a private affair, and who hopes that your candour will allow such correction to be inserted in your paper of to–morrow. — I am Sir,
